teaAndTalking.name: Tea and Talking
teaAndTalking.node.81: (You have lost a little favor with Élisabeth)
teaAndTalking.node.80: Alex can barely finish the story because he's laughing too hard at his own story. This, in itself, proves to be so funny that you can't stop laughing either.
teaAndTalking.node.79: Eventually, you all have to part ways, and Alex returns to his patrol. You and Élisabeth return your cups to the tea vendor, who merrily tips his hat to you both. For a brief moment, all is right with the world.
teaAndTalking.node.78:
(You have gained some favor with Élisabeth)
(You have gained some favor with Alex)
teaAndTalking.node.77: The laughter flows freely between you, and good times are had by all.
teaAndTalking.node.76: ""Of course, I'm a professional, so I can't say anything about it." Élisabeth says. ""Instead I have to sit there with a straight face and paint, pretending that nothing is happening, while this animal is just soaking anything it gets close to. This wasn't a one time occurrence, mind you. This happened in every, single, sitting!"
teaAndTalking.node.75: Élisabeth begins telling the story of a private commision she received. It was a client who insisted on having their portrait painted with their prized dog. It was a decent idea, but it was made difficult by the fact that the dog would pee when it was agitated... and it was always agitated.
teaAndTalking.node.74: "So this is what we're up to?" Élisabeth says, wiping a tear of laughter from her eye. "Alright, I think I have something you'll all like."
teaAndTalking.node.72: Alex can barely finish the story because he's laughing too hard at his own jokes. This, in itself, proves to be so funny that neither you nor Élisabeth can stop laughing either.
teaAndTalking.node.71: Soon, you all have to pause to catch your breath, because Alex has gotten to the part of the story where his entire barracks of fifty men devolved into an all-out brawl when it was revealed that not two, or three, but seven different dragoons all had designs on the young woman's heart. Hearing him describe the chaos, the three of you are laughing so hard that you almost feel sick.
teaAndTalking.node.70: Without any further ado, Alex launches into a tale about the latest 'intrigue' of the men in his barracks. Specifically, this is the story of several dragoons all trying to court the sister of his comrade, Corporal d'Auvergne.
teaAndTalking.node.68: You do, and he leaps atop his horse to resume his patrol.
teaAndTalking.node.67: Wiping tears of good humor from your eyes, Alex realizes that he must finally part, and that the two of you must say your goodbyes, for now. "Wish me luck out there."
teaAndTalking.node.66: Your walk has to stop for a moment because Alex has gotten to the part of the story where his entire barracks of fifty men devolved into an all-out brawl, when it was revealed that not two, or three, but seven different dragoons all had designs on this young woman's heart. Hearing him describe the chaos, the two of you are laughing so hard that you almost feel sick.
teaAndTalking.node.65: Far too many men back in your village treated you like you were made of spun glass, and that you would shatter at the first sight of something indelicate. While you're sure they intended this to be kind and endearing, it merely ended up being frustrating and boring.
teaAndTalking.node.64: Alex is telling you a tale of the latest 'intrigue' of the men in his barracks. Specifically, this is the story of several dragoons all trying to court the sister of his comrade, Corporal d'Auvergne. It's a funny story, and it reminds you that it's nice to be with Alex, because while he's never rude, he also never treats you like you're fragile.
teaAndTalking.node.63: You and Alex walk together in the streets. He strolls with one hand around your waist, and the bridle of his horse in the other. His horse seems indifferent to the whole situation. The horse seems indifferent about everything, really.
teaAndTalking.node.62: You follow Alex as he departs, and Élisabeth stays behind.
teaAndTalking.node.61: "Au revoir, I guess." Says Élisabeth, picking up the empty tea cups. "I'll just return these myself."
teaAndTalking.node.60: Today feels like it was a good use of your time.
teaAndTalking.node.58: However, right as you're both about to finish up and say your goodbyes, Élisabeth takes your hand in both of hers and says "This has been wonderful. Thank you, Yvette."
teaAndTalking.node.57: You spend your time together catching up, unwinding, and edging closer and closer to each other on the edge of the fountain. Élisabeth is so blasé about so many things, but there's something extremely cute about how anything close to romantic affection in public makes her nervous. You never do anything more overt than brush your hand against hers, but it's fun to watch her heart race.
teaAndTalking.node.56: You and Elisabeth spend more time together, talking over your tea. It's not that there's anything wrong with Alex, per se, but being alone with just Élisabeth is different. Really, you've found that to be true of any situation where only women were in attendance. It's not to feel like you're struggling to be heard, because everyone already understands the same things.
teaAndTalking.node.55: With that, Alex mounts his horse and returns to his duties.
teaAndTalking.node.54: (You have lost a little favor with Alex)
teaAndTalking.node.53: "... yes. Thank you." Alex replies, obviously not anticipating this turn of events.
teaAndTalking.node.52: "It's all too easy for them to promise what they could do, when there's no way for them to follow through on their words. What guarantee is there that all of their promises of liberty and universal brotherhood won't be cast aside, once they become inconvenient? I certainly wouldn't believe a single thing those men say about what they'll do for women. Why should you be different?"
teaAndTalking.node.51: "I know the royal family is often painted as this aloof, uncaring thing, but Marie is so much more than that. She befriends and listens to people from every walk of life, and has even sponsored the works of the Chevalier de Saint-Georges." She says, referring to the accomplished black composer, who has so often been scorned by the general public.
teaAndTalking.node.49: Without another word, Alex mounts his horse, and returns to his patrol.
teaAndTalking.node.48: (You have lost some favor with Alex)
teaAndTalking.node.46: She leaves before you can say anything to calm her spirits. Instead, you are just left with Alex, who seems both confused and frustrated.
teaAndTalking.node.45: Today feels like it was a good use of your time.
teaAndTalking.node.44: You and Elisabeth chat for a while longer, but eventually you part ways with her, and head home.
teaAndTalking.node.43: With that, Alex leaps a top his horse, tips his hat to you both, and leaves.
teaAndTalking.node.42: Alex checks his pocket watch and his eyebrows jump in surprise. "Ah! Now I really must be on my way. However, I have no regrets, today has been both fantastic and enlightening."
teaAndTalking.node.41: (The Military has moved towards the Crown by some)
teaAndTalking.node.40: "That's something to certainly think about." Alex admits, rubbing his chin thoughtfully. "None of these things are ever simple."
teaAndTalking.node.39: "Well, this isn't normally something I'm normally asked to speak about, so it might be worthless, but we might as well get it over quickly, no?"
teaAndTalking.node.38: "So you understand, then!" Élisabeth exclaims. "Marie is trying to push things forward, but every time she does, the scandal from the public pushes her back. "Royalty is powerful, but it can't actually overrule the feelings of the people. The Revolutionaries promise so much change, but what happens when their high minded ideas reach a conservative public?"
teaAndTalking.node.37: "The 'Chevalier de Saint-Georges', as you know him, was my fencing instructor when I first came to France. Joseph is the most capable swordsman I've ever in all my life. I used to watch him toy with challengers by slicing buttons, one at a time, off of their coats."
teaAndTalking.node.36:
(You have lost some favor with Élisabeth)
(You have lost some credibility)
teaAndTalking.node.35: "Merde!" Alex grunts and shakes his head. "I lost track of time and need to resume my patrol." Out of the corner of your eye, you can't help but notice that Élisabeth looks a little excited by the prospect of spending more time alone with you.
teaAndTalking.node.34: "Besides, I don't think I'd look good in black."
teaAndTalking.node.33: "N-not that I watch you a lot." Élisabeth suddenly turns away and blushes. "It's just that examining people's faces is something I do for work. I'm an expert, of sorts..."
teaAndTalking.node.32: "It doesn't make any sense, does it?" Élisabeth admits. "It's just an old trick that my mother taught me. I don't understand why it works, but it's yet to fail me."
teaAndTalking.node.31: "I'll have you know that your facial expressions are very easy to read when you think that nobody is watching."
teaAndTalking.node.30: "God no!" Élisabeth laughs. "I have enough toil and trouble in my life as is. I'll stick to mixing paints and all the cursing that comes with that instead."
teaAndTalking.node.29: "I've just been a fool. I have to go." Élisabeth says to nobody in particular, starting to breathe faster and faster. You knew that expressing her affections in public was hard for her, but you didn't expect it to be this bad.
teaAndTalking.node.27: Élisabeth starts talking, not really about the monarchy per se, but instead about what she personally knows about Marie-Antoinette. How Marie has been disliked by the French people from the very beginning, due to being a foreign born queen. She talks about Marie's desire to help people, including her multiple adopted children, amongst them the former slave Jean Amilcar.
teaAndTalking.node.26: "To be completely honest, I rarely know what anyone actually wants from me, so I'm at a loss as to what I should do next." Élisabeth sighs. "Do you have any good stories, Alex?"
teaAndTalking.node.25: (You have gained some favor with Alex)
teaAndTalking.node.24: (You have gained some favor with Élisabeth)
teaAndTalking.node.23: "What would you have me believe, Madame Le Brun?"
teaAndTalking.node.22: "I-I can't do this." Élisabeth sighs in exasperation. "I finally felt comfortable being... No, this is just ruined. I need to go."
teaAndTalking.node.21: "Fine, I can wait a touch longer. What would you have us do, then?"
teaAndTalking.node.20: "Well, today has been rather slow." Alex admits, the tension seeming to drain out of him. "There can't be too many ne'er do wells out in this blasted heat."
teaAndTalking.node.19: "Fantastique!" Alex says, helping you up from your seat on the edge of the fountain. "I doubt things will get too 'interesting', but who knows?"
teaAndTalking.node.18: "Bonne chance! Corporal Dumas!" Élisabeth exclaims in agreement, shifting a little closer to you.
teaAndTalking.node.17: They stop to consider this. Alex shifts his feet, and glances back a few times at his horse.
teaAndTalking.node.16: "Yvette, would you care to join me for a little while on my patrol?"
teaAndTalking.node.15: The two of them glare at each other angrily, occasionally glancing at you.
teaAndTalking.node.14: "That's exactly what people who are a threat say!" Elisabeth replies. "Who and what are you even protecting us from? Everyone know the military is just one step away from joining the revolution anyway."
teaAndTalking.node.13: "The dragoons are not a threat." Alex sighs. "The only reason we've even been stationed in Paris is for everyone's protection."
teaAndTalking.node.12: The three of you spend some time catching up and telling stories, but you get the sense that Élisabeth and Alex don't really know how to act around each other. There's not necessarily a tension between the two of them, but there is a wariness.
teaAndTalking.node.11: "Don't worry! I'm on watch!" Alex laughs, stepping closer to the both of you, and scanning the crowd attentively.
teaAndTalking.node.10: "Oh, joy of joys." Elisabeth replies flatly. "An armed man walking into our conversation. I, in no way, feel threatened."
teaAndTalking.node.9: "No, not at all!" Élisabeth replies. "In fact, with you here, Yvette and I don't have to worry about strange men barging in to the conversation."
teaAndTalking.node.8: Looking at the two of you Alex suddenly takes half a step backwards. "Ah, mon Dieu! How rude of me! Was I interrupting something?
teaAndTalking.node.7: Alex strides over to the two of you, having freshly dismounted from his horse and holding the reins in his hand. The crowd easily parts for both him and his animal.
teaAndTalking.node.6: "Yvette, is that you?" Rings out a voice from the other side of a crowd.
teaAndTalking.node.4: "... and before you say anything to the contrary, I don't think you look disgusting, at all."
teaAndTalking.node.3: You oblige her, and are quickly surprised to find out that she's right. Something about it makes the heat more bearable. "I picked it up from the travelling vendor over there. We'll need to get him his cups back, eventually." She says, pointing out the man carrying the giant, awkward metal tank of tea on his back. The spigot for the tea is sculpted to look like a dragon's mouth.
teaAndTalking.node.2: It's at that moment, that Élisabeth appears at your side, holding a steaming cup of tea in each hand. "Drink this, it will help with the heat."
teaAndTalking.node.1: Even sitting on the edge of the fountain, cooled by the light mist, you're sweating like a horse at full gallop, without the breeze to accompany it. You feel disgusting, and secretly dread the idea of someone seeing you like this.
teaAndTalking.node.0: You decide to spend the day in the square near the water fountain. It's so humid today that if you spent any more time inside then you were afraid that you'd suffocate. You have no idea how Camille is managing to keep working in the kitchen, with a fire going, but you're glad that she can do it.
teaAndTalking.link.36: "Élisabeth and I are going to stay here. Alex, we'd hate to keep you from your duties."
teaAndTalking.link.35: "If you two don't try to get along, I will simply leave."
teaAndTalking.link.29: "How'd you know that hot tea would make me feel better?"
teaAndTalking.link.28: "It's quite bold of you to assume that I thought I looked disgusting."
teaAndTalking.link.27: "You know my thoughts so easily? Have you become a witch in your spare time?"
teaAndTalking.link.21: "Alex, I think you might be too hostile towards the Crown. Just listen to Élisabeth for a moment."
teaAndTalking.link.20: "Not much, I'm just trying to make sure that two people I enjoy very much get along."
teaAndTalking.link.15: "Actually, Élisabeth and I are going to stay here. Good luck out there!"
teaAndTalking.link.14: "I'd actually prefer if you both stayed. You have more in common than you think."
restAtHome.name: Rest At Home
restAtHome.node.5: (You no longer have any levels of exhaustion)
restAtHome.node.4: After spending the day in, taking care of yourself and doing some light reading, you finally feel recharged. The exhaustion that had been affecting you before has passed.
restAtHome.node.3: With that complete, you turn your focus upon the other matters that demand your attention.
restAtHome.node.2: Determined to be truly prepared for the tasks ahead, you stay in and fully unwind. Already, you feel like you'll perform better at your next party or rendezvous.
restAtHome.node.0: You decide to take the day off, and spend some time at home, resting and recuperating.
researchingMaximin.name: Researching Maximin
researchingMaximin.node.33: A man stands on a corner, reading the latest current events aloud from a newspaper to any passers-by willing to listen. Sometimes, people throw a coin into the hat placed at his feet.
researchingMaximin.node.32: (You now have a vital clue for finding Maximin's weakness. However, you'll need to figure out where to search next, on your own.)
researchingMaximin.node.31: Done for the day, you return home, to plan your next move.
researchingMaximin.node.30: Maximin’s mystery servant works at a cafe in Paris. They’re a woman with eyes that are different colors from each other. It’s a solid lead, but you still have a ways to go before you can use it to hurt Maximin.
researchingMaximin.node.29: Deciding that you’ll need a little more information before you can track this person down, you decide to ask around the marketplace.
researchingMaximin.node.28: While all of this knowledge is still fresh in your mind, you take out your journal and write down everything you’ve learned.
researchingMaximin.node.27: A mystery servant, who now works in a cafe. There must be over a hundred cafes in Paris, how are you supposed to find this servant?
researchingMaximin.node.26: “Other than that, I am at a loss madame. Now, you must excuse me, as I must return to my work…” he unfolds the newspaper and returns to yelling to the crowd, and soliciting donations.
researchingMaximin.node.25: “Ah yes, I remember now! This servant is still in the city somewhere, working at a cafe. The good Baron threatened the owner to fire the servant, but the cafe owner wouldn’t budge.”
researchingMaximin.node.24: “Fine! If it will make you go away, then fine…” He angrily wads the newspaper up and tucks it under his arm.
researchingMaximin.node.23: "Nobody’s asked about the mystery servant rumor for a while." He pauses to think for a moment before continuing. "I remember my cousin tried to claim that this servant had committed murder in cold blood, but that turned out to be a pack of lies…"
researchingMaximin.node.22: “Fine! If it will make you go away, then fine…” He angrily wads the newspaper up and tucks it under his arm.
researchingMaximin.node.21: “Can you not see that I’m working?”
researchingMaximin.node.20: “What?” He shouts at you, a vein bulging at the corner of his forehead.
researchingMaximin.node.19: “1st United States Congress declares new constitution to be in effect!”
researchingMaximin.node.14:
The crier glares at your interruption with even greater intensity than before, and insistently taps his foot next to his hat full of coins on the ground.

With a deep breath, he continues proclaiming headlines.
researchingMaximin.node.13: “Venetian arsenal in Corfu explodes, over 100 believed dead!”
researchingMaximin.node.12: “Oh, merci madame!” The Crier says to you, feigning the appropriate amount of surprise. He folds up the newspaper and tucks it under one arm.
researchingMaximin.node.11: The crier pauses to glare at you for a moment, before tapping his hat full of coins with his foot. He then returns to reading the headlines aloud to the crowd.
researchingMaximin.node.9: “The Estates General approaches! Representatives from the third estate expected to demand changes to noble privileges!”
researchingMaximin.node.8: Acting on a hunch, you check in with the crier you saw reading the newspaper aloud earlier. Only a few people have stopped to actually listen to him. His clothes look like they're of fine make, but they're old enough to be in a state of disrepair.
researchingMaximin.node.7: Knowing what they look like is simply not enough to track them down.
researchingMaximin.node.6: You’ve never heard of anything like that before, but it’s certainly possible. If nothing else, it would make this person quite distinct. However, there are over a million people in Paris.
researchingMaximin.node.5:
All of the servants who suddenly left Maximin’s employ were men… except for this one. The mystery servant is a young woman.

Not only that, she's a woman with eyes that are different colors from each other. It’s said to be quite striking to behold.
researchingMaximin.node.4: You approach the man shouting newspaper articles to the nearby shoppers. Only a few people have stopped to actually listen to him. His clothes look like they’re of fine make, but they’re old enough to be in a state of disrepair.
researchingMaximin.node.3: Delving into the marketplace proper, you talk with the various merchants, trying to learn a little more. It’s like fishing in a river for one particular fish. However, you walk away with one valuable piece of information.
researchingMaximin.node.2: Far from the nobility, this feels like the right place to inquire about Maximin’s mystery servant.
researchingMaximin.node.1: "Porters, commoners, and servants bustle to and from. They haggle, exchange coin for wares and occasionally lean in, to slyly share the most interesting and scandalous news of the day. The marketplace buzzes with activity, like a beehive.
researchingMaximin.node.0: You walk the streets near the marketplace les Halles, and just… listen.
researchingMaximin.link.25: "I can do this all day, just tell me what I want to know."
researchingMaximin.link.22: “I’m just looking for the Baron de Termes mystery servant. Tell me and I’ll leave.”
researchingMaximin.link.20: Please, it will only take a mo-
researchingMaximin.link.17: "I'm looking for dirt on the Baron de Termes. Know something about their mystery servant?"
researchingMaximin.link.16: “The Baron de Termes had a servant who quit for mysterious reasons. Know anything?”
researchingMaximin.link.2: “The man on the corner feels like a good place to start.”
researchingMaximin.link.1: “I should ask around in the marketplace…”
researchingArmand.name: Researching Armand
researchingArmand.node.62: "We've met once or twice. Armand, we need to hurry. If someone like her could find you, then we aren't doing a very good job of hiding. We have to go!"
researchingArmand.node.61: "You two already know each other?" Armand asks.
researchingArmand.node.60: "Ah, Yvette. I see we meet again."
researchingArmand.node.59: "Your fiancée? After all this time, I just assumed..." Johanna trails off, looking you over carefully.
researchingArmand.node.58: ""Yvette, this is Johanna du Jardin. She leads the political society I've been working with. Johanna, this is Yvette Decaux, my fiancée. She managed to track me down!" Armand says, quite proudly.
researchingArmand.node.57: There's no guarantee that he'll ever come back here. There's barely a guarantee that he was even here at all.
researchingArmand.node.56: You exit the tavern, your mind swirling with dark possibilities, and heavy with a sense of dread. You've found Armand, but now you're wondering if that was for the best.
researchingArmand.node.55: You exit the tavern, your mind swirling with the need for answers, but full of renewed purpose. You've already found Armand, now you can focus on understanding what's truly going on.
researchingArmand.node.53: "I suppose that's reasonable." Armand admits, running his fingers through his hair. "Yvette, you know how to find me. I want to tell you more, but for now I need to go. Don't worry, this won't last forever."
researchingArmand.node.52: "The longer we stay on the streets, the more likely it is that some assassin runs a blade through your ribs." Johanna replies in a soothing voice, resting her fingers on the back of his hand. "You won't see her again at all if that happens."
researchingArmand.node.51: "Just when I've finally found her again? Absolutely not."
researchingArmand.node.50: "I have so much to tell you, and so much to show you. Soon, you'll understand why I've done all of this. You'll see what's at stake for us."
researchingArmand.node.49: "... but I cannot say that I don't deserve it at least somewhat. Perhaps you'll be able to forgive me with time, when you see that I had good reason for all of this. When you see what's at stake for us."
researchingArmand.node.48: "Well, no matter! If someone like her could find you, then we aren't doing a very good job of hiding. We have to go!"
researchingArmand.node.47: "Oh! I suppose introductions are in order!"
researchingArmand.node.46: She freezes in her tracks when she sees you. "... who is this?"
researchingArmand.node.45: "Armand, what the devil are you doing here? We need to-" A woman asks as she walks into the tavern.
researchingArmand.node.44: (Armand's Purpose is now available to visit on the Paris Map)
researchingArmand.node.43: He hands you the paper, which he's written an address on. "It's a house on the western edge of the city. Don't worry, it's just as 'charming' as the one you're living in at the moment."
researchingArmand.node.42: "Well, please at least consider it. I for one, can't wait to-"
researchingArmand.node.39: "While I can't move back in with you, you'll at least be able to to visit me where we're staying."
researchingArmand.node.38: "Of course, right now, I still have to risk going to the Estates General, as I have many important things to do there. Thankfully, nobody can risk assailing me while I'm there, but I have to keep my living situation a secret due to the threat of ambush." He says while he pulls out a piece of paper and begins to write on it.
researchingArmand.node.37: (You have lost a little favor with Armand)
researchingArmand.node.36: (You have gained a little favor with Armand)
researchingArmand.node.35: (You have gained some favor with Armand)
researchingArmand.node.34: "As for our present, I would never ask you to rebuild a ship in the middle of a storm. Much in the same way, I’d rather we figure out what we're doing with ourselves when this all stops being such a hurricane. You were willing to wait for me. I’m willing to wait for you."
researchingArmand.node.33: "Please ma chérie, don't think anything of it. You had no idea where I was, or if I'd ever be back at all."
researchingArmand.node.32: "I've dreaded for weeks the thought that you would say that."
researchingArmand.node.31: "You have no idea how eagerly I've awaited to hear those words from you." He says, laughing with a sense of great relief.
researchingArmand.node.30: "However, I had no idea when those villains would return, and how many of their associates they'd bring with them. So, I had to flee that very night. I know, in my mind, that it was a sound decision, but in my heart I've regretted it ever since."
researchingArmand.node.29: "Thankfully, my father's constant insistence that I study the art of pugilism proved to be wise. After a great struggle, and several smart applications of a candelabra to their heads and shoulders, I managed to drive them both from the house." He stands proudly, but a telltale wince suggests that he might still be recovering from some injuries.
researchingArmand.node.28: "In fact," He says in a low voice. "I believe that they're the one who sent those men to do violence upon me."
researchingArmand.node.27: "I was beside myself with rage when I'd heard that they lashed out at you to get vengeance on me. I knew that I'd angered them with my proposals, but I had no idea that they'd sink to such wretched behavior."
researchingArmand.node.26: "I was attending parties and needed to make inroads with powerful people, including one Viscountess du Foix." He shakes his head ruefully.
researchingArmand.node.24: "Thinking of how I failed you, and how I'd do anything to make things right again."
researchingArmand.node.23: "Ever since I had to leave that house, I spent every night thinking of you."
researchingArmand.node.22: "I was attending parties and needed to make inroads with powerful people, including one Maximin de Termes." He shakes his head ruefully.
researchingArmand.node.21: "I came to Paris and, as you can tell by my old dwellings, had to live very frugally. As much as I enjoy little luxuries, my money was better spent on my other pursuits in the city."
researchingArmand.node.20: (You have gained a little favor with Armand)
researchingArmand.node.19: (You have lost a little favor with Armand)
researchingArmand.node.18: (You have gained some favor with Armand)

researchingArmand.node.16: "I understand you anger, ma chérie, I really do, but can you at least give me a chance to explain myself?"
researchingArmand.node.15: "I can assure you, ma chérie, that I know exactly how you feel."
researchingArmand.node.14: "I'm so glad to see you." He says, his eyes staring deeply into your own.

researchingArmand.node.12: You're still struck dumb with shock when he leads you off the street and into a nearby tavern with no other patrons. The staff look at the two of you with a mixture of confusion and indignation, as if the very idea of customers offends them to their core.
researchingArmand.node.11: "We should get off the street." He says, quietly.
researchingArmand.node.8: You're about to scour the streets and alleys, when you feel a tap on your shoulder.

researchingArmand.node.5: You feel a rush of energy as you say this to yourself. You cannot rest until you have answers!
researchingArmand.node.4: You feel a rush of energy as you say this to yourself. You can't stop now, not until Armand truly understands the extent of your displeasure.
researchingArmand.node.3: You feel a rush of energy as you say this to yourself. You can't stop now, not while love is at stake!
researchingArmand.node.2: It's utterly maddening, and you struggle to remember what's even motivating you right now.

researchingArmand.node.0: Getting ready in a flash, you head out into the street with the newspaper and your journal, determined to find some evidence of where Armand could possibly be. researchingArmand.link.62: "The more I'm learning about this situation, the less I like it."
researchingArmand.link.61: "I'll go see him as soon as possible, then I'll get some answers."
researchingArmand.link.45: "I'm not sure if I can risk it."
researchingArmand.link.44: "Un moment, Armand. What do you mean by 'where we're staying'?"
researchingArmand.link.43: "I'll do so as soon as I can."
researchingArmand.link.36: "I have some things of my own that I need to apologize for."
researchingArmand.link.35: "You can apologize all you wish, but words won't heal this."
researchingArmand.link.34: "Please, I've already forgiven you. I'm just glad you're alive."
researchingArmand.link.18: "... What happened to you? What's going on? Why? Why to any of this?"

researchingArmand.link.16: "I've never been so happy to see you."
researchingArmand.link.7: "Perhaps I should go inside and question the proprietor."
researchingArmand.link.3: "The truth. All I want is the truth."

researchingMarcelle.node.17: Each of the vile Viscountess’ dresses would have cost far too much just to pay for it in coins. It would require a banknote. Any dressmaker that worked with Marcelle would have to know the name and address of her bank, in order to collect any payments.
researchingMarcelle.node.16: An idea strikes you, as quickly and surely as a lightning bolt.
researchingMarcelle.node.15: She would have to have been an unpleasant customer indeed, in order to drive a dressmaker away. Apparently, every order she places is completely unique, which means each item in her wardrobe would cost a fortune.
researchingMarcelle.node.14: Marcelle’s vanity, demanding nature, and abrasive manner have led her into serious disagreements with several dressmakers and clothiers across the city. In fact, some of them simply refuse to do business with her anymore, though she claims the situation to be the other way around.
researchingMarcelle.node.13: Do you get to decide that about yourself? Isn’t that something that other people have to call you?
researchingMarcelle.node.12: Apparently, Marcelle is rather obsessed with her clothing and personal appearance, even claiming to be a ‘fashion icon’.
researchingMarcelle.node.11: In the third hour, however, something piques your interest…
researchingMarcelle.node.10:
During the second hour, you hear something about Marcelle’s father, the former Viscount du Foix. Apparently, Viscount Alfonso du Foix died a few years ago, and his funeral was so lavish that people are still discussing it today. 

Not exactly what you’re looking for, but it’s on the right track.
researchingMarcelle.node.9: (You have acquired some Cheap Crown Gossip)

researchingMarcelle.node.6: Without the benefit of a title, or an introduction, you can’t approach any of these groups directly. However, there’s nothing to stop you from overhearing things as you just ‘pass by’.
researchingMarcelle.node.5: You remember reading about this place over a year ago. Its storied buildings are even more impressive in person. Elegantly dressed aristocrats strut about the gardens, stopping briefly to chat in hushed tones.
researchingMarcelle.node.4: (La Place Royale is now available to visit in the Paris map)
researchingMarcelle.node.3: La Place Royale, the favored social spot for all the aristocrats in the city. The hub of all gossip, social news, slander, and scandal. If there was ever a telling secret, or a salacious rumor, this was the place to find it.
researchingMarcelle.node.2: La Place Royale. The elegant square is packed today, with titled persons flitting this way and that, all eager to share the most scandalous social news of the day.
researchingMarcelle.node.1: There’s only one place to learn more about a woman like that...
researchingMarcelle.node.0:
You start your day by walking  towards the center of Paris. 

Viscountess De Foix isn’t just a member of the aristocracy, she’s a woman who wields her title and noble privileges like a weapon.
salaciousNovelty.name: Salacious Novelty
salaciousNovelty.node.50: ... just how much of this poem is lusty encounters? Is it necessary for the narrator to explain that the sex was good? Shouldn't that just be apparent?
salaciousNovelty.node.49: Well, one thing's for certain, Antoine's concepts of spelling and grammar are about as radical and unconstrained as his politics. Some of the turns of phrase are clever, but most of this feels like it's being offensive for its own sake, rather than making an actual point. The characters are less like living people, and more like marionettes for stating Antoine's ideas.
salaciousNovelty.node.48: Is that... is that a dedication to the Vatican? Oh no...
salaciousNovelty.node.46: Hesitantly, you begin to read the first canto of this 'fantasy epic', about a lusty young knight named... 'Antoine Organt'. That could have been more subtle.

salaciousNovelty.node.44: (You have gained a little favor with Antoine)

Hopefully, they can hire a proofreader for him.

salaciousNovelty.node.17: "But, of course! What matters is the message: Early man wasn't restricted by society and ranks. He was natural and free! To tear down the old would only make us better."
salaciousNovelty.node.16: "Have you lost your mind? We're a respectable publishing house, not some back-alley print shop."
salaciousNovelty.node.15: "Would you be willing to do that, Monsieur de Saint-Just?"
salaciousNovelty.node.14: "What?!" He spits at you. "You're giving up as well?"
salaciousNovelty.node.13: "Madame, are you seriously insulting my company like that?"
salaciousNovelty.node.12: Antoine leans in intently, as she stops to consider your proposal.
salaciousNovelty.node.10: "Well no, we can't print it. We love it personally, we just don't think it'll sell enough copies to make its cost back."

salaciousNovelty.node.6: "Bonjour! Are you Louis Antoine de Saint-Just? I'm from T. Guerin publishing." Says a woman, interrupting you at the best possible time.
salaciousNovelty.node.5: He smiles, wide and genuine. "I can't wait to hear what they say. Back home I had a limited printing, but a new run from a publisher in Paris could be what it needs to get the success it deserves."
salaciousNovelty.node.4: "I'm here to meet with a publisher. They read my poem 'Organt, a Poem In Twenty Cantos', and wanted to discuss it."

salaciousNovelty.link.10: "Sell it anonymously, and say that it was banned. That kind of mystique advertises itself!"
steppingOutForADrink.name: Stepping Out For A Drink
steppingOutForADrink.node.71: "Don't worry. The value of my words shall prove self-evident in but a moment."

(You have gained some favor with Alex)
(You have gained some favor with Antoine)
steppingOutForADrink.node.69: They each buy a bottle of wine for the table and spend their time trading death defying stories. Between Alex's adventures fighting bandits in the countryside and Antoine's various run ins with the law, it's a miracle that both them are alive.
steppingOutForADrink.node.68: As the evening winds down, you all end up heading your separate ways. The wine may have been sweet, but not nearly as sweet as your success today.
steppingOutForADrink.node.67: (The Military has moved towards the Revolution some)

steppingOutForADrink.node.64: "I see what you're saying, Antoine, and would like to you note that I'm quite familiar with this problem. Even 'benevolent' masters are no such thing."
steppingOutForADrink.node.63: Now that these two have actually let their guards down a little around each other they get along decently well. There's still a tension in the air, but you're not worried that a fight is going to break out while they talk.
steppingOutForADrink.node.61: Antoine shakes his hand across the table. "I can tolerate such an alliance."
steppingOutForADrink.node.60: Antoine launches into a speech explaining that a constitution is a contract between their people and their government. Despite all of its promises of stability, monarchy is ultimately subject to the whims of whoever sits on the throne. Even with a good leader, monarchy is a system dependent on tyranny.
steppingOutForADrink.node.59: "I will... reserve my judgement until he's said his piece."
steppingOutForADrink.node.58: Alex looks Antoine up and down, before slowly extending his hand. "A truce?"
steppingOutForADrink.node.57: You wait around a touch longer to finish your wine before leaving. However, no amount of wine will drive away the bitter taste that this has left in your mouth.
steppingOutForADrink.node.56: With a polite nod, Alex gets up and leaves. Shortly afterwards, Antoine stalks back to his own table.
steppingOutForADrink.node.55:
(You have lost a little favor with Alex)

steppingOutForADrink.node.54: "I hate to agree with this fiend, but he's right. In fact, this reminds me that I have some other, pressing business that I should attend to."
steppingOutForADrink.node.53: You both leave the bar, with different destinations in mind.
steppingOutForADrink.node.52: "Unfortunately, I must take my leave. We should do this again, sometime."
steppingOutForADrink.node.51: "It was a prudent decision for you to join me. Make no mistake, you have quite the insightful mind, but it's not just that. You're inspiring, Yvette."
steppingOutForADrink.node.50: The candlelight dances in Antoine's eyes as he writes faster and faster. Eventually, he slams down his pen, and stares at you. It feels like he's looking into your soul.
steppingOutForADrink.node.49: He tests a few of his arguments on you, and you dissect them as best as you can. You're no fool, but these are difficult questions, and this is an extremely ambitious project on his part. If we were to abandon all of our thoughts and prejudices from the past, what would we even be left with? How would we stop ourselves from immediately making the exact same mistakes, all over again?
steppingOutForADrink.node.48: You take advantage of this offer to join Antoine, who is in the process of writing a political treatise. The whole thing is concerned with the idea of 'natural laws'. Essentially pointing out that all the laws of our society have been made by men with their own interests at heart, no matter their claims about fairness or "divine inspiration".
steppingOutForADrink.node.47: "I shall return to my table. You may join me, if you like."
steppingOutForADrink.node.46: Alex drains his wineglass, and leaves the public house. Antoine stares at you, intensely.
steppingOutForADrink.node.45: You head home yourself, and consider the day's events. The wine may have been sweet, but not nearly as sweet as your success today.
steppingOutForADrink.node.44: With a theatrical bow, Alex leaves.
steppingOutForADrink.node.43: As he rises from his seat, Alex leans forward and gives you a kiss upon your forehead.
steppingOutForADrink.node.42: A church bell rings in the distance, drawing your attention to the waning hours. "Unfortunately, I must take my leave. Regardless, this was great, Yvette. With all of the furor and strife going on, I truly needed something likes this."
steppingOutForADrink.node.39: You lose a few hands, but it hopefully won't be enough to deter any of your carefully laid plans.
steppingOutForADrink.node.38: You win more hands than you lose, and feel a surge of triumph, despite the petty amounts of coin at risk. Sometimes, it's the little victories that make life worth it.
steppingOutForADrink.node.37: To make things interesting, you both engage in some petty gambling with minimal stakes. Of course, that doesn't stop you both from pretending like you're risking staggering fortunes with every wager. The theatrics are really what make the game work.
steppingOutForADrink.node.36: To make things interesting, you both engage in some petty gambling with minimal stakes. Of course, that doesn't stop you both from pretending like you're risking staggering fortunes with every wager. The theatrics are really what make the game work.

Alex commandeers an unattended table left outside at a nearby cafe and you sit down to play a few rounds of brusquembille.

steppingOutForADrink.node.29: (You have gained some favor with Alex)
steppingOutForADrink.node.28: "I'm Louis Antoine de Saint-Just, but you may simply call me Antoine." Antoine replies, his voice equally tense. "Perhaps you've heard of me?"
steppingOutForADrink.node.27: "Yvette, what are the odds of us choosing to spend the evening in the same public house?" Antoine says as he strides over to your table, closing a book in his hand as he does so.
steppingOutForADrink.node.26: Your conversation is interrupted by the sound of the barmaid angrily tapping her foot, and holding her hand out expectantly.
steppingOutForADrink.node.25: "Ah, my apologies for sneaking up on you, Yvette." Alex says with a nod as he steps in front of you.
steppingOutForADrink.node.24: "Don't worry, I can stand! Honestly, I already spend too much time sitting in a saddle." Alex laughs, as he steps in front of you and across the table from you.
steppingOutForADrink.node.23: "It's great to see you, Yvette!" Alex says with a smile, taking a seat across from you.
steppingOutForADrink.node.22: Once seated, you gesture to one of the barmaids to bring you some wine. It's a task she quickly accomplishes, to your satisfaction. The wine is a young red, and still relatively sweet.
steppingOutForADrink.node.21: "A foolish assumption, Yvette. You clearly don't understand how deep this divide lies."
steppingOutForADrink.node.20: "What, exactly, did you have in mind?" asks Alex
steppingOutForADrink.node.18: "Ah, magnifique! I was hoping you'd say that."
steppingOutForADrink.node.17: The two of them look at you, almost in disbelief, before looking back at each other.
steppingOutForADrink.node.16: You flick your eyes back and forth between the two men.
steppingOutForADrink.node.15: "Well, if the good corporal is going to leave, then you could also stay here, Yvette. I wouldn't mind your presence."
steppingOutForADrink.node.14: Alex turns to you and smiles. "I was thinking about going somewhere, to play cards for a while. How would you feel about joining me? I bet you can bluff with the absolute best of them."
steppingOutForADrink.node.13: The tension at your table is oppressive, and you're starting to wish that you'd ordered something stronger than wine.
steppingOutForADrink.node.12: "A lasting republic, by any means." Antoine toasts, raising a wineglass of his own.
steppingOutForADrink.node.11: "It's true, my heart beats in time with the same fervent drum of any patriot that yearns for a new republic, but my true duty will always lie in protecting the innocent from any danger that comes their way."
steppingOutForADrink.node.10: "Please, call me Antoine. It's nice to see a brother in arms, eager to seize liberty from tyrants."
steppingOutForADrink.node.9: Antoine shoots Alex a flippant smile. "A quick death in the name of liberty, is a far nobler end than a slow death groveling under a tyrant's heel."
steppingOutForADrink.node.8: "Yes, I've heard of you." Alex says, narrowing his eyes. "However, I must admit the things I've heard have not been complimentary. I do not appreciate your... willingness to rush towards bloodshed."
steppingOutForADrink.node.7: "You have guessed correctly." Alex replies tersely. "... and that would make you?"
steppingOutForADrink.node.6: Alex looks at Antoine and slowly starts to relax, but you can tell that something about Antoine still puts him on edge. "You're correct, and you are?"
steppingOutForADrink.node.5: "... and you must be Corporal Dumas." Antoine says, turning to Alex. "Your reputation travels very quickly."
steppingOutForADrink.node.4: Just as the two of you are about to toast to each other's health, you're interrupted by the feeling of an intense stare from a few tables over. It almost feels warm on your skin. Alex seems to notice it as well.
steppingOutForADrink.node.3: Alex laughs, and drops a few coins in her hand, motioning for her to bring him a glass as well. Satisfied, the barmaid leaves.
steppingOutForADrink.node.2: "Is this seat taken?" Asks a voice from deep, familiar voice from behind you.
steppingOutForADrink.node.1: You see several people glance up at you when you enter, and are keenly aware of the implications of a woman entering such a place without an escort. steppingOutForADrink.node.0: Despite the availability of wine in your own house, you find yourself with powerful yearning for a change of scenery. With that, you take a walk to find a public house of decent repute.

steppingOutForADrink.link.63: "I merely wish to drink my wine without a bloodbath. Try to be civil, for me."

steppingOutForADrink.link.15: "Antoine, allow me to stay with you, for a while."
steppingOutForADrink.link.14: "Alex, I would love to join you for some cards. It's been too long since I last played."
steppingOutForADrink.link.13: "Gentlemen, this tension is overwhelming! Let's please just relax together, for a moment."

rumorMongers.node.20: But moments later, you're already free of them, and heading home to jot down some valuable notes. A successful day, all in all.
rumorMongers.node.18: The second you've gotten everything you need, you put up your hood and start to slink away. You can feel one of them glaring suspiciously at your back, but neither of the fools can prove a thing.
rumorMongers.node.17:
(You have acquired some cheap Military gossip)
(You have acquired some cheap Bourgeoisie gossip)
rumorMongers.node.16: The two of them continue to whisper back and forth, and your keen hearing manages to deduce all of the relevant details. This will be valuable indeed.
rumorMongers.node.15: "Well, I suppose that does make sense. I did learn something shocking about a prominent lawyer today..."
rumorMongers.node.14: Adopting your best, most vapid expression, you pretend to be utterly fascinated by some flowers blooming near them. The two of them pay you no mind as your approach and crouch low, listening to their exchange.
rumorMongers.node.13: Once he finishes up and separates from his companion, you approach the young rumor monger and offer him a similar exchange to the one he performed with his older compatriot.
rumorMongers.node.12: Once he finishes up and separates from his companion, you approach the old gossip catcher and offer him a similar exchange to the one he performed with his young compatriot.
rumorMongers.node.11: They lean in and start whispering to each other. Their voices are too low for you to hear from here.
rumorMongers.node.10: His new compatriot chuckles. "Are we? All we have to do is share our gossip between ourselves, then sell it all to different newspapers on the same day. We each make twice the money!"
rumorMongers.node.9: The older man puts out his hand, for the other one to stop. "What are you doing? Why, exactly would I share anything I've learned with you? We're competitors in this business."
rumorMongers.node.8: "Oh! Anything juicy lately?" The younger man leans in. "I myself, heard the most fascinating things about a certain General in the Military..."
rumorMongers.node.7: "Now I sell what I find to a far more reputable clientele."
rumorMongers.node.6: You would, of course, rush to Pierre's defense if all those vile accusations weren't so... true.
rumorMongers.node.5: "Ugh, yes! I used to sell gossip to that self-important drunk. After all, he used to be the only game in town. Frankly, I'm glad to be free of that slimy weasel."
rumorMongers.node.4: "I take it you used to work for Pierre Renaudot as well..."
rumorMongers.node.3: You break from your increasingly venomous internal accusations, when you hear a familiar name mentioned by someone nearby.
rumorMongers.node.2: Still, you have mountains of extenuating circumstances that have brought you to this point! What are their excuses? Have they no shame?
rumorMongers.node.1: You wonder to yourself if any of these idle malingerers have jobs, until your remember that you too share a similar, ill-earned but decadent lifestyle.
rumorMongers.node.0: During one of your explorations of the city, you find yourself in a fountain square. Groups of people are clustered together, locked in the kind of deep yet carefree conversations that make you wonder what, exactly, these people do all day.

necessaryHonesty.name: Necessary Honesty
necessaryHonesty.node.29: He departs, and you decide to leave as well, before it gets too dark.
necessaryHonesty.node.28: "Au revoir, madame." He says, before he packs up all of his materials, and drops some coins on the table for your respective refreshments.

(You have gotten a piece of Shocking Military Gossip)
(You have lost some credibility)

(You have gotten a piece of Shocking Revolution Gossip)

necessaryHonesty.node.25: The two of you talk for a little longer, but the conversation eventually winds down. He pauses to check his pocketwatch, and says "I'm sorry, but I must head to the Bastille. If I am to study it, I will need to do so before I lose the sunlight."
necessaryHonesty.node.23: He spends the next few minutes detailing some gossip concerning the military. It's certainly an interesting story, but something about the whole exchange feels rather untoward. Without the pretense of intrigue, it seems so heartless and mercantile.
necessaryHonesty.node.22: He spends the next few minutes detailing some gossip concerning the revolution. It's certainly an interesting story, but something about the whole exchange feels rather untoward. Without the pretense of intrigue, it seems so heartless and mercantile.
necessaryHonesty.node.21: Carefully, he sets aside his work and engages you in earnest. His full name is Christophe Von Mayendorf, and he's an architect visiting from Vienna. He's studying the oldest buildings in Paris, in order to learn techniques for designing structures that can withstand the tests of time, both physically and aesthetically.
necessaryHonesty.node.20: For the first time, he looks up at you from his document. "It seems that I've rudely misjudged you. My apologies."
necessaryHonesty.node.19: "As I suspected." He sighs. "Here's what I've learned."
necessaryHonesty.node.18: "As I suspected." He sighs. "Here's what I've learned."
necessaryHonesty.node.17: "To that end, would you prefer to learn something interesting about the military, or the revolution?"
necessaryHonesty.node.16:
"Judging from your interest in the affairs of strangers, I imagine you also have a thirst for gossip, yes?"

While this is true, you're not sure if he had to put it quite so cynically.
necessaryHonesty.node.15: (You have lost a level of exhaustion)
necessaryHonesty.node.14: When it arrives, you take a sip. It is coffee sweet, strong, and hot. It's also quite invigorating.
necessaryHonesty.node.13: Without taking his eyes off the document, he waves over a waitress and orders you some coffee.
necessaryHonesty.node.12:
He gestures to the chair across from him. "Please take a seat." 

You do so and settle in, finally feeling a little more comfortable in the situation.
necessaryHonesty.node.11: "Right now, I'm studying a four hundred year old church to determine why it hasn't fallen down, despite a complete lack of renovations in the last hundred years. The priest has insisted to me that this is a miracle, but I can't imagine the Lord using miracles to reward a century of shoddy maintenance."
necessaryHonesty.node.10: He chuckles. "While I'm afraid to inform you that I'm very busy at the moment, I suppose you can still join me."
necessaryHonesty.node.9: "Ah, so you want something from me." He says with half of a smile.
necessaryHonesty.node.8: "What business is it that you have here?"
necessaryHonesty.node.7: "Ah, bonjour, madame." He says without looking up. His accent is foreign, but you're unable to place it. It sounds either Austrian or Hungarian. "My name is Christophe, if that's what you were going to ask."
necessaryHonesty.node.6: You approach him, but he doesn't acknowledge you at first, and appears totally lost in this document. From the looks of it, it's some kind of diagram or blueprint, but the exact details are lost on you.
necessaryHonesty.node.5: You spot a man who has just taken a seat, by himself, at the table of a nearby cafe. He's spread out a great sheet of paper, and weighed down the corners with empty saucers.
necessaryHonesty.node.4: Curse the audacity of these strangers! How dare they have friends?
necessaryHonesty.node.3: You survey the area and everyone here already looks like they have someone to talk to, which is concerning. Approaching a stranger is easy, approaching a group of them by yourself is far more daunting.
necessaryHonesty.node.2: Perhaps you'll be able to find something that would bring you a little closer to finding out what happened to Armand.
necessaryHonesty.node.1: Perhaps you'll be able to find something that Pierre would find valuable.
necessaryHonesty.node.0: You decide to spend the day wandering the fountain square, as it's a warm day and plenty of people will be congregating there. Which usually means it's a good place for finding information.
necessaryHonesty.link.20: "Je suis désolé, but I'm simply not in the mood for gossip."
necessaryHonesty.link.19: "Really? Please tell me what you've learned about the revolution."
necessaryHonesty.link.18: "Merveilleux, tell me what you know about the military."
necessaryHonesty.link.11: "Indulging in curiosity. What are you doing?"
necessaryHonesty.link.10: "I have nobody else to talk to."
necessaryHonesty.link.9: "Well, I'm always looking to meet someone and learn something new."
payingRespects.name: Paying Respects
payingRespects.node.12: When you finally decide to head home, you're surprised by how late it's gotten. You must have lost track of time.
payingRespects.node.11: Perhaps Alex is watching over you now? He always was the protective sort.
payingRespects.node.9: Saying those words aloud grants you an vague sense of peace, like exhaling a breath that you'd been holding for too long. It was good that you came here. Burying such emotions might kill you faster than any of the other madness boiling inside this city.
payingRespects.node.8: Not knowing what else to say, you spend a while telling Alex about what's happened since he passed. The highs, and the lows. The amusing occurrences that you know he'd enjoy.
payingRespects.node.7: Not knowing what else to say, you spend a while cursing the circumstances that lead to this situation. It all feels so pointless and unfair.
payingRespects.node.6: Not knowing what else to say, you spend a while talking about how proud you are, and how you know Alex did the right thing. How it was awful that it happened, but that you know, if he were still alive, that he wouldn't hesitate to do it again.
payingRespects.node.5: You look upon the cold slab of stone, and try to think of something to say.
payingRespects.node.4: Walking up and down the rows, you find his grave, and are shocked by the mere sight of it. You knew that he was laid to rest here, but seeing the gravestone for yourself makes it feel real in a whole new way.
payingRespects.node.3: The article mentioned something about him wanting to be buried near his father.
payingRespects.node.2: It takes a moment for you to realize that you recognize the name of the graveyard from the newspaper. This is where Alex was laid to rest, after he was killed during the Réveillon riots. He was trying to keep everyone calm.
payingRespects.node.1: It's then that you spot a small graveyard. It's out of the way, and nothing about it is particularly distinct, but something still rings a bell inside your mind.
payingRespects.node.0: You leave your home to explore the streets of Paris, and find yourself drawn to this particular area of the city. It's hard to explain why, it just happens.
payingRespects.link.7: "It's good to see you again, I suppose."
payingRespects.link.6: "Why did you have to do it? Why did you have to be a hero?"
payingRespects.link.5: "You did the right thing, Alex. I'm proud of you."
navalArchitecture.name: Naval Architecture
navalArchitecture.node.28:
A few blocks later, you find yourself outside the stately building. It doesn't look nearly as nautical as you would imagine a naval office to be.

There should simply be a stronger nautical theme.
navalArchitecture.node.27: "Oh! My apologies, madame!" The man sputters as he collects himself. You're quite certain that you've met this man at a party before.
navalArchitecture.node.26: It doesn't work, and at least one adult falls in during the chase.
navalArchitecture.node.25: "The fortresses are leaking terribly, you see. We made them out of wood, which is apparently quite appetizing to all of the sea worms in the port. It was probably something that should have been looked into before we made them."
navalArchitecture.node.24: He departs inside, and you're left to your own devices. It's more than likely that you'll return to the fountain square to spend the rest of your day, to try to overcome the stifling heat.
navalArchitecture.node.22: "Thank you again for your help, madame!" He says with a deep bow. "If not for you, this entire journey would have been a complete waste."
navalArchitecture.node.21: With that, he disappears into the crowd, and you return to your day spent trying to overcome the stifling heat.

navalArchitecture.node.17: "It seems that I'll have to continue my efforts on my own."
navalArchitecture.node.16: Combining your knowledge of the city and his map, you manage to locate the naval office, and hurry towards it.

navalArchitecture.node.13: "Capital! Let us be off. Our mission begins anew!"
navalArchitecture.node.12: "Do you know where I can find the naval department?"
navalArchitecture.node.11: "I'm in a touch of a hurry, and I must have stopped paying attention to where I was going."
navalArchitecture.node.10: Without any hesitation, he pulls a handkerchief from his pocket, soaks it in the fountain, and presses the cold damp cloth to your forehead. You have to admit, it helps with the shock and heat at least.
navalArchitecture.node.9: He stops to check his pocketwatch, then sighs. "I'm supposed to be meeting with a draftsman to get the plans for the sunken fortresses at Cherbourg, but at this rate I'll miss my appointment at the naval department entirely."
navalArchitecture.node.8: "I had originally planned to orienteer my way across the city with my handy compass." He says, holding up a well polished brass compass, and a paper map of Paris. "However, that plan seems to have been less effective than I'd have hoped."
navalArchitecture.node.7: He straightens up and adjusts his disheveled spectacles. "You see, madame, I'm lost in the city and terribly late for a meeting. I normally work on the coast in La Rochelle, and this is my first time in Paris."
navalArchitecture.node.6: "Oh, that's the spirit!" He replies with an encouraging smile.
navalArchitecture.node.5: "Oh, I'm so sorry to hear that!"
navalArchitecture.node.3: "Oh! My apologies, madame!" The man sputters as he collects himself.
navalArchitecture.node.2: Your street theater is suddenly interrupted by a man hurtling around a corner and colliding with you. You manage to keep your balance, but are still a little disoriented.
navalArchitecture.node.1: At the moment, you're walking easy circles around the fountain, giggling to yourself at a pack of children playing in it. The situation becomes even more amusing when their parents notice, and desperately try to shepherd them out of it.
navalArchitecture.node.0: You decide to spend the day walking around in a fountain square, simply to cool off. It's sweltering outdoors, stifling indoors, and most people are just trying not to lose their tempers with each other. You swear you can see steam rising up from the fountain.
navalArchitecture.link.14: "I don't, but perhaps we can find someone who does know?"
navalArchitecture.link.12: "I know the city well enough, I can at least help you search for it."
navalArchitecture.link.5: "My word, what has you in such a hurry?"
navalArchitecture.link.4: "It was nothing. I'm sure I'll be fine."
navalArchitecture.link.3: "I'm afraid that I'm still a little shaken, monsieur."

providingForThePoor.node.6: "I have nothing but sympathy for my poor countrymen, it's you priests that I hate! You take our land, ignore our taxes, and build yourselves great churches of marble and gold. Then you have the audacity to ask us for money to help the poor."
