Looking at Alex, you feel like today went rather poorly.
Looking at Alex, you feel like today went by agreeably.
Looking at Alex, you feel like today went quite well.
Looking at Ludovico, you feel like today went rather poorly.
Looking at Ludovico, you feel like today went by agreeably.
Looking at Ludovico, you feel like today went quite well.
Looking at Élisabeth, you feel like today went rather poorly.
Looking at Élisabeth, you feel like today went by agreeably.
Looking at Élisabeth, you feel like today went quite well.
A few hours later, you realize that it's starting to get late, and the two of you depart together.

You practically have to drag him inside, but once you're there, he sits down with you. While he enjoys the food, you can see that he's mere moments away from starting a fight with someone, anyone in the restaurant.
It seems that Madame Gazel already knows the staff quite well, and they have a solid rapport. She orders for you, but the food that they give you is exquisite.
A few hours later, you realize that it's starting to get late, and the two of you depart together.
A few hours later, you realize that it's starting to get late, and the two of you depart together.

Your meal together tastes exceptional, and the two of you delve deeply into their extensive wine list. The clientele don't seem to know what to make of this elegant woman and the striking enlisted man with her, but they also leave the two of you alone.
A few hours later, you realize that it's starting to get late, and the two of you depart together.

Ludovico attends to his meal with gusto, and is always eager to share with you what's on his plate, in exchange for a sample of what's on your own. He says, multiple times, that this is the finest French food he's ever had.
A few hours later, you realize that it's starting to get late, and the two of you depart together.

The meal itself is more than you could have ever asked for, and at one point you have to excuse yourself in order to loosen your stays a little bit. However, you both get the feeling that you were being watched by the other patrons, which is simply invasive.
(You have lost a little favor with Antoine)

"La Grande Taverne de Londres." Antoine says, as if the name of the establishment were a curse. "The conservative leeches who frequent this place will get their due eventually. Is this the sort of thing that you like?"
(You have gained some favor with Madame Gazel)
"Oh, I absolutely adore this place." Madame Gazel says with a sigh. "The food is exquisite, the lavish decor is excellent, and you know how much I love being served."
(You have gained a little favor with Alex)

"I must admit that the atmosphere here is a little stuffy for my tastes, but if their reputation or the smells coming form the kitchen are anything to go by, the quality of their food can't be argued with."
(You have gained a little favor with Ludovico)
"I've heard of this place." Ludovico says nodding as he looks around. "Let's hope it lives up to it's lofty reputation!"
(You have gained a little favor with Élisabeth)
Élisabeth tilts her head back and smells the air. "I'm not sure how I feel about this place on the whole, but who am I to get the way of such excellent food?"
(You have lost a little favor with Antoine)
"Really? Did you think that this would please me?" He asks, as he looks you over before walking ahead.
(You have gained no favor with Antoine)
"You look good, but I think you already know that." He says offhandedly before walking ahead of you.
He looks around, and you're not really certain if he's examining the location, or looking for threats.
(You have gained quite a bit of favor with Antoine)
"You look ravishing, by the way." He says, quietly but firmly before walking ahead of you.
Turning her attention from you, she surveys your location.
(You have lost a little favor with Madame Gazel)
(You have gained no favor with Madame Gazel)
"Are you sure you can't do better than this, little Yvette?" She asks, examining you carefully.
"I'm glad you could make it." She says, eyes quickly flickering over you.
(You have gained quite a bit of favor with Madame Gazel)
"Oh, this is very pleasing." She says, looking at you through narrowed eyes as she slowly circles you like a panther. "You've done quite well."
He glances away from you, taking in your location.
(You have gained a decent amount of favor with Alex)
"It's great to see you!" He says, not even taking a second glance at your clothes. You are, once again, reminded that military men seem to have little interest in fashion.
Reluctantly taking his gaze off of you, he examines your location.
(You have gained quite a bit of favor with Ludovico)
(You have lost a little favor with Ludovico)
(You have gained no favor with Ludovico)
Looking away from you, she surveys your location.
(You have lost a little favor with Élisabeth)
(You have gained no favor with Élisabeth)
(You have gained quite a bit of favor with Élisabeth)
"Ah, I see." He says when he notices your outfit of choice.
"You look quite nice." Ludovico says, after a moment.
"I feel blessed to even look upon you." He says with a smile, and you catch his eyes lingering in a few choice places.
"Oh, is that what you're going to wear?" She asks quietly.
"You look nice." She says with a quick smile.
"You look absolutely stunning!" She gushes, as she looks you over, and you notice her empty hand idly sketching you in the air.
Antoine, tumultuous as ever, storms over to you shortly after you arrive. "So, you've made it. Shall we?"

Looking around, you see that Honorade arrived long before you did. Noticing you, she approaches and stands far closer than the rules of politeness might allow. You'd forgotten how good she is at looming over people.
Alex arrives exactly on time, and greets you with a precise bow and a broad smile. "Bonne après-midi, Yvette."

You return to the fine dining room and crystal chandeliers of La Grande Taverne de Londres. A few aristocrats glance up from their tables at you, and take your measure, before returning to their splendid food.

Ludovico arrives at the same time as yourself, and approaches you. He stands close, but with just enough distance to provide him with plausible deniability, should anyone become suspicious of you two.
A few minutes late, Élisabeth arrives. After taking a moment to carefully look around, she approaches you.
After spending the first half of the day getting ready, you head out for your rendezvous.
character.description.armandDeMarbo: You met your estranged fiancé Armand back when you were both living in a small village to the south. Currently representing the Second Estate as part of the Estates General, Armand is witty, politically active and quite sweet. However, his recent behavior has been odd, to say the least.
parismap.description.incidentSteppingOut: Yearning for a change of scenery, you decide to visit a public house of decent repute. There, you might encounter a certain soldier, and a revolutionary.
parismap.description.incidentAwaitingIns: A famous painter is looking for inspiration. Perhaps you can help her find it… perhaps you can help her find more than that?
parismap.description.missionBankAndMistr: Your tireless investigation of your hated foe, Viscountess Marcelle de Foix, has led you to a small and seemingly insignificant bank.
parismap.description.incidentImportAndEx: At the docks, a foreign alcohol importer of… dubious legality is looking for someone to help him move his wares. Preferably, they can be moved without interference from the Guet Royal.
parismap.description.missionHonoradesLea: Madame Gazel has invited you to meet her here, so that you might discuss what she’s learned while researching your hated foe, Baron Maximin de Termes.
parismap.description.incidentRumorMonger: It appears that you’re not the only person hunting for gossip in Paris. However, if you’re quick enough, you might be able to snatch some choice morsels from your competition.
parismap.description.missionTheSecondSit: The painter, Élisabeth, still has work to do on the nude portrait that she’s been painting of you. You head over for your second sitting, which is at her personal studio.
parismap.description.locationLaTrompette: A popular, if unscrupulous newspaper. Spend the day here to sell gossip, manipulate public opinion, and update your knowledge of the political factions in Paris.
parismap.description.incidentTheMaidAndT: Walking near the market, you come across your own maid of all works, who seems to be in a bit of trouble.
parismap.description.incidentSalaciousNo: You come across a fiery revolutionary who is in the process of trying to sell his latest, and most controversial, literary masterpiece.
parismap.description.missionTheForger: You head to La Place Royale, in order to meet with a mysterious ‘master of letters’ who has offered his services to you.
parismap.description.missionDirectAction: Dissatisfied with calls for moderation by his fellow revolutionaries, Antoine has invited you to join him in some ‘direct political action’ in a wealthy neighbourhood in Paris. If nothing else, it won’t be boring.
parismap.description.missionHonoradesClu: Madame Gazel has invited you to meet her here, so that you might discuss what she’s learned while researching your hated foe, Viscountess Marcelle de Foix.
parismap.description.missionAPaupersGrav: Your research into the mysterious fortune of your hated foe, Viscountess Marcelle de Foix, has led you here. A small cemetery, with a paltry grave. What could she be hiding?
parismap.description.incidentAManAboutTo: A chance wandering through La Place Royale brings you in contact with a good soldier, and some leftover business from his romantic past.
parismap.description.rendezvousLesGrands: The premiere theater in Paris, Les Grands-Danseurs du Roi is a rendezvous location known for its comedies, which tend to be coarse and proletarian, but always lively, and never boring.
parismap.description.incidentAStudyInChe: An unusual man of science has a proposition for you, and it has something to do with rumors in the city.
parismap.description.missionTheFinalSitt: The painter, Élisabeth, needs to see you at her personal studio so that she can finish the nude portrait that she’s been painting of you. She says there are some final touches that she needs to perform...
parismap.description.missionThePromisedP: The painter, Élisabeth, has finished the ‘family portrait’ of your hated foe, Baron Maximin de Termes. Spend the day reviewing it, and considering how you’ll be able to use it in order to exact your vengeance.
parismap.description.incidentAFabricShor: Due to a recent fabric shortage, it appears that a certain dressmaker you know might be in need of a favor. A favor that requires a little guile.
parismap.description.missionBenedictions: The intriguing priest, Father Ludovico Sidotti, has invited you to visit him when he’s holding mass at this church. Apparently, he’s hoping to establish a socially acceptable pretext for the two of you to be seen together more frequently.
parismap.description.incidentMusicToYour: Down by the water, you come across an unusual man of many talents. A chance conversation, that may hold the power to subtly alter the future.
parismap.description.missionBetrayingHon: If Armand’s plan is to succeed, a sacrifice will be required. In this case, it needs to be Honorade. Can you forge the letter necessary for this to come to fruition?
parismap.description.incidentTurnedAroun: Choosing to explore the city later in the evening, you happen to come across a certain widow, and a certain priest.
parismap.description.missionTyingUpLoose: The traitorous ‘master of letters’, Henri Vrain-Lucas, has extorted you for the last time! After hours, you head to his office in order to find some way to extract yourself from this terrible situation. You shall not be taken advantage of, not by anyone!
parismap.description.incidentPayingRespe: It’s been some time since Alex passed. However, it’s never too late to pay one’s respects.
parismap.description.incidentCoffeeRun: Marguerite, the waitress from Cafe Principe, appears to be having some sort of emergency. Perhaps you can be of assistance?
parismap.description.missionRequestingLe: You spend the day at home, thinking about what you should request from the Master Forger, Henri Vrain-Lucas. His services aren’t cheap, so you should make sure that you have the money to pay for them.
parismap.description.missionAssistingAnt: You rush over to Antoine’s abode, to check in on him. He claims that someone has attempted to poison him!
parismap.description.missionEmigre: With the specter of bloodshed quickly approaching, this is your last chance to flee Paris. Dare you leave behind what you’ve built, to seek new fortunes?
parismap.description.missionBetrayingLud: If Armand’s plan is to succeed, a sacrifice will be required. In this case, it needs to be Ludovico. Can you forge the letter necessary for this to come to fruition?
parismap.description.missionBetrayingEli: If Armand’s plan is to succeed, a sacrifice will be required. In this case, it needs to be Élisabeth. Can you forge the letter necessary for this to come to fruition?
parismap.description.incidentThePerilsOf: Pierre, your erstwhile employer, works in a field where one makes quite a few enemies. You just didn’t expect it to catch up with him, quite so quickly.
parismap.description.missionAlexsClue: Alex has invited you to meet him here, so that you might discuss what he’s learned while researching your hated foe, Viscountess Marcelle de Foix.
parismap.description.missionTheAscendant: Antoine has invited you out for dinner at Les Grande Tarvernes Londres. He claims that he has some momentous news he’d like to celebrate with you, but why would he want to do it at a restaurant that he despises?
parismap.description.locationCafePrincip: A coffee house frequented by philosophers, artists and academics. Get coffee, update your knowledge of the political factions in Paris, and speak your mind.
parismap.description.missionTheAbandoned: Courtsey of Pierre, you've learned about an art studio that Armand used to visit. Unfortunately, that studio was shut down, after being raided by the Guet Royal. This investigation may require some... discretion on your part.
parismap.description.missionLudovicoEpil: This is your last chance to see Ludovico before he returns to Rome. For now, your destiny may be out of your hands, but what really matters is how you make the most of it.
parismap.description.incidentFurnishings: You spot a certain wealthy widow making inquiries with a creator of bespoke furniture. What could she be up to?
parismap.description.missionLudovicosLea: Ludovico has invited you to meet him here, so that you might discuss what he’s learned while researching your hated foe, Baron Maximin de Termes.
parismap.description.missionBetrayingAnt: If Armand’s plan is to succeed, a sacrifice will be required. In this case, it needs to be Antoine. Can you forge the letter necessary for this to come to fruition?
parismap.description.missionAWishForDeli: At Antoine’s request, you travel to the infamous Château de Vincennes. There, you hope to be able to find a way to free the printmaker Monsieur Clet, a revolutionary sympathizer, who has been imprisoned there at the orders of the Crown.
parismap.description.missionResearchingA: After reading about a man that matches Armand’s description in a newspaper article, you head down to where he was last spotted. Hopefully, you’ll be able to find some clues in regards to his disappearance.
parismap.description.missionTheFirstSitt: The painter, Élisabeth, has requested that she be allowed to paint a portrait of you. You head over for your first sitting, which will be at her personal studio.
parismap.description.missionForeignEntan: Armand has requested your assistance with one the events he’s putting on with the mysterious Frankish Hapsburgian Society. For better or worse, this ‘Johanna’ woman may also be there.
parismap.description.rendezvousGuinguett: Out in the suburbs of Paris, Guingette Paradis is a rendezvous location that’s the perfect spot for drinking, dancing, and cabaret entertainments.
parismap.description.missionTheMasterOfL: You spend the day at home, thinking about what you should request from the Master Forger, Henri Vrain-Lucas. His services aren’t cheap, so you should make sure that you have the money to pay for them.
parismap.description.missionStraightToTh: Without many leads in your investigation looking into a dreadful attempted poisoning, you head to the market, Les Halles. However, even if you do find the culprit, what could have possibly motivated them to attempt such a heinous crime?
parismap.description.rendezvousJardinDes: Relax and promenade with your liaison in this rendezvous location. These popular gardens are the ideal place to unwind, and engage in a little people watching.
parismap.description.incidentBalanceOfPo: There appears to be some disagreement between members of Le Guet Royal and the military as to who has true authority in the streets of Paris.
parismap.description.rendezvousParcMonce: Created by the infamous libertine, Louis Philippe d'Orléans, this rendezvous location is a bustling garden filled with strange, adventurous, and exotic attractions.
parismap.description.incidentStudyingClo: On your latest walk exploring the city, you come across an artist preparing for their latest commission. You might also encounter a certain priest.
parismap.description.missionLudovicosClu: Ludovico has invited you to meet him here, so that you might discuss what he’s learned while researching your hated foe, Viscountess Marcelle de Foix.
parismap.description.incidentAHessianDoo: Exploring a more dangerous part of the city carries some risks, but some of the violent types you might meet could also be useful, or even employable.
parismap.description.missionResearchingM: You head to La Place Royale, hoping to track down some information in regards to the mysterious fortune of your hated foe, the Viscountess Marcelle de Foix.
parismap.description.incidentNavalArchit: A bespectacled traveler with an important appointment to keep is facing some navigational woes. Can you help him find his way?
parismap.description.missionTheMistressO: Madame Gazel has invited you to visit her at her home, a rare and enticing opportunity. The city may be in tumult, but that makes her commands no easier to disobey.
parismap.description.incidentAppointment: You happen to cross paths again with a foreign alcohol importer of… dubious legality. Here, past actions are accounted for, appropriately.
parismap.description.incidentArtisticLic: You run across a famous painter, trying to prevent a past legal matter from troubling her present, or her future.
parismap.description.missionAlexsLead: Alex has invited you to meet him here, so that you might discuss what he’s learned while researching your hated foe, Baron Maximin de Termes.
parismap.description.missionTheValueOfDi: Your previous misadventure at the Caisse de Confiance, the bank used by Viscountess Marcelle de Foix, may have gone poorly, but that doesn’t mean you can’t try again. It’s really just a matter of bribing the right people.
parismap.description.missionBetrayingAle: If Armand’s plan is to succeed, a sacrifice will be required. In this case, it needs to be Alex. Can you forge the letter necessary for this to come to fruition?
parismap.description.missionStrangerAndS: You spend the day at home, investigating the mysterious notice and key that you recovered from the abandoned studio. Hopefully the risks you took to break in there were worth it.
parismap.description.missionTheirOwnMedi: You find your way to the home of the strange ‘Monsieur Toiry’, who you believe to be connected to the attempted poisoning that you’ve been investigating. How do you plan on putting a stop to all of this?
parismap.description.missionArmandsPurpo: You’ve finally found your fiancé, Armand, and he’s invited you to visit him in his new abode. He claims that he’ll be able to explain his mysterious disappearance, and what he’s been doing, all of this time.
parismap.description.locationLaPlaceRoya: A great square where the rich and powerful socialize. Here, you’ll spend the day trawling for gossip.
parismap.description.missionResearchingM: You head to Les Halles, hoping to track down some information in regards to a mysterious servant who suddenly and quietly left the employ of your hated foe, Baron Maximin de Termes.
parismap.description.incidentNecessaryHo: Not everyone visiting Paris has the wry subtlety that you’ve grown used to. Some are far more blunt. However, that’s not always a bad thing.
parismap.description.rendezvousLaGrandeT: A luxurious restaurant, this rendezvous location caters to some of the wealthiest and most powerful clientele in all of Paris. It also serves some of the finest food in the city. Try the lamb!
parismap.description.missionForeignPower: After nightfall, you join Armand at his home on the other side of Paris. He’s promised you a surprise of some sort.
parismap.description.locationLePetitMogo: A small shop run by the dressmaker Fatima Shenna. Spend your day here to buy and sell wardrobe items.
parismap.description.incidentProvidingFo: A lovesick priest you might know is trying to raise money for the less fortunate. However, that is proving to be much harder than it sounds.
parismap.description.missionThisIsGoodby: You hurry over to the watch post for your last chance to see Armand. They say that he’ll be executed for high treason soon. Is it possible to find answers, in such a brief moment of time? Is it possible to find closure?
parismap.description.missionClandestineM: Ludovico has invited you to meet him at the abbey where he’s been staying, while all of the other priests are out of town for business of some sort. It would be very nice to take advantage of… his hospitality.
parismap.description.incidentTeaAndTalki: On this particularly sweltering day, you decide to spend some time cooling down near a fountain. There, you might come across a certain artist, and a certain soldier.
parismap.description.locationHome: Spend the day resting at home. This will remove all levels of exhaustion, if you have any.
parismap.description.missionLegacy: Alex has requested your help with something, but you’re not really sure what it is. Why would he need your help at a cemetery?
parismap.description.incidentFishyBusine: Down by the docks, you run into a certain soldier and widow. They might serve as agreeable company to spend the day with.
parismap.description.missionAssistingEli: You rush over to Elisabeth’s studio, to check in on her. She claims that someone has attempted to poison her!
parismap.description.incidentMinionsAndM: You come across the hirelings of one of your earliest enemies… but what are they up to?
concerningCorrespondance.name: Concerning Correspondence
concerningCorrespondance.description: You take some time to go over distant memories of the letters Armand used to send you while you were still in the village. In retrospect, some of those missives may have been more concerning than you thought.
concerningCorrespondance.node.17: 'Individuals like that cannot be allowed to steer the fate of our people. If we are presented with two bad options, then we must force a third.'
concerningCorrespondance.node.16: 'Our leader'. You had puzzled this over before. Who was this woman that Armand was referencing in his letter? Was this perhaps that Johanna person you've met recently?
concerningCorrespondance.node.15: With that ambivalent assessment, you decide to engage with the world around you once more.The memory drifts away like the waning moments of a dream. Hopefully, you can accomplish something at this party before the night is over.
concerningCorrespondance.node.14: With this dour assessment, you decide to engage with the world around you once more. The memory drifts away like the waning moments of a dream. Hopefully, you can still accomplish something at this party before the night is over.
concerningCorrespondance.node.13: With this positive assessment, you decide to engage with the world around you once more. The memory drifts away like the waning moments of a dream. Hopefully, you can accomplish something at this party before the night is over.
concerningCorrespondance.node.12: Still, what to make of these revelations?
concerningCorrespondance.node.11:
(You have lost a little peril)
(You have gained a little credibility)
concerningCorrespondance.node.10: Reconsidering these memories in a new light is unpleasant, but also grounding. You feel a little more prepared for whatever comes next.
concerningCorrespondance.node.9: 'All I can be certain of is that we're racing against an unseen clock. To put it simply, the people of France are hungry, and hungry people do not remain hungry for long.'
concerningCorrespondance.node.8: 'I know I've said it before but I really wish you were here. I know there are things I'm not seeing, things that you would notice instantly.'
concerningCorrespondance.node.7: 'Of course, in the name of building coalitions I've had to partake in the company of several extremely unpleasant individuals. It's perhaps the only reason I'm glad you're not here, as I would hate to inflict their judgmental presence upon you. Even when I finally travel home from the interminable dinners at their grand estates, I still feel like I'm being watched.'
concerningCorrespondance.node.6: 'To put it simply, it feels like France is a ship hurtling towards a rocky shore, and nobody is at the wheel. This awareness of imminent catastrophe is the main unifying thread that binds our little group together. Our leader is the only one who isn't worried. She works feverishly, but betrays no signs of fear. I think you would like her immensely. You two share a lot in common.'
concerningCorrespondance.node.5: 'Whenever I find myself engaging with persons other than my sponsors, I find myself exasperated. So many powerful people calmly discussing the state of the nation as if it were a tennis match; as though there are only two possible victors, yet the outcome had no real meaning.'
concerningCorrespondance.node.4: Warning signs like that gentleman named Charles, who had accosted the two of you during your last night with Armand.
concerningCorrespondance.node.3: ‘Chère Yvette, My heart aches to see you with an ever growing ardor that I'm scarcely able to control. I may be surrounded by companions here, but without you I feel alone.'
concerningCorrespondance.node.2: In retrospect, his letters had been growing stranger for quite some time, but it's much easier to notice such warning signs long after the point where they would have been useful. Dwelling on such failures has never helped anyone.
concerningCorrespondance.node.1: It was after Armand had left for the Estates General, but you yourself had yet to leave for Paris. Instead, you walked around in the cold, reading his letter over and over again. This particular one had been puzzling you for a while.
concerningCorrespondance.node.0: You step away from the crowds at the party to take a moment to be alone. A memory you had not considered for a while flashes through your mind. You're back in your provincial hometown.
concerningCorrespondance.link.13: "It's easy to jump to conclusions, but I simply don't know enough right now."
concerningCorrespondance.link.12: "The more I think about this, the worse it all gets. I am in a den of vipers."
concerningCorrespondance.link.11: "I trust Armand, and I trust that something good can still come of this."
theInterview.name: The Interview
theInterview.description: You come across a woman interviewing a man for the sake of her book, but something doesn’t seem quite right about the man’s outrageous claims.
theInterview.node.52: "Merci beaucoup for your assistance, Yvette. I couldn't possibly have done this without your help."
theInterview.node.51: After your collective font of outrageous lies finally runs dry, Nika leaves, satisfied with her 'research', and Maurice returns to whatever was preoccupying him earlier.
theInterview.node.50: Maurice then launches into a lengthy soliloquy concerning the attire and beauty of those native to the northern Americas. It's so effusive and detailed that even you start to forget that none of this ever happened. Madame Eikov is paying rapt attention to your tailor, writing so furiously that you're afraid that her notes might burst into flames.
theInterview.node.49: Maurice steps in, the wheels of his vivid imagination already turning. "Ah yes, but of course! It was a fine evening of visual delight. I had loyally followed Madame Decaux to the festivities, as I was searching for sartorial inspiration among the Algonquians' unique configurations of paints, buckskins and expert beadwork."
theInterview.node.48: Barely concealing a smile, Monsieur de Sable steps back to admit Maurice into the circle of the conversation.
theInterview.node.47: With that, he leaves, and you decide to examine the rest of the party. Perhaps you'll find another opportunity out there, amongst the crowds.
theInterview.node.46: "Well, I'm off to seek other entertainments. Au revoir, madame." He says with a overly elaborate bow.
theInterview.node.45: (You have gained a piece of Outrageous Bourgeoisie gossip)
theInterview.node.44: (You have gained a piece of Shocking Bourgeoisie gossip)
theInterview.node.43: (You have gained a piece of Cheap Bourgeoisie gossip)
theInterview.node.42: This also means that you have some decent gossip, given that you just caught a prominent figure in the Bourgeoisie flagrantly lying about his accomplishments. However, Guillaume doesn't necessarily need to know that.
theInterview.node.40: Of course, eventually you realize that you and Guillaume have truly stretched the limits of believability here.
theInterview.node.39: With that, she leaves, and you decide to examine the rest of the party. Perhaps you'll find another opportunity out there, amongst the crowds.
theInterview.node.38: "Merci beaucoup for your assistance, Yvette. I couldn't possibly have done this without your help."
theInterview.node.37: It becomes apparent, via your spying, that the woman interviewing Guillaume is a foreign author named Nika Eikov. She's looking for inspiration for her latest novel, which mostly seems to concern itself with mysteries, thefts, and courtly intrigues.
theInterview.node.36: It becomes apparent, via your spying, that the man she's interviewing is Guillaume de Sablé, the self-styled 'libertine philosopher'... an appellation that doesn't seem to require much in the way of academic credentials.
theInterview.node.35: It becomes apparent, via your spying that these people are Nika Eikov, a foreign author looking for inspiration for her latest novel, as well as Guillaume de Sablé, a self-styled 'libertine philosopher'... an appellation that doesn't seem to require much in the way of academic credentials.
theInterview.node.34: After your font of outrageous lies finally runs dry, Nika leaves, satisfied with her 'research'.
theInterview.node.33: You could consider feeling bad for leading the poor woman astray, but that feeling easily slips away. After all, history is just truth that slowly becomes lies, and stories are just lies that slowly become truth.
theInterview.node.32: Unsure of what to do next, you and Guillaume start fabricating outlandish tales of his exploits, of which you were party to many. At some point in time in the tales, both you and Guillaume have apparently had torrid affairs with lusty pirates of the Barbary Coast, perhaps on the same vessel. Nika's writing only seems to grow faster and more intense.
theInterview.node.31: With a shrug, he leaves as well. You take this time to examine the rest of the party. Perhaps you'll find another opportunity out there, amongst the crowds.
theInterview.node.30: "... and here, I just thought we were having fun." Guillaume comments drily, taking a noisy sip of his wine.
theInterview.node.29: Angrily throwing up her hands, she storms away. You and Guillaume are left to stare at each other in silence.
theInterview.node.28: (You have lost quite a bit of credibility)
theInterview.node.26: "Ah... well, we met at a banquet... held by a visiting Algonquian prince!"
theInterview.node.25: "Oh, this will be fantastic for my book, monsieur! I must ask, how did you and Monsieur Beaumarchais meet?"
theInterview.node.24: After a few shocked seconds, Madame Eikov gives you a slow curtsey. "Merci, madame. I know it may seem unimportant to most, but my research for this novel is very important to me. I appreciate you care enough to stop someone from filling it with outlandish falsehoods."
theInterview.node.23: You decide to examine the rest of the party. Perhaps you'll find another opportunity out there, amongst the crowds.
theInterview.node.22: You utter a few un-ladylike curses to yourself under your breath as you realize that this detour has already cost you precious time here.
theInterview.node.21: (You have gained a piece of Outrageous Bourgeoisie gossip)
theInterview.node.20: (You have gained a piece of Shocking Bourgeoisie gossip)
theInterview.node.19: (You have gained a piece of Cheap Bourgeoisie gossip)
theInterview.node.18: Monsieur de Sablé drains his wineglass and storms away with a sour look on his face. While that might seem unpleasant, it also means that you have some decent gossip, given that you caught a prominent figure in the Bourgeoisie flagrantly lying about his accomplishments
theInterview.node.17: "You're simply no fun at all, madame." He continues, shaking his head in disgust. "I shall find my entertainments elsewhere, then."
theInterview.node.15: From what you remember of that play, that's not something to be particularly proud of. It also doesn't sound... even vaguely true.
theInterview.node.14: You recognize neither the bespectacled woman, nor the extravagantly dressed gentleman that she's speaking with. However, judging from the fact that she pauses to write whenever he speaks, you can surmise that she's interviewing him.
theInterview.node.13: "No... no, that can't be right!" She dismisses your ploy with a shake of her head. "I'm just surrounded by liars!"
theInterview.node.12: "That's amazing! Please, you have to tell me more." She continues, furiously writing more notes.
theInterview.node.11: You quickly slink away before either of them have the chance to drag you into their slowly unravelling web of lies. In war and in parties, discretion is sometimes the better part of valor.
theInterview.node.10: "Curses!" Guillaume says with a sneer, shooting you a nasty look.
theInterview.node.8: Guillaume glances to you and raises an eyebrow. He knows his game is almost up.
theInterview.node.7: "I'm sorry, did you say an Algonquian prince? He came across the ocean from the Americas and then held a banquet?" The author replies, far more suspicious of this particular claim.
theInterview.node.6: "I am no mere tight-fisted patron, good madame. I am an inspiration, a muse if you will. In fact, when Beaumarchais wrote 'The Barber of Seville', I was his inspiration for Count Almaviva!" The sharply dressed man proudly replies between long gulps of wine.
theInterview.node.5: "You described yourself earlier as a patron of the arts. What is your relationship with theater? Have you sponsored any performances?"
theInterview.node.4: You don't recognize the bespectacled woman, but you do recognize Guillaume de Sablé, the self-styled 'libertine philosopher'... an appellation that doesn't seem to require much in the way of academic credentials. Judging from the fact that she pauses to write whenever he speaks, you can surmise that she's interviewing him.
theInterview.node.3: You recognize the woman as Nika Eikov, the foreign author looking for inspiration for her latest novel, but you don't recognize the extravagantly dressed gentleman that she's speaking with. However, judging from the fact that she pauses to write whenever he speaks, you can surmise that she's interviewing him.
theInterview.node.2: You recognize these people as Nika Eikov, the foreign author looking for inspiration for her latest novel, as well as Guillaume de Sablé, the self-styled 'libertine philosopher'... an appellation that doesn't seem to require much in the way of academic credentials. Judging from the fact that she pauses to write whenever he speaks, you can surmise that she's interviewing him.
theInterview.node.1: It's then that you see two individuals speaking together in a corner. The fact that they're trying to stay away from everyone else only increases your interest in their conversation.
theInterview.node.0: You step back into the vestibule for a moment, so you can collect your thoughts, and get the first opportunity to speak with any new arrivals to the party.
theInterview.link.54: "Not only was I there with him, so was my tailor Maurice, who can attest to splendor of the evening."
theInterview.link.9: "I know far too much to take a side in whatever this business is."
theInterview.link.8: "Madame Eikov, it sounds unlikely because it never happened. This is just a fable."
theInterview.link.7: "I know it sounds outrageous, but he's serious about that banquet. I, myself was there."
wingsAndWomen.name: Wings and Women
wingsAndWomen.description: The chemistry student, Michael Pelletier, is in need of someone to help him gain the attention of a comely young lady. Are you up to the task?
wingsAndWomen.node.41: All in all, this feels like it was a productive use of your time.
wingsAndWomen.node.40: (You have gained a piece of Outrageous Military Gossip)
wingsAndWomen.node.39: (You have gained a piece of Shocking Military Gossip)
wingsAndWomen.node.38: (You have gained a piece of Cheap Military Gossip)
wingsAndWomen.node.37: On it, you find some gossip related to the host of this party, presumably as 'payment' for your services here.
wingsAndWomen.node.36: Now that you're alone, you realize that you feel an unfamiliar shape in the pockets of your dress. You check and realize that Michael seems to have slipped you a note at some point without you knowing it.
wingsAndWomen.node.35: Still, you don't want to be rude so you humor him for just as long as is necessary, before you also take your leave.
wingsAndWomen.node.34: Oblivious, the boorish gentleman attempts to turn his attentions on you. You manage to deflect his clumsy advances with relative ease.
wingsAndWomen.node.33: It's not long before she excuses herself from the conversation to read this note...
wingsAndWomen.node.31: ...where you watch her bump into Michael, who 'just happened' to be walking in the same area. As their conversation begins together, you notice the young student shoot you a grateful wink before he and the object of his affections disappear into the crowd.
wingsAndWomen.node.30: She turns and leaves from your group at high speed, before anyone can attempt to make her stay...
wingsAndWomen.node.29: Of course, your sudden entry into the conversation does generate some suspicion on its own.
wingsAndWomen.node.28: As Michael leaves, you are forced to dwell on how this undertaking has cost you valuable time. Hopefully, you'll be able to find some other way to gain something useful at this party.
wingsAndWomen.node.27: As you watch them leave, you lock eyes with Michael, who has been observing the proceedings. He gives nothing more than a shrug. Such is life. Such is love.
wingsAndWomen.node.26: Confused by your behavior, they take their leave. You do your best not to curse loud enough that the other guests will hear you.
wingsAndWomen.node.25:
(You have lost a decent amount of credibility)
(You have gained a little peril)
wingsAndWomen.node.24: "A secret message, madame?" The man surmises, as he nudges the rolled-up paper with his shoe. "For what reason are you passing such missives to people you don't even know?"
wingsAndWomen.node.23: "Yes... you've brought up many things that would make my success impossible." The musician says, with a barely concealed sigh.
wingsAndWomen.node.22: However, stealthily passing a note to someone who isn't aware that they will be receiving such a note proves to be much harder to do than it seems. You fumble the rolled-up piece of paper, and drop it on ground. It quietly lands in the middle of your circle.
wingsAndWomen.node.21: Stealthily, you manage to press the message into the woman's hand, and she quickly stows the message in the pockets of her dress. The conversation doesn't even slow down for a moment.
wingsAndWomen.node.19: "Really? This is outrageous." The budding harpsichordist says at this blatant shift of romantic intent. However, you notice that this admonishment comes with only a token amount of anger and disgust. This is merely the perfect excuse for her to leave the conversation.
wingsAndWomen.node.17: With your nervousness calmed to a mere dull roar, you approach these would-be lovers in the middle of conversation. The lady immediately makes room for you in the conversation. "Oh, bonjour madame. Please, come join us! I was just relating how I've been learning to play the harpsichord. I'm hoping to be part of a recital by the end of the year."
wingsAndWomen.node.16: With this in mind, you take your leave of him and begin the process of steeling yourself while you walk over to the couple that he indicated. It seems that no matter how experienced you become, there's something disquieting about the prospect of approaching a group of strangers, alone and unintroduced.
wingsAndWomen.node.15: "I would accompany you myself, but I think my rival is a little too canny for that." Michael says, handing you a small, rolled-up piece of paper tied with a little bow. A message between potential lovers. "Give her this, if you can."
wingsAndWomen.node.14: "It's still a work in progress," he replies with a mysterious smile. "However, my progress has been waylaid by other... worldly pursuits." You notice that Michael is looking at something over your shoulder. Something, or someone.
wingsAndWomen.node.13: "Worry not. I've not been particularly productive myself." He says as he glances at something over your shoulder. "After all, one can always study when they're older."
wingsAndWomen.node.12: "Well, it's certainly better than being bored." He quips, before his attention becomes fixed on something over your shoulder. "Life is meant for living, is it not?"
wingsAndWomen.node.11: Unfortunately, this undertaking has cost you valuable time. Hopefully, you'll be able to find some other way to gain something useful at this party.
wingsAndWomen.node.9: "Well, I'm very excited to hear that madame!" He replies, a little too enthusiastically while he looks you up and down.
wingsAndWomen.node.8: You step closer to the budding harpsichordist and try to discreetly pass her the note that Michael gave you.
wingsAndWomen.node.7: You can tell that she wants to leave this conversation, but doesn't yet have a way out.
wingsAndWomen.node.6: You step into the circle of their conversation, and the man says "I was just telling her what pieces she should watch out for in her recital, as they might prove to be too difficult for a novice."
wingsAndWomen.node.5: You excuse yourself before Michael can get a chance to sway you to whatever this latest plan is. If he wants to win someone's heart, he can do it himself. You don't need such damage to your reputation.
wingsAndWomen.node.4: "Fantastique! I need you to go forth and separate the two people over there." He continues, subtly indicating towards a young couple talking together in a different tent. "Once the lovely madame is on her own, I shall have the chance to make my affections known."
wingsAndWomen.node.3: "More specifically, my scientific studies have been waylaid by my romantic ones. Unfortunately, the woman I've set my heart upon is already being courted by a jealous and tiresome fellow. It's a situation that has put me at my wit's end."
wingsAndWomen.node.2: "In fact, I could very much use your assistance, if you were so willing?"
wingsAndWomen.node.1: "Bonjour, Yvette!' Michael says as you approach. "What have you been up to?"
wingsAndWomen.node.0: As you stroll through the party, you spot a vaguely familiar figure. You remember meeting him in the streets of Paris, not that long ago. He gave you a piece of gossip as part of some kind of 'experiment'.
wingsAndWomen.link.10: "How did that strange experiment of yours turn out?"
wingsAndWomen.link.9: "I wish it wasn't the case, but I've simply been up to very little."
wingsAndWomen.link.8: "I've been up to... a lot. To be honest, I've never been so busy in all my life."
wingsAndWomen.link.5: "Monsieur, when I overheard your wise counsel, I just had to see you up close for myself."
wingsAndWomen.link.3: "I'd rather not be part of any more of these schemes of yours. Good luck, Michael."
wingsAndWomen.link.2: "Just lead me to your problem, and I shall handle the rest."
peckingOrder.name: Pecking Order
peckingOrder.description: A composer of some considerable ability is eager to get a chance to speak with the Chevalier de St. Georges, but there appears to be quite the line. Perhaps you can help him with this problem?
peckingOrder.node.37: With that, he leaves you to your own devices. Hopefully you can find some way to repair your reputation after that debacle.
peckingOrder.node.36: "I'm sorry Madame Decaux, but I must come up with a new plan."
peckingOrder.node.35: "To the devil with him." Angelos mumbles to himself. "Now I'll never meet the Chevalier de St. Georges!"
peckingOrder.node.34: Angelos maintains a carefully neutral expression, while the two of you slink away from the room to somewhere quieter and less scornful.
peckingOrder.node.33: "Of course not!" Angelos laughs nervously. "My dear friend is just very punctilious. It's one of her many virtues."
peckingOrder.node.31: "You have business with the Chevalier... and you really needed this woman to speak up for you?" The gentleman narrows his eyes.
peckingOrder.node.30: The gentleman steps aside and Angelos goes on ahead. You ask a passing servant for some more wine, and decide to relax by yourself until his 'meeting' is complete.
peckingOrder.node.29: The gentleman interrogating you rubs his chin thoughtfully. "It is true that wasting someone's time is the highest form of disrespect. I also have no reason to doubt your character. Very well."
peckingOrder.node.28: Angelos leaves, and your reputation remains intact. Unfortunately, all of this has still cost you precious time.
peckingOrder.node.26: This seems to have gone quite well.
peckingOrder.node.25: You chat with Angelos for only a moment longer, otherwise there's a good chance that someone seeing the two of you together might catch onto your ruse.
peckingOrder.node.24: (You have gained an piece of Outrageous Crown Gossip)
peckingOrder.node.23: (You have gained a piece of Shocking Crown Gossip)
peckingOrder.node.22: "Of course, I didn't forget the payment that I owe you." He says in a low voice and begins to describe the latest intrigues that he's heard, concerning the aristocracy at Versailles.
peckingOrder.node.21: Angelos finds you a short time later, a great grin plastered on his face. "Ah, you've truly outdone yourself Madame Decaux. My meeting with the Chevalier de St. Georges went so well that we actually plan on meeting for dinner tomorrow night!"
peckingOrder.node.20: Eventually, you manage to find a lull that gives you sufficient opportunity to smoothly extract yourself from the conversation. With some gracious thanks, you leave your two erstwhile caretakers behind.
peckingOrder.node.19: To ensure that Angelos has enough time to finish his meeting, you make sure to exaggerate the symptoms of your sudden fainting spell. Some of the men mutter sagely to themselves about your 'delicate constitution', nodding their heads as if they were a team of expert physicians agreeing on a diagnosis.
peckingOrder.node.18:
(You have lost a large amount of credibility)
(You have gained some peril)
peckingOrder.node.17: When you fully regain your wits, you find yourself being helped to a couch by two gentlemen desperately asking you if they can get you anything. If nothing else, you could get used to this part of things.
peckingOrder.node.16: (You have gained quite a bit of peril)
peckingOrder.node.15: On second thought... you might be the victim of your own success in this endeavor. Now that you're lying on the ground, you genuinely feel quite light-headed.
peckingOrder.node.14: Just as your vision begins to grow unclear, you pretend to faint, and fall to the ground in front of the highest ranking people in the room. Your sudden collapse causes no small amount of shock.
peckingOrder.node.13: With your clothing settled and everything prepared, you walk back into the crowded room and begin to increase the pace of your breathing. Normally, your stays are quite comfortable, but now you can really feel the effect they have on restricting your breathing.
peckingOrder.node.12: "My name is Angelos Strassner. I'm a composer and mathematician, which is what makes me so excited to meet the man."
peckingOrder.node.11: You glance around and Angelos certainly isn't wrong. You recognize a few guests in the area that come from extremely powerful lineages. Simply put, they're not people one can simply barge ahead of, without dangerous consequences.
peckingOrder.node.10: "I know one thing for certain, it's that nobody here is taking appointments." He continues, his voice enraged and imperious. You feel the eyes of many important and scandalized men staring at you.
peckingOrder.node.9: "Madame Decaux is correct, monsieur." Angelos chimes in, introducing himself by way of a simple bow. "Normally, I'd hate to interrupt such honorable gentleman, but I simply must not keep a man of Chevalier de St. George's stature waiting."
peckingOrder.node.8: "I see..." Angelos says, shaking his head. He can be as displeased as he likes, it's simply too risky to lie to those people. "I suppose that makes you more honorable than myself."
peckingOrder.node.7: With that said, you excuse yourself to an empty room. There, you undo a few ties on your dress so that you can tighten your stays a little bit. This will help you sell the effect of what comes next.
peckingOrder.node.6: "I'm sorry, you have a what?" Asks a gentleman, regarding you with suspicion.
peckingOrder.node.5: "I know that you hunt for gossip, and if you help me... I might have something for you."
peckingOrder.node.4: His voice drops low and he gestures to the expensively dressed gentlemen in the room. "However, as you can imagine, there's a significant waiting period to speak with him. Nothing so gauche as an official list, but you know how people of rank are... these strutting peacocks are quite attached to their established pecking order."
peckingOrder.node.3: "He's an accomplished composer, a well regarded poly-math, and even a master fencer! There's really nothing the man can't do. It's no wonder that Her Majesty refers to the man as 'Her favorite American'."
peckingOrder.node.2: "Ah, my apologies, madame! Are you here to see the Chevalier de St. Georges as well?"
peckingOrder.node.1: "It's good to see you again, Madame Yvette!" Angelos says, as he looks you over to make sure that you're alright. "Are you here to see the Chevalier de St. Georges as well?"
peckingOrder.node.0: You enter a crowded room and nearly bump into a man who is dressed in far more sober colors than most of the gentlemen at this party.
peckingOrder.link.5: "I'm sorry, but some gossip isn't worth the wrath of that many powerful men."
peckingOrder.link.4: "Allow me but a moment, and I'll create a distraction. Then you can make your move."
peckingOrder.link.3: "Pardon me monsieurs, but my friend already has an appointment with the Chevalier."
party.description.theOrphansFeast: The Orphan's Feast is a small social gathering spot for people of every class of society, though almost everyone who comes here does so alone.
party.description.maximinDeTermesPrivate: Maximin de Termes' Private Salon is a humble salon concerning the ills plaguing our great nation. We hope you shall remember this event for years to come!
party.invitation.maximinDeTermesPrivateS: Requests the attendance of Citizen Armand de Marbo, on 22 Mars 1789, to a salon concerning the ills plaguing our nation. We hope you'll remember this event for years to come!
party.description.marcelleDeFoixsExclusi: Viscountess Marcelle de Foix's Private Gathering is an intimate gathering of her most loyal peers, for fine entertainment and elegant merriment. You are most eagerly awaited!
party.invitation.marcelleDeFoixsExclusiv: Requests the attendance of Baron Armand de Marbo, on 22 Mars 1789, to a gathering of her most loyal peers, for entertainment and merriment. You are most eagerly awaited!
party.description.mmeReveillonsTrivialWi: Mme. Reveillon's Intimate Wine Tasting is sure to be the very height of merry merriment.
party.invitation.mmeReveillonsTrivialWin: Requests the attendance of Madame Yvette Decaux to her Wine Tasting on 29 Mars 1789. This intimate party is sure to be the very height of merry merriment.
party.description.mmeBaillysTrivialSalon: Mme. Bailly's Intimate Poetry Salon is sure to be the purest form of effervescent celebration.
party.invitation.mmeBaillysTrivialSalon: Requests the attendance of the infamous Madame Yvette Decaux to her Poetry Salon on 3 Avril 1789. This intimate party is sure to be the purest form of effervescent celebration.
party.description.mMariottesTrivialChoir: M. Mariotte's Intimate Choir Recital is sure to be the very height of cheerful gaiety.
party.invitation.mMariottesTrivialChoirR: Requests the attendance of Madame Yvette Decaux, to his Choir Recital on 26 Mars, 1789. This intimate party is sure to be the very height of cheerful gaiety.
party.description.mDeLaunaysTrivialMilit: M. de Launay's Intimate Military Ball is sure to be the very height of merry celebration.
party.invitation.mDeLaunaysTrivialMilita: Requests the attendance of Madame Yvette Decaux to his Military Ball on 5 Avril 1789. This intimate party is sure to be the very height of merry celebration.
party.description.mDeBoulainvilliersTriv: The Duc d'Harcout's Intimate Opera Galla is sure to be a most spectacular display of generous amusement.
party.invitation.mDeBoulainvilliersTrivi: Requests the attendance of the fascinating Madame Yvette Decaux to his Opera Gala on 3 Avril 1789. This intimate party is sure to be a most spectacular display of generous amusement.

payingYourDue17.node.8: Camille leaves to deliver the money, and with that business concluded, your day may continue.
payingYourDue17.node.7:
(You have lost a decent amount of credibility)
(You have gained some peril)
payingYourDue17.node.5: While you have the money to pay for these things, you really need those livres for your other plans. It might be risky, but you think you can weather this particular storm. Of course, this doesn't make your landlord very happy, nor does it make Camille feel any better about you.
payingYourDue17.node.4: "Merci beaucoup, madame!" Camille says with a curtsey as you hand her the money.
payingYourDue17.node.3: Unfortunately, you simply don't have the money to pay for that. Of course, this doesn't make your landlord any happier, nor does it make Camille feel any better about you.
payingYourDue17.node.2: You have the necessary 40 Livres, but wonder if you could put them to better use elsewhere.
payingYourDue17.node.1: "The house's rent is due today, as are my wages."
payingYourDue17.node.0: You look up at the sound of Camille knocking on your door frame. "Good morning Madame!"
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.name: Bearing Gifts
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.64: You discreetly hide the note under your stays and turn back to Madame Gazel.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.63: It reads 'You're clearly making good progress. Keep joining Madame Gazel on rendezvous and she's likely to open up to you further.'
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.62: Feeling something strange in your pockets, you reach inside to find a hastily written note that your spymistress, Thérèse must have slipped in there when you passed her in the hallway.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.61: You discreetly hide the note under your stays and turn back to Madame Gazel.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.60: It reads 'You're clearly making good progress. Keep joining Madame Gazel on rendezvous and she's likely to open up to you further.'
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.59: Feeling something strange in your pockets, you reach inside to find a hastily written note that your spymistress, Thérèse must have slipped in there when you passed her in the hallway.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.58: She holds the door open for you, and soon the two of you are whisked off to your destination.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.57: Together, the two of you head outside, where René is awaiting you with Madame Gazel's carriage.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.56: She holds the door open for you, and soon the two of you are whisked off to your destination.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.55: She takes your stunned silence as agreement. "Good. I'm glad we understand each other."
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.54: "Oh, that is tempting..." She leans close to whisper in your ear. "...but I've already spent far too much effort to have the world miss out on how perfect I've made you look."
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.53: (You have gained a little favor with Madame Gazel)
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.52: Her eyes drink in your every last detail. She wants your resistance, just so she can break it.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.51: Together, the two of you head outside, where René is awaiting you with Madame Gazel's carriage.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.50: (You have gained a little favor with Madame Gazel)
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.49: (You have gained some favor with Madame Gazel)
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.47: She laughs at the memory. "Of course, I had no idea why I was doing any of it back then, I just knew that I liked it."
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.46: Camille heads down to the kitchen, leaving you and Honorade alone.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.45: "You're all set Madame!" Camille says with a curtsey. "Now, I must be going. The kitchen is an absolute mess."
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.44: You get dressed, as per usual, with Camille helping you into your outfit. It's a little odd at first, having Madame Gazel there, but once the three of you all start talking, you realize that you really enjoy having the company.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.42: That warm whisper suddenly turns to ice. "So you will do exactly as I say, do you understand?"
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.41: "I thought so. After all, everyone needs to see how good I've made you look. Exactly how I like you."
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.40: "Shall we go?" She asks innocently, as if it was all in your imagination.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.39: (You have gained a little favor with Madame Gazelle)
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.38: You look at yourself in the mirror, and you have to admit that Honorade has good taste. She spends some time adjusting your bodice, but before you know it, these adjustments slowly turn into something firmer, and more sensual. Yet, the moment you start to submit to her touch, she pulls away, leaving you wanting more.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.37: Without another word Madame Gazel firmly, but politely, ushers Camille out of the room.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.35: (You have lost a little favor with Madame Gazel)
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.34: (You have gained some favor with Madame Gazel)
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.33: "I liked being in control of all the details. I liked it even more when they fought back, but I still got my way."
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.32: Honorade continues her ministrations, but you can feel her slowing down. As you sit there, frozen in place, you wonder how one tells the difference between unwavering obedience and boredom.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.31: Just as you start to pull away from her, she places her hands on your shoulders and forces you down into the seat at your vanity. Holding a makeup brush in one hand, she grasps you firmly by the chin with the other. "Protest all you want little Yvette. It won't do you any good. I always get my way, and you'll be no different."
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.30: "I'm glad you're grateful." She replies with a contented sigh. "I've always enjoyed dressing others up like this, even when I was child."
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.29: All that seems to matter is whether your appearance pleases her.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.28: This is different. Being pulled this way and that. Being fussily primped and preened without any consultation to you whatsoever. You're not the one in control here.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.27: However, those occasions were about comfort and efficiency. A ribbon tied here, a pin placed there. You were the one in control.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.26: This, of course, isn't the first time anyone has helped you get dressed before.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.25: "As I was saying, let's get you ready."
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.24: "That will not be necessary." Madame Gazel interrupts. "Your mistress and I shall attend to this ourselves."
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.23: "Don't worry Madame!" Camille happily interjects. "That's something I-"
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.22: Honorade pulls a pocket watch from her bodice and notes the time, before putting it away. "It seems that I've already taken too much of your time. If we want to make it to our rendezvous tonight, you'll need some help getting ready."
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.21: (You have gained a little favor with Madame Gazel)
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.18: (You have gained some favor with Madame Gazel)
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.17: You set the parcel aside on your bed, for later.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.16: (You have lost a little favor with Madame Gazel)
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.15: You open the package to reveal a gorgeous black silk dress. Expensive, and rather revealing, it certainly feels in line with the Bourgeoisie.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.13: "It's true, it was a very sweet attempt." Madame Gazel admits, reassuring Camille with a light pat on the cheek. Satisfied, she sets her focus on you.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.12: "Madame you have to understand, I tried to stop her!" Camille wails softly.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.11: Some moments later, they enter together, with Camille trailing behind Madame Gazel. Your hapless maid is carrying a large parcel with a bow on it.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.10: Before you can reply, Camille sets off to her new task with gusto, but you're not optimistic about her success, based on what you hear of her stammered attempts at an argument in the stairway.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.9: She barely conceals a smile. "I'd considered it, but this was really more of an unexpected bounty than anything else."
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.8: "I see. I had hoped for this to be a pleasant surprise."
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.7: "I had a feeling that you liked being spoiled."
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.6: "In fact, how would you feel about wearing it tonight?"
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.5: "I looked through my wardrobe and found that I had something which will look a lot better on you than it does on me."
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.4: The parcel is placed in your hands, and she continues "This morning, I realized that we're almost the same size. I also know that you, ever the social butterfly, are always looking for novel outfits to wear at parties."
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.2: A few moments later, Camille enters your room and whispers "Uh Madame... Madame Gazel is here to see you? Don't worry, I'll delay her until you're ready."
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.1: You hear knocking downstairs, at the front door. Camille answers it and you can hear an exchange, but the muttering is too soft for you to make out any specifics.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.node.0: It's a few hours before your rendezvous with Madame Gazel, and you're in your room, just starting to get ready.
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.link.55: "Are you sure Madame Gazel? Perhaps we should just stay in..."
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.link.41: "Do you always dress up girls in your clothes before you romance them, or am I just special?"
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.link.29: <Stay silent, stay still, and let her do as she pleases>
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.link.28: <Smile> "Oh Madame Gazel, I don't think I should be letting you do this."
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.link.7: "Are you sure that's the only reason you're in my room while I'm still half naked?"
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.link.6: "Ah, but I had something else in mind for tonight. I'd prefer to wait before trying that on."
bearingGiftsJardinDesPlantes.link.5: "Well, I've never turned down a nice gift before, and I won't start now."

Together, the two of you head outside, where René is awaiting you with Madame Gazel's carriage.
(You have gained a little favor with Madame Gazel)
(You have gained some favor with Madame Gazel)
"It was never just girls."
She laughs at the memory. "Of course, I had no idea why I was doing any of it back then, I just knew that I liked it."
Camille heads down to the kitchen, leaving you and Honorade alone.
"You're all set Madame!" Camille says with a curtsey. "Now, I must be going. The kitchen is an absolute mess."

You get dressed, as per usual, with Camille helping you into your outfit. It's a little odd at first, having Madame Gazel there, but once the three of you all start talking, you realize that you really enjoy having the company.
"Yvette, don't be ridiculous!" She laughs.
That warm whisper suddenly turns to ice. "So you will do exactly as I say, do you understand?"
"I thought so. After all, everyone needs to see how good I've made you look. Exactly how I like you."
"Shall we go?" She asks innocently, as if it was all in your imagination.
(You have gained a little favor with Madame Gazelle)

You look at yourself in the mirror, and you have to admit that Honorade has good taste. She spends some time adjusting your bodice, but before you know it, these adjustments slowly turn into something firmer, and more sensual. Yet, the moment you start to submit to her touch, she pulls away, leaving you wanting more.
Without another word Madame Gazel firmly, but politely, ushers Camille out of the room.
"But-"
(You have lost a little favor with Madame Gazel)
(You have gained some favor with Madame Gazel)
"I liked being in control of all the details. I liked it even more when they fought back, but I still got my way."
Honorade continues her ministrations, but you can feel her slowing down. As you sit there, frozen in place, you wonder how one tells the difference between unwavering obedience and boredom.

Just as you start to pull away from her, she places her hands on your shoulders and forces you down into the seat at your vanity. Holding a makeup brush in one hand, she grasps you firmly by the chin with the other. "Protest all you want little Yvette. It won't do you any good. I always get my way, and you'll be no different."
"I'm glad you're grateful." She replies with a contented sigh. "I've always enjoyed dressing others up like this, even when I was child."
All that seems to matter is whether your appearance pleases her.
This is different. Being pulled this way and that. Being fussily primped and preened without any consultation to you whatsoever. You're not the one in control here.
However, those occasions were about comfort and efficiency. A ribbon tied here, a pin placed there. You were the one in control.
This, of course, isn't the first time anyone has helped you get dressed before.
"As I was saying, let's get you ready."
"That will not be necessary." Madame Gazel interrupts. "Your mistress and I shall attend to this ourselves."
"Don't worry Madame!" Camille happily interjects. "That's something I-"

Honorade pulls a pocket watch from her bodice and notes the time, before putting it away. "It seems that I've already taken too much of your time. If we want to make it to our rendezvous tonight, you'll need some help getting ready."
(You have gained a little favor with Madame Gazel)
(You have been gifted Honorade's Outfit)

You set the parcel aside on your bed, for later.

You open the package to reveal a gorgeous black silk dress. Expensive, and rather revealing, it certainly feels in line with the Bourgeoisie.
"Go ahead, open it."
"It's true, it was a very sweet attempt." Madame Gazel admits, reassuring Camille with a light pat on the cheek. Satisfied, she sets her focus on you.
"Madame you have to understand, I tried to stop her!" Camille wails softly.
Some moments later, they enter together, with Camille trailing behind Madame Gazel. Your hapless maid is carrying a large parcel with a bow on it.
Before you can reply, Camille sets off to her new task with gusto, but you're not optimistic about her success, based on what you hear of her stammered attempts at an argument in the stairway.
She barely conceals a smile. "I'd considered it, but this was really more of an unexpected bounty than anything else."
"I see. I had hoped for this to be a pleasant surprise."
"I had a feeling that you liked being spoiled."
"In fact, how would you feel about wearing it tonight?"
"I looked through my wardrobe and found that I had something which will look a lot better on you than it does on me."

The parcel is placed in your hands, and she continues "This morning, I realized that we're almost the same size. I also know that you, ever the social butterfly, are always looking for novel outfits to wear at parties."
"Bonsoir Yvette! I've come, bearing gifts."
A few moments later, Camille enters your room and whispers "Uh Madame... Madame Gazel is here to see you? Don't worry, I'll delay her until you're ready."
You hear knocking downstairs, at the front door. Camille answers it and you can hear an exchange, but the muttering is too soft for you to make out any specifics.
It's a few hours before your rendezvous with Madame Gazel, and you're in your room, just starting to get ready.
"Are you sure Madame Gazel? Perhaps we should just stay in..."
"Do you always dress up girls in your clothes before you romance them, or am I just special?"
<Stay silent, stay still, and let her do as she pleases>
<Smile> "Oh Madame Gazel, I don't think I should be letting you do this."
"Are you sure that's the only reason you're in my room while I'm still half naked?"
"Ah, but I had something else in mind for tonight. I'd prefer to wait before trying that on."
"Well, I've never turned down a nice gift before, and I won't start now."

The two of you order a bottle of cheap wine and take a table near the main stage. The violinist playing tonight is fantastic and you soon find yourselves pounding your fists on the table in time with his music, along with the rest of the patrons.
(You have gained a little favor with Antoine)
(You have lost a little favor with Madame Gazel)
(You have gained some favor with Alex)
"Ah! Free-flowing drink, raucous fun, and excellent dancing. This is going to be a great day!"
(You have gained a little favor with Ludovico)
(You have gained a little favor with Élisabeth)
(You have lost a little favor with Antoine)
"Really? Did you think that this would please me?" He asks, as he looks you over before walking ahead.
(You have gained no favor with Antoine)
"You look good, but I think you already know that." He says offhandedly before walking ahead of you.
"The common people, in a rustic setting, enjoying themselves in such a truly honest way. It reminds me of home."
He looks around, and you're not really certain if he's examining the location, or looking for threats.
(You have gained quite a bit of favor with Antoine)
"You look ravishing, by the way." He says, quietly but firmly before walking ahead of you.

Honorade stares at the guinguette and swallows deeply, her face slightly paler than usual. "Oh... there is... a lot of wine here."

Her voice is apprehensive.
Turning her attention from you, she surveys your location.
(You have lost a little favor with Madame Gazel)
(You have gained no favor with Madame Gazel)
"Are you sure you can't do better than this, little Yvette?" She asks, examining you carefully.
"I'm glad you could make it." She says, eyes quickly flickering over you.
(You have gained quite a bit of favor with Madame Gazel)
"Oh, this is very pleasing." She says, looking at you through narrowed eyes as she slowly circles you like a panther. "You've done quite well."
He glances away from you, taking in your location.
(You have gained a decent amount of favor with Alex)
"It's great to see you!" He says, not even taking a second glance at your clothes. You are, once again, reminded that military men seem to have little interest in fashion.
Ludovico chuckles to himself when he looks around at Guinguette Paradis. "I see we're going to experience some authentic French culture here."
Reluctantly taking his gaze off of you, he examines your location.
(You have gained quite a bit of favor with Ludovico)
(You have lost a little favor with Ludovico)
(You have gained no favor with Ludovico)
Élisabeth looks around at Guinguette Paradis, and smiles warmly to you. "It's a little rustic, but I like it. It's honest. Nobody is putting on airs here."
Looking away from you, she surveys your location.
(You have lost a little favor with Élisabeth)
(You have gained no favor with Élisabeth)
(You have gained quite a bit of favor with Élisabeth)
"Ah, I see." He says when he notices your outfit of choice.
"You look quite nice." Ludovico says, after a moment.
"I feel blessed to even look upon you." He says with a smile, and you catch his eyes lingering in a few choice places.
"Oh, is that what you're going to wear?" She asks quietly.
"You look nice." She says with a quick smile.
"You look absolutely stunning!" She gushes, as she looks you over, and you notice her empty hand idly sketching you in the air.
Antoine, tumultuous as ever, storms over to you shortly after you arrive. "So, you've made it. Shall we?"

Looking around, you see that Honorade arrived long before you did. Noticing you, she approaches and stands far closer than the rules of politeness might allow. You'd forgotten how good she is at looming over people.
Alex arrives exactly on time, and greets you with a precise bow and a broad smile. "Bonne après-midi, Yvette."

Ludovico arrives at the same time as yourself, and approaches you. He stands close, but with just enough distance to provide him with plausible deniability, should anyone become suspicious of you two.
A few minutes late, Élisabeth arrives. After taking a moment to carefully look around, she approaches you.
You return to the idyllic Guinguette Paradis, which is already packed with enthusiastic patrons, clapping in time with the band's music, drinking great gulps of wine, and dancing.
After spending the first half of the day getting ready, you head out for your rendezvous.

someLightReading.node.14: You start finding pages where the margins have been filled with densely packed notes. However, these notes aren't about the book or its characters. These are notes on the most prominent people in Paris.
someLightReading.node.13: Equal parts curious and suspicious, you page through the book. At first you don't notice anything, but suddenly...
someLightReading.node.11: He gestures to his cassock. "Obviously, my situation didn't allow for me to follow his example, but such is life, and we do what we can."
someLightReading.node.10: "But that's not all," He says in a low voice.
someLightReading.node.9: "Will you at least give it a try? If not, I won't pester you about this. The story itself isn't important."
someLightReading.node.8: "When it was written, everyone saw it as a comedy about a fanciful madman. Then, years later, readers started to see it as a tragedy about a well meaning eccentric, ridiculed and ground down by an overly serious society."
someLightReading.node.7: "Absolutely, I fell in love with his work years ago. I've especially enjoyed seeing how the meaning of the book has changed over time."
someLightReading.node.6: "Oh, is it not?" He asks with a certain amount of apprehension.
someLightReading.node.5: "It's an adventure, it's a comedy, and there's also some delightfully biting social commentary. In short, it's my favorite kind of story. I'll always treasure Quixote's sense of romance."
someLightReading.node.4: "I originally started reading it in French to learn the language faster, but it's always been a favorite of mine."
someLightReading.node.3:
Finally, he pulls a worn leather book out of his bag and hands it to you. The lamp light catches on the gilted lettering on the cover.

'Don Quixote' reads the title.
someLightReading.node.2: He starts rummaging through his bag, looking for something. "I have a present for you."
someLightReading.node.1: "Ah yes! I almost forgot!" Ludovico suddenly yelps.
someLightReading.node.0: After your rendezvous, Ludovico offers to walk you home. Soon, you find yourself chatting and laughing together, as you stroll home under the glow of the city lamps.
someLightReading.link.166: "I'm well, Camille. I'm just slowly losing control of my life."
someLightReading.link.159: "I'm well, Camille. I'm just slowly losing control of my life."

someLightReading.link.62: "I'm well, Camille. I'm just slowly losing control of my life."

someLightReading.link.50: "Ugh, fine. Just take it and begone."
