theMorningOfTheParty.name: The Morning of the Party
theMorningOfTheParty.node.7: Camille enters your bedroom, already full of cheer.
theMorningOfTheParty.node.6: "Don't worry, madame! A glamorous woman, like yourself, is sure to catch on quickly!"
theMorningOfTheParty.node.5: "Ah, but of course you are, madame!" Camille laughs, following you as you start to get ready for the party tonight.
theMorningOfTheParty.node.4: Camille winces at this statement, and looks at the floor. "I don't know how to tell you this, madame, but party preparations for a woman of your station usually take all day. On days where you have a party, you won't really have time to spend exploring Paris."
theMorningOfTheParty.node.3: "Once you go to your wardrobe, we can get started!"
theMorningOfTheParty.node.2: "That's good to hear! These preparations always seem to take all day. On days where you have a party, you won't really have time to spend exploring Paris."
theMorningOfTheParty.node.1: "Madame, when would you like to start getting ready?"
theMorningOfTheParty.node.0: You awaken to the vision of sunlight filtering through the shutters, scattering sunbeams across this dusty bedroom. It takes a few minutes before you groggily remember the events that brought you here. You also remember that tonight, you have a party to attend.
theMorningOfTheParty.link.5: "I've never really done anything like this. Is there anything I should know?" <Tutorial>
theMorningOfTheParty.link.4: "Don't worry, Camille, I'm already quite good at this." <No Tutorial>
theMorningOfTheParty.link.2: "Not yet, Camille. I still have some things that I need to take care of, today."
theMorningOfTheParty.link.0: "If this is as important as the invitation makes it seem, I should start preparing now."
aStructuralDisagreement.name: A Structural Disagreement
aStructuralDisagreement.description: Monsieur von Mayendorf, who you’ve spoken with earlier, appears to be having quite the disagreement with one of his supplies. It’s considered rather gauche to air such grievances in public, so this must be serious indeed...
aStructuralDisagreement.node.41: Thinking quickly, you manage to provide some socially acceptable excuses and part leave the conversation before you find yourself sucked in any further. This feels like it's been a decent use of your time.
aStructuralDisagreement.node.40: You speak a while longer with the older gentleman, but it yields you little in the way of information, other than learning that the man absolutely adores talking about himself.
aStructuralDisagreement.node.39: Shaking his head, Christophe leaves the room. The crowd parts before him, sensing the danger lurking behind his quiet anger.
aStructuralDisagreement.node.38: The crowd of onlookers whispers, and seem to approve of your decision to step in and enforce the existing social order.
aStructuralDisagreement.node.37: "Are you quite serious, Madame Decaux?" Christophe says, looking at you with barely concealed disgust. "Fine, then. To the devil with you both!"
aStructuralDisagreement.node.36: Christophe leaves, and you carefully step into a corner, so that you can write down what you've just learned. Overall, this has been a good use of your time.
aStructuralDisagreement.node.35: "Now, if you might excuse me, I have some other business to attend to. My reputation has been damaged enough by that loathsome blockhead that I must find a new project to save my reputation."
aStructuralDisagreement.node.34: (You've gained a piece of Outrageous Bourgeoisie Gossip)
aStructuralDisagreement.node.33: (You've gained a piece of Shocking Bourgeoisie Gossip)
aStructuralDisagreement.node.32: (You've gained a piece of Cheap Bourgeoisie Gossip)
aStructuralDisagreement.node.31: Christophe steps closer and whispers a few choice details to you. You listen carefully, memorizing as much as possible.
aStructuralDisagreement.node.30: "Thank you for your assistance. Seeing self-important boors get their comeuppance always puts a smile on my face. In fact, maybe you could use this rumor I've heard to ensure that his reputation more accurately reflects his character. After all, anything that can be destroyed by the truth, should be."
aStructuralDisagreement.node.29: The masonry magnate storms away from the conversation, his face frozen into a permanent sneer.
aStructuralDisagreement.node.28: "To the devil with you both, then!"
aStructuralDisagreement.node.27: "Are you certain about that? If you were to ask me, I'd say that Madame Decaux is extremely welcome right now."
aStructuralDisagreement.node.26: "Are you sure that I'm the one that's in danger?" Christophe replies, smiling for the first time. "I've learned a lot while having the unpleasurable experience of working with you. If you're not careful, some of your indiscretions could become more... public."
aStructuralDisagreement.node.24: The older man whirls on you. "I shall ask you to leave us to our own business, madame. Now is not the time for interlopers to inject their opinions where they don't belong."
aStructuralDisagreement.node.23: The two of them begin to raise their voices at each other, growing ever louder, until they both step outside together. Some of the more brazen members of the crowd follow them outside, but you'd much rather not watch whatever mess is going to happen next, just in case it blows back against you again. So, you go back to your own business at the party.
aStructuralDisagreement.node.22: Christophe leaves, and you're left there without much in the way of reward, but at least you've prevented their argument from degenerating into a complete embarrassment.
aStructuralDisagreement.node.21: "Now, if you might excuse me, I have some other business to attend to. My reputation has been damaged enough by that loathsome blockhead that I must find a new project to save my reputation."
aStructuralDisagreement.node.20:
(You have gained some credibility)
(You have lost a little peril)
aStructuralDisagreement.node.19: The Magnate leaves, and Christophe turns to you. "Well, that was vaguely satisfactory, and I suppose it prevented us from causing a scene. So, thank you, Madame Decaux."
aStructuralDisagreement.node.18:
(You have gained a little credibility)
(You have lost some peril)
aStructuralDisagreement.node.16: Some of the observing guests whisper amongst each other reprovingly. Even if the Bourgeoisie is unhappy with the Crown at the moment, one still has to give a certain amount of respect to powerful men like this Masonry Magnate.
aStructuralDisagreement.node.15: "You exaggerate, garçon. The materials my company supplied weren't as poor as you say. Even if they were, every business has a right to save itself money wherever possible..."
aStructuralDisagreement.node.14:
(You have lost quite a bit of credibility)
(Gain some peril)
aStructuralDisagreement.node.13: "I can find these terms agreeable, as long as I never have to work with you again" The Austrian architect replies, receiving only a polite nod in response.
aStructuralDisagreement.node.12: "I shall ask you to leave us to our own business, madame. Now is not the time for peacemaking!" The Masonry Magnate growls between his teeth.
aStructuralDisagreement.node.11: “Perhaps... we can part ways, and simply be icily polite to each other from now on?"
aStructuralDisagreement.node.10: "Are you really suggesting that we should just 'live and let live' over something this serious?" Christophe asks you flatly.
aStructuralDisagreement.node.9: "You should listen to the good woman, Christophe." The masonry magnate chuckles, his eyes twinkling with good humor. "You're stepping a little above your station, don't you think?"
aStructuralDisagreement.node.8: The crowd of onlookers gasps at your snide question. Both of the men involved freeze in place.
aStructuralDisagreement.node.7: You see both of them sharply inhaling, about to deliver their next verbal blows.
aStructuralDisagreement.node.6: Some of the observing guests whisper amongst each other reprovingly. Even if Monsieur Von Mayendorf has a point, this is not how one does things in France.
aStructuralDisagreement.node.5: "I'm sure the nobles adore you and your refusal to take responsiblity for your own failings. However, if you'd actually paid any attention, you would have noticed that the Court at Versailles doesn't quite have the favor of the people in this room. Then again, I can't expect you to notice that, it would require you to pay attention to something other than yourself!"
aStructuralDisagreement.node.4: “Am I supposed to be impressed by the fact that the Courtiers at Versailles have misjudged your character? You're a pretender at being nobility, just like you're a pretender at being competent."
aStructuralDisagreement.node.3: “Listen here, you Austrian cur! You do not have the right to speak to me like that. I may not hold a title, but I am still far above your station. I am a regular guest of the Lords and Ladies at Versailles, and I will be treated as such."
aStructuralDisagreement.node.2: "Are you even listening to yourself? You'd trade your very soul to the devil for a few coins, and I think you'd still have struck the better bargain." Monsieur Von Mayendorf replies, his expression calm, but his voice white hot with anger.
aStructuralDisagreement.node.1: "Me, monsieur? You're blaming me for the collapse of that bridge? I visited the worksite myself, and I saw the supplies that you'd sold the builders. The stones had enough cracks in them to resemble a spider's web! Of course my design didn't hold up. The angels themselves couldn't succeed with such shoddy materials."
aStructuralDisagreement.node.0: You find yourself drawn to the telltale sounds of an argument. If nothing else, it should be entertaining.
aStructuralDisagreement.link.7: "Now now, Messieurs. Perhaps this isn't so bad? Let's not take this a bridge too far..."
aStructuralDisagreement.link.6: "A poor craftsman blames his tools, Christophe. Surely, this esteemed gentleman is right."
aStructuralDisagreement.link.5: "Esteemed monsieur, did you make your entire fortune shifting blame, or just most of it?"
aLostOpportunity.name: A Lost Opportunity
aLostOpportunity.node.20: 'Such concerns are beyond the comprehension of the dull creatures that infest our highest social circles. Such as that thoughtless Madame Decaux.'
aLostOpportunity.node.19: (The Revolution has gained a little power)
aLostOpportunity.node.18: 'Such splendor is, of course, beyond the reach of the pathetic wretches that claw at our heels. Such as that artless Madame Decaux.'
aLostOpportunity.node.17: (The Crown has gained a little power)
aLostOpportunity.node.16: This entire day can already go to the devil himself!
aLostOpportunity.node.15: Possessed by a terrible rage, you crumple the newspaper and hurl the traitorous rag out of your window. This elicits some consternation and choice invectives from someone outside, but you are beyond caring about such things.
aLostOpportunity.node.12: 'The Masquerade was a beautiful celebration of the traditions and gentility that make our kingdom great.' Marcelle is quoted to say.
aLostOpportunity.node.11: 'The Grand Salon was a triumph of enlightened works highlighting the primacy of true feeling and natural law.' Maximin is quoted to say.
aLostOpportunity.node.10: Uncertain of why you're choosing to do this to yourself, you keep reading the article anyway, growing angrier by the line. Not only was entire the event a staggering success, Marcelle was even interviewed about it later.
aLostOpportunity.node.9: Uncertain of why you're choosing to do this to yourself, you keep reading the article anyway, growing angrier by the line. Not only was entire the event a staggering success, Maximin was even interviewed about it later.
aLostOpportunity.node.8: (You can no longer pursue vengeance against Baron Maximin de Termes)
aLostOpportunity.node.7: (You can no longer pursue vengeance against Viscountess Marcelle du Foix)
aLostOpportunity.node.6: A distant memory flits through your mind, of when you received a letter concerning how you might be able to damage their reputation, but it all seems irrelevant now.
aLostOpportunity.node.5: That was her most public event of the year, and with this opportunity passed by, it seems like you will not be able to gain any kind of meaningful vengeance against her.
aLostOpportunity.node.4: That was his most public event of the year, and with this opportunity passed by, it seems like you will not be able to gain any kind of meaningful vengeance against him.
aLostOpportunity.node.3: A distant memory flits through your mind, of when you received a letter concerning how you might be able to damage their reputation, but it all seems irrelevant now.
aLostOpportunity.node.2: You furrow your brow at the news that something has gone well for that vile Viscountess Marcelle du Foix. Apparently, she held her Birthday Masquerade last night.
aLostOpportunity.node.1: You furrow your brow at the news that something has gone well for that wretched Baron Maximin de Termes. Apparently, he held his Grand Salon last night.
aLostOpportunity.node.0: You start your day as you normally do, by reading the morning paper.
workingUpTheNerve.name: Working Up The Nerve
workingUpTheNerve.node.36: She leaves to go inside, and you are left to consider your own life. Has the unvarnished truth always been the best choice for you? Perhaps it's just better for other people.
workingUpTheNerve.node.35: "Well, here goes nothing!" She sighs, steeling herself for what's to come. "If all else fails, at least I'll get some good tea and pastries out of the bargain."
workingUpTheNerve.node.33: Snorting with contemptuous anger, you decide to bring your day to an early close, and head home. The audacity of the people around you is but an eternal fountain of consternation and woe.
workingUpTheNerve.node.32: She leaves to go inside, and you briefly fume about the fact that someone specifically asked your advice, just to turn against it. What was the point of even asking you, then?
workingUpTheNerve.node.30: She leaves to go inside, and you begin to consider your own life. Do you really lie that much? Perhaps, but if it's the only way to actually reach a fruitful end, then perhaps deception is the only reasonable choice.
workingUpTheNerve.node.29: (You have gained some credibility... strangely enough)
workingUpTheNerve.node.28: As you don't want to make things awkward by lingering outside the very cafe where Fatima is meeting her parents, you decide to bring your day to an early close, and head home. It wasn't a thrilling way to spend your day, but it certainly wasn't awful either.
workingUpTheNerve.node.26: She heads inside, and you find yourself thinking about applying this wisdom to your own life. Your situation isn't perfect, but you have a place to live in Paris. You have Camille, and apparently people trust you enough to seek your counsel. It puts things in perspective, and you find yourself thinking more clearly about your own situation.
workingUpTheNerve.node.25: "Well, here goes nothing!" She sighs, steeling herself for what's to come. "If all else fails, at least I'll get some good tea and pastries out of the bargain."
workingUpTheNerve.node.24: "I can't say that you're wrong, though. Perhaps I've been dwelling on my own problems too much. Every day, there's a new disaster, and if I don't stop to appreciate what I have right now, then I'll only be making myself miserable."
workingUpTheNerve.node.23: "I'm almost angry at how well that worked. Thanks, Yvette."
workingUpTheNerve.node.22: "This is what my life has come to. I'm dreading that someone is going to ask how I'm doing."
workingUpTheNerve.node.21: "Then again..." Fatima mumbles to herself. "I imagine it does solve my problems, and it doesn't mean that I have to do this all the time. Just until things pick up at the shop a little. This is a good idea, Yvette!"
workingUpTheNerve.node.18: "No... I just can't do it. If I tell them how bad things are going, they're just going to worry, and nothing is going to get better. I'm sorry, but you just don't know them like I do."
workingUpTheNerve.node.17: "Ugh! I hate how much sense you're making right now. If I'm not honest with them then I'll end up having to build new lies upon old lies, and that's just inviting the devil into your home. It can only bring problems."
workingUpTheNerve.node.16: "I know! I know!" The dressmaker admits with a sigh. "There are worse problems in life, but this is the one haunting me right now. Don't you think I know that?"
workingUpTheNerve.node.15: "You actually want me to lie to my parents? As in, you're not joking?"
workingUpTheNerve.node.13: "It simply defies belief that I'm so exhausted by this. There are people starving, and we've had riots in the streets, but I'm so bothered by this? Every time I open a newspaper I feel guilty for being unhappy, which somehow manages to make it all worse."
workingUpTheNerve.node.12: "Yvette, you seem to have your life under control. What should I be doing here?"
workingUpTheNerve.node.11: "I'm either going to lie to them, or I'm going to tell them the truth, and bear their disappointment. I don't even know which choice is worse."
workingUpTheNerve.node.10: "Agh! Why am I telling a customer this?!"
workingUpTheNerve.node.9: She forces a smile before continuing. "To be honest, my business at Le Petit Mogol has been struggling for months. In fact, your loyal patronage is one of the only reasons that I'm still in business. I know my parents, and the first thing they're going to ask me is how the store is going, and..."
workingUpTheNerve.node.8: "They've always supported me, but there's this pressure to succeed that's just, overwhelming sometimes. I'm their only child, and I know that they gave me everything that they could and... there are times that I feel like I was a poor investment."
workingUpTheNerve.node.7: "I appreciate her concern, but I'm also not a fool."
workingUpTheNerve.node.6: "It's just that, my parents are waiting for me in the cafe." She says, pointing at the newly opened business with the stem of her pipe. "We're just supposed to be meeting for tea, and... I'm at my wits' end."
workingUpTheNerve.node.5: "Oh, I'm more than aware. Whenever I see my mother, she always find a way to bring up bring up the latest wicked deed she's heard about here in Paris, and telling me to be carefuly. It's like she thinks that she's the one who was born here, not me."
workingUpTheNerve.node.4: Fatima pauses her nervous pacing to breathe slowly in through her nose, and out of her mouth. The breaths start off as shaky, but slowly become more uniform, and she stands up a touch straighter.
workingUpTheNerve.node.3: "I'm so sorry, Yvette. I must have been lost in my thoughts."
workingUpTheNerve.node.2: By the time she finally notices you, you're practically standing right next to her. She gasps and hops back from you with a start.
workingUpTheNerve.node.1: Fatima is pacing pensively back and forth outside the cafe, puffing so heavily on her pipe that it resembles a chimney. You decide to approach her.
workingUpTheNerve.node.0: Walking through some newly familiar streets, you notice that a new cafe has opened. The smell of coffee hangs in the air, and a small crowd of citizens mill about outside to see what's going on. It's then that you recognize one of the people in the crowd.
workingUpTheNerve.link.16: "Not to be rude, but I would've killed for my parents to care about my interests at all."
workingUpTheNerve.link.15: "If there's one thing I've learned in my life, it's that you should never stop lying."
workingUpTheNerve.link.14: "Lying gets you nothing, and it makes you feel awful, so just tell the truth."
workingUpTheNerve.link.5: "What is it, that has you so worried?"
workingUpTheNerve.link.4: "This isn't the safest place to be distracted. Paris has more than a few villains in it."
aDanceTogether.name: A Dance Together
aDanceTogether.node.37: "Forgive me..." Armand whispers. "It's been so long, that I almost forgot how much I missed this."
aDanceTogether.node.36: "I think if that man yells his affection for that woman any louder, his tongue's going to fall out... can you imagine if it actually worked? They're married, surrounded by bountiful children, warming themselves by the fire, and his wife lovingly telling the story of how she hadn't felt true love until she met the loudest man in all of France?"
aDanceTogether.node.35: It's a merry place indeed, if a bit brash and rustic. Perhaps it would make a good place to take someone on a rendezvous. Someone who enjoyed more lively and honest entertainments.
aDanceTogether.node.34: Your mind returning to the manifold difficulties and intrigues occupying your time, you walk home, trying to organize your thoughts. There are just too many possibilities to consider.
aDanceTogether.node.33: As much as you like Armand before, you feel like you're growing past him. You're becoming something... more.
aDanceTogether.node.32: It truly was good to see him. After all, he's the reason you came to Paris in the first place, and he's still your first true love. Sometimes, the first urgers of the heart are those that are most correct.
aDanceTogether.node.31: As you find your way home, you consider the day's events, and your time with Armand.
aDanceTogether.node.30: "This is where we must part ways ma chérie, but I hope to see you again soon. Things may be chaotic now, but I just know that we'll make it through this."
aDanceTogether.node.29: Slowly, the music winds down, and you step away from the other dancers and revelers. Arm in arm, the two of you walk back, through the city gates, to Paris proper.
aDanceTogether.node.28: While the merrymaking continues, you thankfully manage to retain some level of temperance, so that you're not rendered completely senseless. With the aid of an excessive amount of cold water, the two of manage to make yourselves steady on your feet. Arm in arm, the two of you walk back, through the city gates, to Paris proper.
aDanceTogether.node.27: It's been some time since you've felt this relaxed, and the longest you've gone in weeks without thinking about the latest intrigue or impending disaster.
aDanceTogether.node.26: It's been some time since you've felt this relaxed, and the longest you've gone in weeks without thinking about the latest intrigue or impending disaster.
aDanceTogether.node.25: "Eventually, my books started arriving with letters from him, asking my opinion on this issue or that, and we struck up a frequent correspondence. Perhaps a year later, he asked if I would be interested in joining a society of like-minded individuals, who turned out to the Frankish Hapsburgian Society. The rest is, as they say, history."
aDanceTogether.node.24: "Eventually, my books started arriving with letters from him, asking my opinion on this issue or that, and we struck up a frequent correspondence. Perhaps a year later, he asked if I would be interested in joining a society of like-minded individuals, who turned out to the Frankish Hapsburgian Society. The rest is, as they say, history."
aDanceTogether.node.23: "Charles? The book-seller?" Armand asks, surprised. "Years ago, once I'd devoured every book on political theory that I could find, I started to order them from him. He lived in Avignon, and had a much easier time obtaining the latest imprints.
aDanceTogether.node.22: Now that you and Armand are truly alone, you find a question coming to mind.
aDanceTogether.node.21: You settle into your chair and bask in the numbing warmth of drunkenness. You and Armand spend some time catching up, reminiscing over old times, and stealthily making inappropriate jokes to each other about some of the more disorderly patrons.
aDanceTogether.node.20: "Charles? The book-seller?" Armand asks, surprised. "Years ago, once I'd devoured every book on political theory that I could find, I started to order them from him. He lived in Avignon, and had a much easier time obtaining the latest imprints.
aDanceTogether.node.19: Now that you and Armand are truly alone, you find a question coming to mind.
aDanceTogether.node.18: The music starts to slow down, and your find yourself resting your cheek against Armand's chest. The smell of his skin is both comforting and familiar.
aDanceTogether.node.17: You can feel the pressure of stares at your backs as you dance together. While times are changing, there are still those who view partnered dancing as indecent. Then again, they can take their complaints up with the hangman, if they care so much. You and Armand have been defying convention for a long time, already. Why stop here?
aDanceTogether.node.16: You drink deep of your fresh pitcher and soon find yourself a little unsteady in your seat. Still merry, of course, but it's been some time since you've been so affected by your drink.
aDanceTogether.node.15: A waltz is more of an Austrian dance, but Armand seems remarkably familiar with it.
aDanceTogether.node.14: It is controlled, it is graceful, it is exactly how you want to feel. It is a dance where you must pay attention to every detail of your partner.
aDanceTogether.node.13: "I think we can do just that." Armand says with a grin, and gestures to a barmaid, who brings your table another pitcher of wine.
aDanceTogether.node.12: You take his hand and join him among the other dancers, choosing to dance a waltz together. Your movements together are synchronized and powerful, and you feel his breathing as you dance so close together that you're almost cheek-to-cheek. The music isn't really suited for the dance, but that feels besides the point for a place like this.
aDanceTogether.node.11: You take his hand and join him among the other dancers, choosing to dance a minuet, characterized by precisely synchronized movements and short steps together. The music isn't really suited for the dance, but that feels besides the point for a place like this.
aDanceTogether.node.10: He extends a hand to you across the table. "Would you care to dance, ma chérie?"
aDanceTogether.node.9: Armand grabs a table for the both of you and orders the house wine. It arrives in a clay pitcher, and the vintage is completely unknown. Then again, this doesn't feel like a place where the patrons care about the specifics of their refreshments, merely quantity and potency. A few glasses later, you notice that the tempo of the music has started to pick up.
aDanceTogether.node.8: "It turns out, by the way, that Camille has absolutely no capacity for liquor. I'm not joking. After her first glass of wine she started to try to clean the tables, and after the second she just passed out. I had to carry her home myself."
aDanceTogether.node.7: "Back when I lived on this side of town, I frequented this idyllic bacchanalia quite a bit. In fact, I even convinced Camille to join me at one point."
aDanceTogether.node.6: "Don't worry, Yvette, nobody here knows who the devil I am." He replies. "Only some of the wealthy, the powerful, and the extremely politically active consider me a danger. The common man has no quarrel with me. Here, I'm just another patron."
aDanceTogether.node.5: "It really does!" He laughs. "As hard as we worked to escape that place, there's something nice in being able to visit what reminds us of its virtues. Especially when we have the ability to leave whenever we want."
aDanceTogether.node.4: "I have to admit, I've grown quite fond of this place."
aDanceTogether.node.3: Unable to think of any particular reason to object, you follow him to the eastern edge of Paris, to a certain Guinguette Paradis. The workday is far from over, yet somehow they seem to already have a good crowd.
aDanceTogether.node.2: "Yvette! I managed to finish my business early today. We so rarely get to see each other, how would you feel about joining me for a little merriment?"
aDanceTogether.node.1: As you ponder this quandary, you feel a gentle tap on your shoulder. Turning around, you find yourself face-to-face with none other than your fiancé, Armand.
aDanceTogether.node.0: You wander the streets of Paris. As always, you're looking for an opportunity of some sort, but a certain malaise drags at your every step. It's not exhaustion per se, but it certainly makes things more difficult. Perhaps this is common in a life such as yours, where it's difficult to truly separate one's labor from their leisure.
aDanceTogether.link.39: "I have no solid feelings yet. It's a tempestuous world that we live in."
aDanceTogether.link.38: "I fell in love with Armand because he was a big fish in a small pond. I see that now."
aDanceTogether.link.37: "It does my heart well to see him again."
aDanceTogether.link.27: "Armand, who was that man from the village? The one who called himself 'Charles'?"
aDanceTogether.link.22: "Armand, who was that man from the village? The one who called himself 'Charles'?"
aDanceTogether.link.14: "Why don't we grab some more wine, instead?"
aDanceTogether.link.5: "Are you sure that you should be seen in public right now?"
aDanceTogether.link.4: "I can see why. Does it remind you of home as well?"
anUncertainFuture.name: An Uncertain Future
anUncertainFuture.node.26: Your day of shopping is otherwise uneventful, characterized mostly by laughter and a general state of relief. Camille seems significantly more carefree than before, and appears to have taken your bodyguard's assurances to heart.
anUncertainFuture.node.25: Eventually, with the day's shopping complete, the three of you head back to your home.
anUncertainFuture.node.24: You're not certain if you'd have personally phrased it that way, but at least it seems to have put Camille at ease.
anUncertainFuture.node.22: "You will? Oh that's great!" Camille says with a look of relief. "Madame makes lot of enemies too, so you'll always have something to do!"
anUncertainFuture.node.21: "Ja. As long as the good madame keeps paying my bar tabs, I'll keep staring people down and beating fools within an inch of their life for her."
anUncertainFuture.node.20: Your day of shopping is otherwise uneventful, characterized mostly by laughter and a general state of relief. Camille seems significantly more carefree than before, and appears to have taken your thoughts to heart.
anUncertainFuture.node.19: Eventually, with the day's shopping complete, the two of you head back to your home.
anUncertainFuture.node.18: Your day of shopping is otherwise uneventful, characterized mostly by a state of heightened vigilance. Camille may still be as tense as she was before, but she seems to have a certain amount of confidence in you, due to the fact that you're taking the city's recent unrest quite seriously.
anUncertainFuture.node.15: Your day of shopping is otherwise uneventful, characterized mostly by a shroud of quiet from the both of you. It's not a peaceful quiet, but a state of fatalistic calm. Whatever happens, will happen.
anUncertainFuture.node.14: "Besides, they've only targeted really wealthy and powerful people, which means we're safe... begging your pardon, madame."
anUncertainFuture.node.13: "It's why I'm so glad you decided to join me today, madame. I haven't really felt that safe either, to be honest."
anUncertainFuture.node.11: "I guess that's true, madame, but I'm not sure if makes me feel any better."
anUncertainFuture.node.10: This answer leaves Camille in a state of uncharacteristic silence, as she contemplates this possibility.
anUncertainFuture.node.9: "I guess so, madame! If so many people are unhappy with the state of things, maybe it's alright if a few things get broken in the meanwhile."
anUncertainFuture.node.8: "Well, that doesn't make me feel that much better, but... it's better that than a comforting lie, right Madame?"
anUncertainFuture.node.7: "... I don't think anyone agrees anymore."
anUncertainFuture.node.6: "It feels like everything is made of glass, and we've just gone this whole time agreeing to not to break anything, and..."
anUncertainFuture.node.5: "I know we're different than the Réveillons, but everything feels fragile right now." Camille pauses to think for a moment. "Maybe it's been fragile this whole time, and I just didn't notice."
anUncertainFuture.node.4: "... and Madeline was a maid of all works with the Réveillon family." Camille sighs. "Then the riots happened and she didn't feel safe there anymore. So, yesterday she left to find new work. Which is really a shame, because they actually paid her on time."
anUncertainFuture.node.3: You can't help but notice that for every one of her siblings that's managed to find some semblance of success, there are two that have either been beset by grave misfortune, succumbed to vice-fueled collapse, or both. An army of people who generally seem to work themselves to the bone, but remain staggeringly poor.
anUncertainFuture.node.2: "... and my brother Jean-Pierre was a footman with the Boucher family, before they stopped paying him. Marie just started as a barmaid at a public house, but she's really just trying to find a reputable husband. Phillipe was going to join the navy, but then he 'found his calling' as a professional gambler, which apparently involves drinking all day..."
anUncertainFuture.node.1: There are so many of them... in fact, you've already spent half of this conversation trying to determine how her parents found time to sleep, while producing this battalion of offspring.
anUncertainFuture.node.0: You decide to spend the day with Camille, keeping her company while she gets some supplies for the house from the markets at Les Halles. Something about her seems unusually tense, today. During the walk, the conversation turns to the state of her family. Specifically, that of her siblings.
anUncertainFuture.link.22: "Well, no matter what happens, we still have Hansel with us. So we'll be fine."
anUncertainFuture.link.7: "Before, people were starving, now they're being shot. Does the cause of death matter?"
anUncertainFuture.link.6: "Perhaps what's being broken is something that needs to be broken."
anUncertainFuture.link.5: "We should be careful. A few sparks can easily turn into an uncontrollable inferno."
hiddenDepths.name: Hidden Depths
hiddenDepths.node.48: "I shall have to thank you properly, one day, but for now I must go. Bonne nuit, Yvette."
hiddenDepths.node.47: Without a word, Antoine leans close enough to you that his lips are but a hair's breadth from your own. You can feel the heat of his body, so close to yours, burning like a raging inferno. His eyes look deeply into your own, and you find yourself struggling so as not to shrink away from the intensity of his gaze.
hiddenDepths.node.46: "That's all I know for the moment. The only thing I'm really certain of, is that these people are dangerous. Not just to our dreams of a Republic, but to all of France."
hiddenDepths.node.45: "I don't know much else about them, other than the fact that this group is run by a woman named 'Madame du Jardin'... if that's her real name."
hiddenDepths.node.44: "I must say, Yvette, I didn't expect you to come to my rescue. You're not half bad, are you?" Antoine says, watching the shadow of the watchman recede into the distance.
hiddenDepths.node.43: "Experience is commonly a virtue of age, madame. I'm certain that you'll be adept at such things, soon enough."
hiddenDepths.node.42: "Madame, take the credit. After all, two heads cannot wear a crown." She replies with a fleeting hint of a smile. "You're my employer, and I would be a poor spy mistress indeed, if I sought glory."
hiddenDepths.node.41: She retreats into the shadows, while you approach Antoine, who is in the process of secreting the retrieved papers in his coat.
hiddenDepths.node.40: "Now that I've taken care of that, I'll hang back, and remain discreet."
hiddenDepths.node.39: She then slips away from you and intercepts the officer of the Guet Royale. While he's surprised at first, they begin to have a conversation in hushed tones. Soon, he starts to walk away, laughing merrily all the while. Moments like this are exactly why you employ a Spy Mistress.
hiddenDepths.node.38: "There's a small group of intellectuals who have been spreading word of a 'political third option'. Something distinct from both our tyrannical monarchy, and our enlightened future as a republic. What's worrying is that they're actually gaining favor among certain disaffected nobles, mayors and judges."
hiddenDepths.node.37: With that, you head inside, and go to bed. While your day may have been uneventful, it seems that your night has given you plenty to consider.
hiddenDepths.node.36: "Bonne nuit, Yvette." He says with respectful upwards nod, before disappearing into the night.
hiddenDepths.node.35: He turns away from you, and like a spectre, he disappears into the night.
hiddenDepths.node.34: True to his word, Antoine escorts you home through the dark city, staying extremely close. You can tell from his breathing that, despite his cool demeanor, he's still on edge from having been so close to being apprehended by the authorities.
hiddenDepths.node.33: "Nevertheless you've done me a great favor, so I must insist that I be allowed to walk you home, as thanks."
hiddenDepths.node.32: "In addition to my normal, revolutionary activities, I've been keeping track of a variety of fringe political groups. The Jansenists have always been a potential threat, among others. However, it appears that one of my contacts has come across something new... something strange."
hiddenDepths.node.31: Slowly, relucatantly, he relaxes. "Then again, I suppose you've earned the right to know some of this, at least."
hiddenDepths.node.28: (You have gained a little favor with Antoine)
hiddenDepths.node.27: "You want the papers?" He asks, and you notice the shine of steel, tucked up one of his sleeves.
hiddenDepths.node.26: "Well, I'm still glad that you're here. I'd hate to have had my work disturbed by one of those loutish, corrupt bullies."
hiddenDepths.node.25: "Oh, well, you didn't have to do that..." Antoine replies, a little stunned. "I'm quite capable on my own..."
hiddenDepths.node.24: "So, Yvette... why, exactly, did you render me that assistance?"
hiddenDepths.node.23: (You have gained some favor with Antoine)
hiddenDepths.node.22: "Ah, but of course, madame!" Thérèse says, stepping out of the shadows.
hiddenDepths.node.21: Once you're certain that you're not being followed anymore, the two of you eventually come to a slow halt. "I must say, I didn't expect you to come to my rescue. You're not half bad, are you?"
hiddenDepths.node.20: "What the devil are you doing out here, prowling about in the middle of the night? I don't know what this is, but I know that you're coming with me, in the name of the King!"
hiddenDepths.node.19: Running as fast as you can, the two of you manage to lead the warman on a merry chase. This comes to an end when the Guet Royal Sergeant manages to twist his ankle on a stone and fall in the river. Hobbled, waterlogged, and generally defeated, he resorts to flailing around in the water and shouting invectives in your direction. It's not very effective.
hiddenDepths.node.18: Well, that was interesting. You have no idea what fresh hell Antoine was up to, but you simply don't have the luxury to take those kind of risks, right now. You go home and consider the events of the night.
hiddenDepths.node.17: Antoine runs off into the night, unaware that you were ever even there.
hiddenDepths.node.16: "Alright, you two! I don't know what's going on here, but I do know that you're both coming with me!"
hiddenDepths.node.15: This merry chase between Antoine and the watchman endures for a while, eventually coming to an end when the Guet Royal Sergeant manages to twist his ankle on a stone and fall in the river. Hobbled, waterlogged, and generally defeated, he resorts to flailing around in the water and shouting invectives at the fleeing Antoine. It's not very effective.
hiddenDepths.node.14: "Go tell your king to catch us himself, you blockheaded lout!" Antoine laughs, as you both take off running.
hiddenDepths.node.13: "Merde!" Antoine snarls while grabbing you by the hand. "We need to leave Yvette, and now!"
hiddenDepths.node.12: (The Revolution has lost a little power)
hiddenDepths.node.11: Just as Antoine sprints away, you see the papers flutter from his grasp. The wind takes these errant pages, and scatters them across the river. Even from this distance, you can hear Antoine utter a barrage of curses at this latest turn of fortune.
hiddenDepths.node.10: "Go tell your king to catch me himself, you blockheaded lout!" Antoine snarls as he takes off running.
hiddenDepths.node.9: Looking up at the sound of the commotion following you, Antoine stops his reading long enough to frantically stuff the letters into his coat. "Yvette? What are you doing here?"
hiddenDepths.node.8: (You have gained a decent amount of peril)
hiddenDepths.node.7: You see the watchman stumble upon Antoine, who seems rather annoyed with this turn of events.
hiddenDepths.node.6: Without a second thought, you pull up the hood of your cloak and rush forward to his position in the dark. Startled, an angry voice yells out "What the devil? You there! Halt, in the name of the King!"
hiddenDepths.node.5: He could be upon Antoine at any moment...
hiddenDepths.node.4: It's then that you see an officer of the Guet Royal approaching Antoine's position. He's not moving directly towards the young revolutionary. Rather, the watchman appears to be stumbling blindly through the dark. However, he is growing dangerously close.
hiddenDepths.node.3: You hide behind an overturned boat and stare into the inky blackness, watching carefully for any sort of movement. He appears to be furiously rummaging amongst some rocks on the river's edge. Suddenly, you see a glint of reflected moonlight as he retrieves a glass bottle, extracts some rolled-up paper from it, and begins to read it by the light of the moon.
hiddenDepths.node.2: Is that Antoine? What is he doing here, skulking in the dark?
hiddenDepths.node.1: Paying a little more attention to your surroundings, you spot a figure moving in the darkness. However, this shape seems somewhat familiar.
hiddenDepths.node.0: You wander the city for a while, and before you realize it, the sun is already setting and you have accomplished nothing particularly useful. With darkness upon you, you find yourself at the docks, and its normal hustle and bustle is replaced with an eerie quiet.
hiddenDepths.link.43: "This isn't your first time doing this sort of thing, is it?"
hiddenDepths.link.42: "You're the one who actually did the deed, Thérèse, you deserve some credit."
hiddenDepths.link.41: "Merveilleuse, Thérèse. I'll take it from here."
hiddenDepths.link.26: "Antoine, I want to know what's on those papers you took from the bottles."
hiddenDepths.link.25: "To be honest, I stumbled upon the whole scene by accident."
hiddenDepths.link.24: "I saw you in danger, and leapt to your defense. Does that need further explanation?"
hiddenDepths.link.6: "Interesting... let's see how this all plays out."
hiddenDepths.link.5: "I need to warn Antoine, there's not a moment to lose!"

unwillingConfessor.node.17: "No, Yvette is correct. Most confessions are the petty sins that trouble the hearts of every man and woman, not great scandals."

unwillingConfessor.link.14: "Ludovico, you should consider his offer. You could do a lot of good with that money."
unwillingConfessor.link.13: "Come now, Pierre. This is beneath you."

oldConnections.node.52: "Oh, it's always nice to see you, little Yvette. I dearly wish I had more time, but it seems that my responsibilities have called me away. You'll be good for me while I'm gone, won't you?"

oldConnections.node.7: "Ah, Madame Gazel, I see you know my dear associate, Yvette. We work together."
oldConnections.node.5: "Ugh! This is impossible! I would rather-"
oldConnections.node.4: Pierre coughs awkwardly and straightens up. “Well, as much as I might enjoy that, I assure you that I shall stand firm against such temptations... in the name of journalism.”
oldConnections.node.3: "Do not test me, you conniving worm! I will not hesitate to thrash you like you've never been before!"
oldConnections.node.2: "Madame, I assure you that I'm only interested in a deal that we would both find mutually beneficial. In fact, let me begin by-"
oldConnections.node.1: "... I've had quite enough. Stop walking around the issue, and just tell me what you want."
oldConnections.node.0: During the course of your exploration of the city, you notice two familiar faces when you're walking through La Place Royale. Honorade and Pierre are talking to each other, and she does not appear to be happy to see him. Then again, most people aren't happy to see him.
oldConnections.link.16: "A Frankish Hapsburgian Society? What's this all about?"
oldConnections.link.15: "Pierre, if you keep this up, we'll have to reconsider our working relationship."
oldConnections.link.14: "Madame Gazel, this is a great opportunity. Perhaps you should take it?"
oldConnections.link.8: "Trust me Pierre, Madame Gazel is not the sort of woman you should be trifling with."
oldConnections.link.7: "Pierre, you are not helping right now."
oldConnections.link.6: "It's true. I've been known to sell some information to Pierre from time to time."
clearingOnesHead.name: Clearing One's Head
clearingOnesHead.node.44: "Unfortunately, I must go, but I hope to see you again, under better circumstances."
clearingOnesHead.node.43: "I hope that you find me to be similarly invigorating."
clearingOnesHead.node.42:
Then, with a bow as formal and precise as always, he departs.

Today seems to have gone quite well.
clearingOnesHead.node.41: "I just wanted say 'thanks', Yvette, for helping me take my mind off of today. I seem to be cursed with a tendency to crawl into my own head, and dwell upon my problems. It's nice to have someone who can pry me out of such dreadful reveries."
clearingOnesHead.node.40: "I just wanted say 'thanks', Yvette, for helping me take my mind off of today. You always seem to know how to brighten even the dourest of my moods."
clearingOnesHead.node.39: As your time together comes to a close, Alex insists on walking you back to your home. Camille heads inside, to get dinner started.
clearingOnesHead.node.38: Eventually, Camille stops attempting to climb Alex like a tree for long enough that you're all able to continue your walk along the river. The conversation is light, and it seems to do quite a bit for calming the dragoon's nerves.
clearingOnesHead.node.37: (You have gained some favor with Alex)
clearingOnesHead.node.36: "...that's a fair point." He laughs. "I've never known you to be one to shrink from difficulty. My apologies, Yvette, for underestimating you so quickly."
clearingOnesHead.node.35: You both walk for a while in silence, considering the implications of such a thing. Considering what could motivate someone towards such things. Could you be pushed to do such a thing, by desperation or necessity?
clearingOnesHead.node.34: Without even a moment's hesitation, Camille jumps up and grabs onto Alex's outstretched arm, swinging from it like a child on a treebranch. To his credit, he holds her up with remarkable ease.
clearingOnesHead.node.33: "He also said that you were the strongest man in all of France! Is that true?"
clearingOnesHead.node.32: Alex decides to join the two of you on your walk. While your unusual trio manages to attract a few stares, it's a small price to pay for good company.
clearingOnesHead.node.31: (You have gained a little favor with Alex)
clearingOnesHead.node.30: You continue with your walk, trying not to over analyze the situation. You manage to be half successful in your efforts, and have a decently relaxing walk.
clearingOnesHead.node.29: "Well, we tried madame, and nobody can hold that against us!" Camille says, in a game attempt to lift your spirits.
clearingOnesHead.node.28: "Pardon, but I must take my leave." He says stiffly, leaving before you even get a chance to respond.
clearingOnesHead.node.27:
(You have lost a little favor with Alex)
(You have lost some credibility)
clearingOnesHead.node.26: "No, I will not hear of it!" Alex barks, his decision final. "I appreciate your curiosity, and I'm sorry for bringing it up, but I will not discuss this further."
clearingOnesHead.node.25: "Fine..." He sighs. "If you wish to know so dearly, my unit was called in to help search the scene of a murder in the city. The police have been overburdened since that business with Reveillon, so they asked for our assistance."
clearingOnesHead.node.24: (You have lost a little favor with Alex)
clearingOnesHead.node.23: "Can you imagine if there was an Estates General for what's adult and what's childish? We could come together and petition the King to declare things like 'Bitter foods aren't more sophisticated' and 'Nothing is funnier than watching a mean and angry person fall down while they're shouting'."
clearingOnesHead.node.22: "It's kind of funny to think that there are certain things you're only allowed to do when you're younger. It's even funnier when you think the adults are the one who make the rules. We can't go splashing in the river because it'd be indecent, but we're the ones who decide if that's true!"
clearingOnesHead.node.21: "Well, there's only one way for us to test that claim!" Alex laughs, holding his arm out at shoulder height. "Grab on!"
clearingOnesHead.node.20: At this, Alex's face takes on a suspiciously neutral expression. "Oh really? It's funny you say that. He’s spoken to me about you, on several occasions. You seem to have made quite the impression on him."
clearingOnesHead.node.19: "Monsieur Dumas, I bumped into your friend, Monsieur d'Auvergne while I was at the market. He told me all of these amazing stories of your adventures in the dragoons together!"
clearingOnesHead.node.18: "The woman that fled the scene was wearing a green dress, and nobody seemed to recognize her. Perhaps it's naive of me to think this way, but to imagine a woman to be involved in such wanton brutality has been truly unsettling."
clearingOnesHead.node.17: "I saw the body and learned the details of the case. I've seen my fair share of violence but this felt different, somehow. The victim, an elderly merchant, was pinned face-down on a table, and had his throat slit like an animal. What distresses me more is that a woman was seen fleeing the scene, carrying a bundle of papers."
clearingOnesHead.node.16: "Don't worry, Monsieur Dumas! I'm certain that Madame Yvette can-"
clearingOnesHead.node.15: "I'm sorry Yvette, but I just can't talk about this."
clearingOnesHead.node.14: "It was barely dawn when my unit was called in to help search the scene of a murder in the city. The police have been overburdened since that business with Reveillon, so they asked for our assistance."
clearingOnesHead.node.13: "Merci beaucoups, I appreciate your willingness to let this go. As much as I'm delighted by your natural curiosity, I don't think I could have been comfortable discussing that."
clearingOnesHead.node.12: "Yvette, that's unfair and you know it."
clearingOnesHead.node.11: Alex doesn't say anything at first. Instead, he stares out at the river for some time.
clearingOnesHead.node.10: "Actually, now that I consider the details, I’m not sure you need to hear this…"
clearingOnesHead.node.9: "Not at the moment. Right now, I'm merely stretching my legs and doing my best to clear my head. It's as I told you when we first met, I truly adore this city. It's been years and I still like to wander its streets for the sake of finding some new sight I've missed."
clearingOnesHead.node.8: "Today, I was called in to deal with something... extremely unpleasant, and I must admit that it's disquieted me more than I expected it to."
clearingOnesHead.node.7: "Ah, it's that obvious then? Yes, I've run across something particularly troubling during the course of my duties, and I needed to clear my head."
clearingOnesHead.node.6: "Not at the moment. Right now, I'm merely stretching my legs and doing my best to clear my head. To put it simply, I adore this city. It's been years and I still like to wander its streets for the sake of finding some new sight I've missed."
clearingOnesHead.node.5: "Ah! My apologies Yvette. I didn't see you there."
clearingOnesHead.node.4: You find yourself so absorbed in this idea that you nearly walk straight into Alex, who was standing at the water's edge, uncharacteristically quiet.
clearingOnesHead.node.3: "You know, madame, I've been in Paris my whole life and I've never once swam in the Seine?" She says, gesturing to the river. "My brothers used to play in it all the time when they were little, but I never really got around to it. Now if I stripped down and went in the river, everyone would think I'd gone mad."
clearingOnesHead.node.2: The two of you walk side by side as you chat. While this kind of public familiarity with one's servants is certainly a breach of etiquette, it's also much harder to have a conversation with someone walking a respectful distance behind you. Camille was a little uncomfortable with this new arrangement at first, but she's enjoying the change of pace.
clearingOnesHead.node.1: Then again, it's not like there's anyone else in your house to ask.
clearingOnesHead.node.0: You spend the day walking along the river with Camille. You didn't feel like going out along, and he was helpful enough to volunteer.
clearingOnesHead.link.11: "It's alright, you don't need to discuss it, if you don't want to."
clearingOnesHead.link.10: "Ah, so you don't think I can withstand the burden of a simple story?"
clearingOnesHead.link.9: "Alex, I'm made of sterner stuff than that. You can tell me."
clearingOnesHead.link.6: "It's quite alright. Are you on duty at the moment?"
clearingOnesHead.link.3: "It's quite alright. Are you on duty at the moment?"
blackBooksAndSecrets.name: Black Books and Secrets
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.52:
It is the end of another strange but eventful day. In this particular case, you walk home with a new spymistress in tow.

How did your life get like this?
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.51: She leaves, and you are left to the rest of your day. A day that's mostly spent relaxing in the sun dappled gentility of La Place Royale.
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.50: "Well, at least I'm not off to rot in a cell somewhere." She replies with an indifferent shrug.
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.49: (You have hired Thérèse, the Spy Mistress!)
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.48: "Fantastique! You shall not regret this, madame."
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.47: "Well, you didn't perform terribly, but with my help, you could be even better."
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.46: With a string of skin-blistering curses, he storms off, leaving you alone with Thérèse.
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.45: "Merde!" He curses to himself as he sense the mood of the crowd shifting strongly against him. "You two dingbats simply aren't worth it. Be warned, if I ever catch the two of you scheming anywhere else in this city, you'll both be doing time!"
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.44: The watchman starts to drag Thérèse away, but you reflexively try to get between the two of the them. When he shoves you, a crowd of onlookers gasp at the sight of this lawman abusing two regular looking women. Apparently, they're not used to seeing the kind of things that play out every day in the other neighborhoods of Paris.
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.43:
(You have lost quite a bit of credibility)
(You have gained a decent amount of peril)
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.42: Despite her growing protests, the woman is dragged away, and you're left to the rest of your day. A day that's mostly spent relaxing in the sun dappled gentility of La Place Royale.
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.41: "Hmph, my apologies madame, I must have had you confused for someone else."
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.40: "Generally speaking, my services cost fifty livres per week."
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.39: Absent-mindedly, she rubs her right shoulder "...and there have been failures. Nevertheless, I'm in your debt, and I'd like to offer my services, as a spy mistress. I can help you avoid clandestine troubles, as well as help you determine the next steps of those who wish to court you."
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.38: "To be quite honest, I'm getting a little old to be pulling the same ruses I used to. They were good when I was still spry, but I don't bounce back from failure quite as quick, anymore..."
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.37: "Well, that was some fine work. You're already pretty good at this Yvette, but with my help, you could be even better."
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.35: "Don't bother the good woman over there with your honeyed lies!" The watchman interjects, grabbing Thérèse roughly by the arm.
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.34: With that he marches away, leaving you alone with Thérèse.
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.33: "Well, you fine ladies should get going. For my part, I must continue my duties searching for criminals and villains... anywhere other than here."
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.32: "Ah, yes!" He says with an unsubtle wink as he takes the money from you. "The customary pre-emptive posting of bail! A fine tradition that has served our good city since time immemorial."
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.31: "I can safely assure you that neither of those are my name. Certainly that means you have the wrong person, non?"
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.30: "Good monsieur, I can't possibly know what you're talking about..." The woman replies with the most ingratiating smile that she can manage.
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.29: "Then again, a poor old spinster like myself has to make money somehow, doesn't she?"
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.28: "Oh, don't worry madame, you can count on me!"
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.27: "Via his trade with the famous princes of the Onitsha Kingdom in the African Continent, my dear." She replies with an indulgent smile. "Of course, I will be paying you a handsome finder's fee"
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.26: "Yes, yes... that all makes sense to me. How did he makes this considerable fortune again?"
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.25: "Well, I can certainly assure you that the Onitsha Kingdom does exist, but other than that... I've never even been married."
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.23: "That is absolutely preposterous, and I should haul you both in for interfering with my arrest!"
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.22: "Well, the resemblance does appear to be there... and the woman I'm searching for has no known relations..." The watchman says, squinting as he glances suspiciously between the two of you.
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.21: "What? You're going to just stand there while-"
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.20: "You want to what? How dare you-" The watchman starts, until he notices the small pouch of coins that you're pulling from your pockets.
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.17: She leans a touch closer and whispers to you. "If you help me out of this, I could work for you. I'm far too old, and far too beautiful to go to prison again."
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.16: "Don't waste your time with flattery Madame von Hershberger, or should I say 'Madame de Gramont'?"
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.15: Your ears perk up at the sound of rapidly approaching footsteps. "Ah! You again! Returned to the scene of the crime, I see!"
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.14: "It's necessary for a woman of my profession to stay informed." She replies, as if that explains everything.
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.13: "By the way, what was it like to deal with Maximin? I'd always had my suspicions about his romantic pursuits, but I could never really get my hands on any proof..." She says, snapping the same black book shut.
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.12: "By the way, what was it like to deal with Marcelle? I'd always had my suspicions about her father, but I could never really get my hands on any proof..." She says, snapping the same black book shut.
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.11: Noticing your eavesdropping, the woman glances at you, and snaps open a small black book. For a few seconds, her eyes dance across its pages. "Ah yes, you're Yvette Decaux. You recently arrived in Paris to meet with your fiancé, Armand."
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.10: Without another question, the man leaves, presumably to fetch the information this mysterious woman requested.
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.9: "It's the only way I can transfer my dear, departed husband's assets into my name. It was a precaution to make sure that I'm not taken advantage of when I inherit his considerable fortune."
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.8: "And all you need is my signature, and my banking information... and you'll name me as the executor of your will?"
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.7: With your goal for the day accomplished, you find yourself about to leave, until you notice a very interesting conversation taking place in the shadow of the statue that dominates the center of the square.
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.6: (You have gained a piece of Cheap Revolution Gossip)
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.5: (You have gained a piece of Cheap Bourgeoisie Gossip)
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.4: (You have gained a piece of Cheap Military Gossip)
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.3: (You have gained a piece of Cheap Church Gossip)
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.2: (You have gained a piece of Cheap Crown Gossip)
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.1: After an hour or so, you manage to overhear something useful. Pierre will be very interested in this.
blackBooksAndSecrets.node.0: Staying on the absolute edge of conversations, you stroll about the square, pretending to be a traveler just admiring the apartments and gardens.
blackBooksAndSecrets.link.53: "I'm sorry, but my household has no such openings." <Don't Hire Thérèse>
blackBooksAndSecrets.link.51: "That sounds reasonable. Welcome to my household." <Hire Thérèse>
blackBooksAndSecrets.link.25: "Was anything you said to that man true, or was it all lies?"
blackBooksAndSecrets.link.24: "How do you know all of that?"
blackBooksAndSecrets.link.23: "Was anything you said to that man true, or was it all lies?"
blackBooksAndSecrets.link.22: "How do you know all of that?"
blackBooksAndSecrets.link.15: "I'm sorry, but you brought this upon yourself."
blackBooksAndSecrets.link.14: "Pardon, good sir, but would it be possible for me to pre-emptively post her bail?"
blackBooksAndSecrets.link.13: "You must have the wrong woman, I will have you know that this is my mother sir."
aWearyWoman.name: A Weary Woman
aWearyWoman.node.64: (You currently have no levels of exhaustion. Coffee can reduce exhaustion, but it cannot make you well rested)
aWearyWoman.node.63: With that, she leaves, and you return to your normal business at the cafe.
aWearyWoman.node.62: "Well, it seems like it's time for me to go out and start looking for introductions until I find a new patron." She says, draining the coffee and standing up. "Thanks for listening, Yvette."
aWearyWoman.node.61:
(The Bourgeoisie has gained a little power)
(The Bourgeoisie has moved towards the Crown a little)
aWearyWoman.node.60: Of course, you also know that having one of their leading figures painted by Élisabeth and shown off in all of the latest salons will do good things for the Bourgeoisie's image. Little moments like these add up, after all.

aWearyWoman.node.47: "That's a great idea! The Bourgeoisie loves the Crown right now, which means my past work with Marie should open some doors."

aWearyWoman.node.38: "Of course, neither of them bothered to inform me of their plans, so I had the privilege of finding out by arriving at their house for our next sitting, only to find the place abandoned. Now I have to work double-time just to drum up new work, and it's killing me."

aWearyWoman.node.35: Any new patron of hers would gain influence, but they'd need to be loyal to the Crown.
aWearyWoman.node.34: "Yes, please, beautiful angel of steam. Bring me coffee..." Élisabeth says to Marguerite, otherwise doing her best to not simply pass out at the table.

theStormOfDiscourse.node.114: You get drawn into a conversation about the Bourgeoisie and the Revolution. theStormOfDiscourse.node.2: You listen for what feels like an hour and you still can’t draw a solid conclusion. The Crown and the Revolution are so evenly matched that you can’t determine which would prevail in any sort of conflict. The victor would most certainly be determined by the strength of their alliances.
theStormOfDiscourse.node.1: After a few minutes, it becomes obvious that the Crown is significantly more powerful than the Revolution. While it might be possible for the Revolution to make the Crown give into their demands, they would have to build strong alliances with the other factions in order to do so.
theStormOfDiscourse.node.0: Taking out your journal and a pencil, you close your eyes and relax, just listening to the bustling café. Not focusing on one individual, but letting the sum total of the room flow into your ears, and assessing it all together. Occasionally, you open your eyes to jot down notes.
theStormOfDiscourse.link.220: "The Revolution is right. If the people can't make changes exactly when they need them, then when?"
theStormOfDiscourse.link.218: "The Crown is right. The King needs his powers to keep France away from tragedy."
theStormOfDiscourse.link.216: "The Revolution is right. The different faiths should be granted equal representation in the First Estate."
theStormOfDiscourse.link.214: "I stand with the Church. This is a Catholic nation, which means the Catholic church takes priority."
theStormOfDiscourse.link.212: "The Revolution's right. Soldiers must protect us from foreign tyrants, not assist local ones."
theStormOfDiscourse.link.210: "The Military is right. If you don't like how they act, then change the laws."
theStormOfDiscourse.link.208: "The Revolution is right. The wealthiest in France have a duty to the poor."
theStormOfDiscourse.link.206: "It's as the Bourgeoisie say. This puts more burden on the same people, instead of fighting the real problem."
theStormOfDiscourse.link.204: "The Bourgeoisie is right, easy trade makes a healthier economy. That means a wealthier France."
theStormOfDiscourse.link.202: "The Crown is right. Loosening the rules could make it possible for the economy to fly out of control."
theStormOfDiscourse.link.200: "The Bourgeoisie is right. If the Church wants to be able to own land, they should have to pay taxes."
theStormOfDiscourse.link.198: "The Church is right. Their mission is to God and the poor, taxes aren't their responsibility."
theStormOfDiscourse.link.196: "I support the Bourgeoisie. They have every right to only do business with the customers they trust."
theStormOfDiscourse.link.194: "I support the Military. What are the soldiers supposed to do, starve?"

parismap.description.incidentUnwillingCo: It appears that Pierre is trying to convince Father Sidotti to participate in some unsavory scheme of his. This might be a prime opportunity to get on either of their good sides.
parismap.description.incidentClearingOne: Taking a break to walk alongside the river with Camille, you come across Alex, who appears to be quite troubled by something he’s seen.
parismap.description.incidentOldConnecti: What could Honorade and Pierre, of all people, possibly have to say to each other? Whatever it is, Honorade doesn’t look very interested in hearing it. This might be a good chance to earn the favor of at least one of them.
parismap.description.incidentHiddenDepth: While going for a late night stroll, you come across a vague shadow rooting around in the dark. Is that a familiar, fiery revolutionary? What shadowy intrigues could he be up to at this hour? Perhaps it’s time for you to find out.
parismap.description.incidentAnUncertain: You take the day to visit the markets at Les Halles with Camille. In addition to learning some things about her sprawling family tree, you also manage to gain some insights into how she feels about the current situation in Paris.
parismap.description.incidentADanceToget: Exploring the streets of Paris, you happen to run into your newly rediscovered fiancé. He suggests that the two of you take a break from your normal routines in order to simply enjoy life in Paris a little. He's always been rather convincing...
parismap.description.incidentWorkingUpTh: You happen to find the dressmaker, Fatima Shenna, outside of a fashionable cafe. However, she doesn’t look that happy to be there. In fact, she looks quite distressed.
cafePrincipe.name: Café Principe
cafePrincipe.node.14: With a barely suppressed scowl, she leaves you to your business.
cafePrincipe.node.13: Marguerite returns with your water, placing and simple cup and jug on your table.
cafePrincipe.node.12: You sip at your drink, and get settled in. It feels familiar, like a louder and livelier version of ‘Le Cygne’, a public house you used to frequent back home.
cafePrincipe.node.11: (You currently have no levels of exhaustion. Coffee can reduce exhaustion, but it cannot make you well rested)
cafePrincipe.node.10: (You have lost one level of exhaustion)
cafePrincipe.node.9: You take a sip of the powerful brew while Marguerite leaves to attend to other tables. Immediately, its invigorating effects become apparent.
cafePrincipe.node.8: She returns with your coffee, steaming and hot. The porcelain cup clinks lightly as she sets it down, along with containers of sugar and milk.
cafePrincipe.node.7: She gives you a quick curtsey before she checks in with another table, taking their order as well. You sigh and take in the café around you. The whole place hums with excitement, as patrons make new pronouncements and trade verbal barbs with their compatriots.
cafePrincipe.node.6: With a scowl, she skulks away to attend to the other customers, while you applaud yourself for your thriftiness.
cafePrincipe.node.4: “Oui, madame. I shall fetch you free water, while you occupy a table in our busy cafe.”
cafePrincipe.node.1: Finding a seat at an empty table, you’re approached by Marguerite, the waitress. "Welcome back!"
cafePrincipe.node.0: You arrive at Café Principe to find it, as always packed with customers engaged in animate conversation and gesticulating wildly with cups of steaming coffee.
cafePrincipe.link.3: “May I just have some water, please?”
theNewAristocracy.name: The New Aristocracy
theNewAristocracy.description: Madame Gazel is considering the position of the Bourgeoisie and how it relates to the Crown and the Revolution. This feels like a prime opportunity to exert some influence upon her decisions.
theNewAristocracy.node.34: Without another word, Thérèse snaps her black book shut, and falls into place behind you.
theNewAristocracy.node.33: Without another word, Thérèse snaps her black book shut, and falls into place behind you.
theNewAristocracy.node.32: (You have gained a little favor with Honorade)
theNewAristocracy.node.31: (You have gained a little favor with Honorade)
theNewAristocracy.node.30: "A fine assessment." Madame Gazel says with a nod of satisfaction. "Oh Yvette, you always employ the finest people."
theNewAristocracy.node.29: "A fine assessment." Madame Gazel says with a nod of satisfaction. "Oh Yvette, you always employ the finest people."
theNewAristocracy.node.28: And so, another piece moves on the grand chessboard of Paris. The only question is, is anyone moving you around on the board?
theNewAristocracy.node.27: You chat with Honorade a touch longer, until she excuses herself to begin one of the very meetings she mentioned.
theNewAristocracy.node.26: (The Bourgeoisie has moved towards the Revolution a little)
theNewAristocracy.node.25: (The Bourgeoisie has moved towards the Crown a little)
theNewAristocracy.node.24: "Regardless, you have a point and, I should make some entreaties to the revolutionaries soon. Unlike some of my peers, I have no delusions of reigning over my own tiny kingdom, so I might actually make some progress."
theNewAristocracy.node.23: "Regardless, you have a point and I should still look into opening conversations with my more tolerable acquaintances as soon as I can, and see if that produces anything of value. They are the more stable solution for the troubles of France."
theNewAristocracy.node.22: "Given the direction everything is heading, I should start positioning myself sooner rather than later. Some of my peers being insufferable isn't a reason to make a poor political decision."
theNewAristocracy.node.21: "As loathe as I am to deal with any more condescension than I have to, I'll reach out to some of my more tolerable acquaintances amongst the nobility as soon as I can, and see if that produces anything of value." She says aloud, more to herself than anyone else. "It's best to go where you're already wanted."
theNewAristocracy.node.20: Whoever she reaches out to will surely gain from her support, but she might react poorly to suggesting someone that has a poor relationship with the Bourgeoisie, at the moment.
theNewAristocracy.node.19: "... as if titles bought with money were more virtuous than ones bought with blood..." She sighs and takes a sip of her water.
theNewAristocracy.node.18: Not that either of you mind, of course.
theNewAristocracy.node.17:
(You have lost a little favor with Honorade)

theNewAristocracy.node.13: "No, that can't be right Yvette." She says with a furrow in her brow. "The Revolution currently sees the Bourgeoisie as a pack of avaricious cravens.
theNewAristocracy.node.12: "Yes, you're absolutely right. The Revolution and the Bourgeoisie do seem to be getting along quite well at the moment, despite some of my more irritating peers' best efforts."
theNewAristocracy.node.11: "No, that can't be right Yvette." She says with a furrow in her brow. "The Crown currently sees the Bourgeoisie as a pack of overly ambitious upstarts."
theNewAristocracy.node.10: "Yes, you're absolutely right. The crown and the bourgeoisie do seem to be getting along quite well at the moment, which I must admit is a bit of a surprise."
theNewAristocracy.node.9: "The Revolution and the Bourgeoisie as a whole are aligned for the moment." She says, pausing to squint through her glasses at her own writing. "Which makes sense, they're both groups of commoners."
theNewAristocracy.node.8: "The Crown and the Bourgeoisie as a whole are aligned for the moment." She says, pausing to squint through her glasses at her own writing. "Which makes sense, they're the two wealthiest groups in France."
theNewAristocracy.node.7: At the sound of your summons, Thérèse steps out from her position nearby and opens her small black book, looking through her notes. "Of course, madame..."
theNewAristocracy.node.4: Madame Gazel swirls her water thoughtfully.
theNewAristocracy.node.3: "Regardless, I'm not even certain who I should be making entreaties to. All of Paris is picking sides, and it would be nice to reach out to someone we already have a good relationship with."
theNewAristocracy.node.2: "Now, I must admit that most aristocrats I've spoken to are tiresome boors that get some kind of carnal thrill from reminding you of their privileged station. I've met some wonderful counter examples, but it feels like a case of exceptions that prove the rule."
theNewAristocracy.node.1: "... what irritates me so is that for all their complaints about the aristocracy, there are more than enough powerful members of the bourgeoisie who clearly just want to become the new nobility. They play at revolutionary talk and preach about fairness, but they're not really opposed to the order of the ancien régime, merely whose running it."
theNewAristocracy.node.0: Due to flow of the party and the vagaries of guests wandering to and fro, you find yourself having a conversation alone with Madame Gazel.
theNewAristocracy.link.4: "Thérèse, you're an expert in these things. What do you think?"
theNewAristocracy.link.3: "Isn't the bourgeoisie already sympathetic to the revolution? That might work."
theNewAristocracy.link.2: "If you want friends, it seems like the crown already favors you."
selfInterest.name: Self Interest
selfInterest.description: Élisabeth, the painter, seems to find herself at a loss as to the Crown’s position in the political landscape of Paris. She’s looking for advice, which might change which faction the Crown courts, moving forward.
selfInterest.node.43: She excuses herself, and you're left to your own devices once more. Perhaps there's something else you can still accomplish at this party.
selfInterest.node.42: Your conversation continues for a while longer, but you can tell that Élisabeth's attention has become focused instead on your suggestion.
selfInterest.node.41: (The bourgeoisie has gained a little power)
selfInterest.node.40: (The military has gained a little power)
selfInterest.node.39: (The church has gained a little power)
selfInterest.node.38: "Well, regardless, I should still reach out to the church. No matter their opinion on His Majesty, perhaps they'll just like me, personally."

selfInterest.node.28: "Ugh!" She sighs. "It really feels like everything is coming apart at the seams, and everyone's just scrabbling for whatever crumbs they can find. What if His Majesty really can't keep France together? I have my daughter, Julie, to think about and..."
selfInterest.node.27: With that, he leaves in order to initiate a transactional romance of the sort that the world has... honestly seen quite a few of already.
selfInterest.node.26: "Ah, yes! Remind me not to get on your bad side."
selfInterest.node.25: "I sorry to report that the crown doesn't really have any allies to speak of, at this time. There isn't really a good answer here."
selfInterest.node.24: "At this time, the Crown has friends everywhere, madame. You truly can't pick a wrong choice here."
selfInterest.node.23: "The bourgeoisie is certainly aligned with the crown, for the moment."

selfInterest.node.21: "The church is certainly aligned with the crown, for the moment."
selfInterest.node.20: "Ugh! That can't be right! Last I heard, the church is already fawning all over these new revolutionaries. At this rate, there'll be nobody left for me to reach out to, at all."
selfInterest.node.19: "That does seem like a good idea! Last I heard, at least, they still cared for us. Hopefully, that still holds true."
