alexsInvitation.name: Alex's Invitation
alexsInvitation.node.7: You consider his offer, and realize that you could join him for this 'day of enchantment and gallantry' today, should you so desire.
alexsInvitation.node.6: ('Monsieur de L'Humanite' is now available to visit in the Paris map)
alexsInvitation.node.4: 'Still, that's no excuse, and I would like to make this lapse up to you as soon as possible, if you would let me. Send a signal to me, and I shall whisk you away to a day of enchantment and gallantry, the likes of which you've never seen!'
alexsInvitation.node.3: 'Chère Yvette, I would like to apologize for my absence as of late. As you can imagine, my duties to my unit have kept me busy indeed.'
alexsInvitation.node.2: In your hands, a letter opener is as powerful and deft as a saber, and the wax seal falls easily to your attack. As always, his penmanship on the letter is disciplined and precise.
alexsInvitation.node.1: You're already quite familiar with the seal, and the unassuming quality of the paper. This was most certainly written by Alex.
alexsInvitation.node.0: The sweltering heat of the last few days continues unabated, as does the discontent that you can hear, even through your shuttered windows. However, you also notice a letter on your vanity, sealed in blue wax.
theChampionOfTheWeak.name: Monsieur de L'Humanite
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.96: Perhaps, this is exactly what you needed.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.94:
It's not a grand day, bedecked with finery, or stymied with pretension. However, it's a carefree and genuine one, that serves to lift your spirits in a way that nothing else would. 

It makes you feel like everything is going to be alright.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.93: You spend the day promenading up and down the river with Alex. You drink many toasts, to his latest accomplishments, and to your future together. Something about your open merriment proves infectious amidst the tension of the streets. People smile in your direction, or doff their caps as you two walk past, arm in arm.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.92: "Enough worry, though! I promised you a lovely day, and I intend to deliver on that promise!"
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.91: "I don't blame them." He says, gesturing to the people scurrying onto their boats. "Things are likely to get worse around here before they get better."
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.90: Looking at the river banks, you can't help but notice just how many people are preparing to flee the city. People with money, at least. No matter what happens, the poorest people are usually forced to contend with the consequences, whatever they may be.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.89: He grumbles to himself "Mon Dieu, I've met people that spent their whole lives scrounging in the dirt with better manners than that man."
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.88: "All at once, the labels fell off, and we couldn't remember who to return the wine to!"
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.87: "After days of tracking these thieves down, the most incredible thing happened when we found the wine."
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.86: With a tug of the reins, Joseph takes off down the street at a reasonable clip.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.84: "Absolutely not. The people and their needs have gone unheard for far too long in this country. To them!" He grumbles as he weakly clinks his cup against your own.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.83: (The Military's allegiance has moved towards the Crown by quite a bit)
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.82: "That's a great point, Yvette. To the Crown! Viva la roi!" He laughs as he merrily clinks his cup against your own.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.81: (The Military's allegiance has moved towards the Revolution by quite a bit)
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.80: (The Military's allegiance has moved towards the Revolution by quite a bit)
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.78: "Absolutely not. The Crown has given me success and freedom. I can never turn my back on that. Viva la Roix!" He grumbles as he weakly clinks his cup against your own.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.77: "You're right!" He agrees, before merrily clinking his cup against your own. "To the people of France, and the happiness they deserve."
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.76: (The Military's allegiance has moved towards the Crown by quite a bit)
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.75: (You have gained some favor with Alex)
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.74: He reaches back and squeezes your hand. "Which is thanks to a certain someone I know."
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.73: He pauses, lost in thought for a moment before saying "Thank you for asking."
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.72: (You have gained a decent amount of favor with Alex)
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.71: "I don't know if this means that you truly trust me, or if you're simply toying with me. Either way, I'm enjoying it."
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.70: Alex manages to catch you, despite his face being frozen in a mask of shock. A passing crowd favors you with some whoops and cheers, and Alex replies with a theatrical wave.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.69: Alex stops to tie Joseph to a hitching post, and then the two of you start to promenade beside the river, tin cups of fine champagne still in hand.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.68: (You have gained some favor with Alex)
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.67: You take his hand, and he gently helps you down from the horse. The gesture reminds you of a different time, a more chivalrous age.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.66: Without warning, you leap from the saddle into his arms.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.65: Alex gets down off the horse first, and holds out his hand to you.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.64: As Joseph starts to slow down, you look around and realize that you've arrived at your destination, wherever it is.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.63: (You have gained some favor with Alex)
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.62: (You have lost a little favor with Alex)
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.61: (You have gained a little favor with Alex)
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.60: "Besides, my unit's been stationed in Paris for far too long, and I think Joseph needed the exercise." He gives the horse an affectionate pat on the side of the neck.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.59: (You have gained a little favor with Alex)
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.58: (You have lost a little favor with Alex)
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.57: "I suppose they won't, but my superiors already have their hands full with civil unrest and safeguarding their own careers, so I don't think they'll mind all that much."
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.56: While you can see his face from your position, you can hear the frown in his voice. "Happy with what? Using my horse for personal business?"
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.55: "I was inspired by a feeling, Yvette. Today, I woke up feeling more like myself than any other day in my life.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.54: "Yes, I think I'm alright." He says. "I can finally put it behind me, and think of the future."
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.53: You uncork the champagne with a jolly pop and carefully pour yourselves two tin cups of fine drink. You pass his cup up to him, and he holds it aloft in one hand.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.52: He laughs "While I appreciate your good taste, there's no need to be greedy. The Count has learned his lesson, and we have fine champagne. Everyone is better off than they were!"
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.51: "I swore an oath to the King and Queen, not to wretches like that Count. If he cared so much about lost property, he should have been more polite to the people risking their lives to help him."
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.50: "I'm glad you agree! In the grand scheme of things, the Count didn't lose much, and he received a simple lesson in how to treat those supposedly beneath him."
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.49: "When we were first called to hunt the thieves down, the Count in charge of the winery was dreadfully inhospitable towards us." He says with such a carefree air that you can only assume that this nobleman was completely unbearable.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.48: "Do you like our spoils of battle? I might have... appropriated the champagne from some fearsome brigands who had looted a winery a few months back."
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.47: You sip the champagne, to find that it's shockingly good. It must have cost a fortune.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.46: (The Military's allegiance has moved towards the Crown by quite a bit)
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.45: (You have gained a little favor with Alex)
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.43: "I certainly can't say no to that." He laughs as he merrily clinks his cup against your own. "To his Majesty, and to us!"
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.42: "Really?" He asks with a note of surprise, before he merrily clinks his cup against your own. "Yes! To the Queen, the King, and all their descendants!"
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.40: "I certainly can't say no to that." He laughs as he merrily clinks his cup against your own. "To the Revolution and to us!"
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.39: "Really?" He asks with a note of surprise, before he merrily clinks his cup against your own. "Yes! To the people, and the nation that is rightfully theirs."
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.38: "Indeed, to the Revolutionaries, France, and a constitution!" He laughs softly as he clinks his cup against your own.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.37: "I certainly can't say no to that." He laughs as he merrily clinks his cup against your own. "To us!"
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.36: "Indeed, to the King! Viva la Roi!" He laughs as he merrily clinks his cup against your own.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.35: He a low voice he says "I'm thinking, to the Revolutionaries, France, and a constitution!"
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.34: "It appears that I'm at a loss. Any thoughts?"
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.33: "How about... 'To his Majesty the King, long may he reign!'?"
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.32: "Now, what should we toast to?" He mumbles to himself.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.31: "Would you mind pouring me a glass?"
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.30: "Nobody else in my unit knows about it yet, but I wanted to celebrate it with you first."
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.29: "I was promoted this morning. You're now riding with Sergeant Dumas of the Queen's Royal Dragoons." He says, puffing out his chest.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.28: Momentarily worried by the prospect of having to shoot someone, you flip open the leather flap on his saddle holster to reveal an unlabeled magnum of champagne, and two tin cups.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.27: You hold onto Alex's firm waist, thinking about everything that's happened.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.26: It's enough to make you feel like a princess in a fairy tale. Hopefully, it's one of the nice fairy tales. Not the ones with all the torture.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.25: However, on a horse, you're holding yourself up on a living pedestal for all the world to see. People stare, and children point. You inspire awe, by being so public.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.24: There's something special about riding a horse. Being in a carriage, you inspire mystery, as you wind through the streets hidden from view. The public is left to wonder about your identity, your appearance, your intentions.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.23: With a tug of the reins and an enthusiastic yell, Joseph rears up and you grab onto Alex instinctively. Together, you take off down the street at a good clip.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.22: (You have lost a little favor with Alex)
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.21: (You have earned some favor with Alex)
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.20: (You have earned a little favor with Alex)
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.19: "Ah! Ever the woman of action! I love it."
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.18: "Well, I was just hoping you'd hold me close, but yes, I do like know you're safe."
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.17: "Don't worry, I'm one of the best riders in my unit. You'll be fine." He replies, unenthusiastically.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.15: You place a hand on the back of the saddle and he grabs you by the middle of your forearm. On the count of three, you jump up, and he pulls you the rest of the way onto the horse. Thankfully, you already know how to ride sidesaddle, or this would be quite undignified.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.14: (You have earned a little favor with Alex)
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.13: Alex affectionately tousle's his steed's mane with a free hand. Joseph gives an appreciative neigh in response.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.12: "I named him Joseph!" He laughs. "I haven't heard any complaints from him yet, so I can only assume he likes it."
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.11: (You have lost a little favor with Alex)
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.10: (You have earned some favor with Alex)
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.8: He looks somewhat taken aback. "I'm not joking. I was hoping to offer you a ride tonight."
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.7: "I was hoping you'd say that." Alex says, as he adjusts himself further back in his saddle.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.6: "Madame, you look far too beautiful to be walking the streets. May Joseph and I assist you?"
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.5: Alex is already waiting for you outside, astride a brilliant white horse. Everything on his uniform is perfectly in place, and the leather polished to a mirror's shine.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.4: That's when you're greeted by something truly surprising.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.3: With a light step you head downstairs and Camille opens the front door for you.
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.2: He turns to you with a mischievous grin. "Yvette, can you check my holster?"
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.1: (The Military's allegiance has moved towards the Revolution by quite a bit)
theChampionOfTheWeak.node.0: Getting ready for your day with Alex, you check your makeup in the mirror one last time. Flawless, as per usual.
theChampionOfTheWeak.link.105: "This champagne is exquisite. You should have taken two bottles."
theChampionOfTheWeak.link.104: "When you steal from thieves, it's no longer theft?"
theChampionOfTheWeak.link.57: "Will your superiors be happy with you doing all of this with... Joseph?"
theChampionOfTheWeak.link.55: "Are you alright, considering all the stuff that happened with your father?"
theChampionOfTheWeak.link.41: "Are you sure? How about something to the people of France? To our nation?"
theChampionOfTheWeak.link.40: "I like that. To the Crown and to us!"
theChampionOfTheWeak.link.39: "Yes, let the Crown and the Bourbon dynasty last a thousand years."
theChampionOfTheWeak.link.38: "Are you sure? Don't you owe your freedom and new rank to the Crown?"
theChampionOfTheWeak.link.37: "I like that. To the Revolution and to us!"
theChampionOfTheWeak.link.36: "Why stop there? To France ruled by the people, and for the people!"
theChampionOfTheWeak.link.35: "To the people of France, and the Revolutionaries!"
theChampionOfTheWeak.link.34: "How about... To us, and to your success!"
theChampionOfTheWeak.link.33: "To his Majesty, the King! Long may he reign."
theChampionOfTheWeak.link.17: "Only when you show me just how fast Joseph can go."
parismap.description.missionTheChampionO: Alex has invited you out for a ‘day of enchantment and gallantry, the likes of which you've never seen’. Perhaps you should take him up on such a generous offer?
emigre.name: Émigré
emigre.node.218: "Why, in fact I am! Personally, I'd suggest that we go to Rome. It's warm, not far from the sea, and I'm sure that I can find many interesting clients to paint. "
emigre.node.217: "Sorry, I just assumed that we would... never mind."
emigre.node.216: "I guess this is where we part ways, then."
emigre.node.214: She leaves, making no attempt to hide that she's hurt. You're not sure how you know it, but you know that this was the last time you'd ever see Élisabeth.
emigre.node.213: "Au revoir, Yvette. I think we have a boat to catch."
emigre.node.212: "Well, Julia and I are heading to Rome next. Maybe I'll be able to pick up some clients there."
emigre.node.211: "Sorry, I just assumed that we would... never mind."
emigre.node.210: "What next, madame?" Camille asks, already dreaming of Rome.
emigre.node.209: "Oh! Bonsoir Madame Le Brun, are you joining us on our boat ride?"
emigre.node.208: Camille approaches you and whispers. "Uh, madame... I just finished packing your things onto the boat, and the sailors are telling us that we'll need to leave soon."
emigre.node.207: She wraps her arms around you, and quickly gives you a peck on the cheek. It's not enough to draw too much attention, but just enough to let you know of her intentions later.
emigre.node.206: "Oh, we are going to make such glorious art together!"
emigre.node.205: Elisabeth stares at you in giddy shock for a few moments, mouth agape.
emigre.node.204: Without another word, Alex turns and marches back towards the shore. Towards the city and the people he swore to protect.
emigre.node.203: He pauses to tenderly kiss your forehead, and stares into your eyes. It's as if he was memorizing every last detail.
emigre.node.201: It is not just silence. Silence is the absence of noise. Alex and Élisabeth greet your reply with something so quiet, that it devours all the sound around it.
emigre.node.200: "What? What are you saying? I just thought-" Élisabeth gasps.
emigre.node.199: "I guess this is where we part ways, then."
emigre.node.198: "Well, not about this... it's just that we're here at the same time and..."
emigre.node.197: "Oh really, you and Yvette agreed to travel together?" Alex asks, his eyebrow raised. "I didn't realize the two of you were planning maneuvers together."
emigre.node.196: "Well, at least you're here, Yvette. Once we reach the coast we can head to Rome. I have some potential clients there, and there are much worse places to start over.
emigre.node.195: "My husband Jean is staying behind. He thinks he can keep the art dealership going, but I simply don't know anymore."
emigre.node.194: "I have other responsibilities." She gestures to her daughter, who has collapsed in an undignified heap on top of the bags.
emigre.node.193: "Absolutely. Even if I wanted to stay amidst, all of this upheaval..."
emigre.node.192: "Ah, Madame Le Brun I take it?" Alex asks. "I see you've also discovered one of the last ships of out Paris."
emigre.node.191: "Yvette, I've never been so glad to see you." She gasps. Before you get the chance to respond, you see another figure approaching through the gloom.
emigre.node.190: Suddenly, you spot Élisabeth hurriedly moving across the sand, with her daughter Julie following close behind. They're both positively laden with baggage.
emigre.node.189: Shaking their heads in bewilderment, the two of them depart, leaving you alone on the beach.
emigre.node.188: "I guess this is where we part ways, then."
emigre.node.187: "Ugh... I guess everything in Paris really is falling apart."
emigre.node.185: Without another word, Alex turns and marches back towards the shore. Towards the city and the people he swore to protect.
emigre.node.184: He pauses to tenderly kiss your forehead, and stares into your eyes. It's as if he was memorizing every last detail.
emigre.node.182: "But I can't do that, yet. My duty is here."
emigre.node.181: "I want to leave with you, more than anything." He replies, putting a hand around your waist and bringing you close. "I want to disappear with you, and start something new."
emigre.node.180: Alex stares at you, dumbfounded. "Yvette... I..."
emigre.node.179:
In a swirl of dark and luxurious fabrics, Honorade turns and walks away. 

It is the last time you will ever see her.
emigre.node.178: "I suppose that's it, then." She sighs. "Au revoir Yvette. I hope that you've found whatever it is that you're searching for."
emigre.node.176: "Sorry, I just assumed that we would... never mind."
emigre.node.175: It is not just silence. Silence is the absence of noise. Alex and Honorade greet your reply with something so quiet, that it devours all the sound around it.
emigre.node.174: "What? Where did this come from?" Honorade snaps.
emigre.node.173: "I guess this is where we part ways, then."
emigre.node.172: "So, dear Yvette, I guess you and I are leaving together."
emigre.node.171: "Well, I am sorry ladies, but I can't stay long. My unit is moving out to secure the Pont Neuf in a few hours."
emigre.node.170: "Well, I wasn't planning on this, but my sleep last night was rudely interrupted by someone hurling bricks through every single one of my windows. After that, I felt that it was a good time to find myself a way out of the city."
emigre.node.169: "Ah, Madame Gazel I take it?" Alex asks. "I see you've also discovered one of the last ships of out Paris."
emigre.node.168: "Yvette, darling! What are you doing here?" She asks in a low voice.
emigre.node.167: That is... that is a lot of possessions.
emigre.node.166: You almost miss Madame Gazel in the darkness, as she is nearly camouflaged in the night by her black dress. You can see her servant René behind her silently unloading a bevy of possessions into a nearby row boat.
emigre.node.165: Shaking their heads in bewilderment, the two women depart, leaving you alone on the beach. While you'll all be traveling on the same ship together out to the coast, you get the feeling that this will be last time you ever speak to either of them.
emigre.node.164: "Ugh... I guess everything in Paris really is falling apart."
emigre.node.163: "Sorry, I just assumed that we would... never mind."
emigre.node.161: Camille returns to the boat, and Madame Gazel turns to you "What next, darling?"
emigre.node.160: "Why, thank you." Madame Gazel replies with a smile. "Please wait with René you adorable thing. Your mistress and I shall be along in a moment."
emigre.node.159: She quiets to a whisper, saying "... I just finished packing your things onto the boat, and the sailors are telling us that we'll need to leave soon."
emigre.node.158: "Uh... excusez-moi, madame- I mean madames!" Camille stammers, flushing bright red.
emigre.node.157: "We're done when I say we're done." She growls playfully in your ear.
emigre.node.156: She pulls you in closer with her hand on your chin and kisses you fiercely. Wary of the other people present, you start to pull away, but she seizes your wrist with her free hand and holds you in place.
emigre.node.155: Madame Gazel stares at you for a while before saying "I understand how difficult that must have been, but you have no idea how much it pleases me to know that you've chosen me."
emigre.node.154: She leaves, making no attempt to hide that she's hurt. You're not sure how you know it, but you know that this was the last time you'd ever see Élisabeth.
emigre.node.153: "Au revoir, Yvette. I think we have a boat to catch."
emigre.node.152: "Well, Julia and I are heading to Rome next. Maybe I'll be able to pick up some clients there."
emigre.node.151: Elisabeth stares at you in giddy shock for a few moments, mouth agape.
emigre.node.150:
In a swirl of dark and luxurious fabrics, Honorade walks away. 

It is the last time you will ever see her.
emigre.node.149: "I suppose that's it, then." She sighs. "Au revoir Yvette. I hope that you've found whatever it is that you're searching for."
emigre.node.147: "Sorry, I just assumed that we would... never mind."
emigre.node.146: "Ugh... I guess everything in Paris really is falling apart."
emigre.node.145: It is not just silence. Silence is the absence of noise. Élisabeth and Honorade greet your reply with something so quiet, that it devours all the sound around it.
emigre.node.144: "What? What are you saying? I just thought-" Élisabeth gasps.
emigre.node.143: "What? Where did this come from?" Honorade snaps.
emigre.node.142: "Well, not about this... it's just that we're here at the same time and..."
emigre.node.141: "Oh really, you and Yvette agreed to travel together?" Madame Gazel asks, her voice flat and monotone. "I didn't realize the two of you were in correspondence."
emigre.node.140: "Well, at least you're here, Yvette. Once we reach the coast we can head to Rome. I have some potential clients there, and there are much worse places to start over.
emigre.node.139: "Ah yes, fleeing for my life with my only child and what few possessions I can muster, while leaving my husband in charge of what remains of my life's work. It's been a day of endless joy." Élisabeth replies, her voices dripping with angry sarcasm.
emigre.node.138: "Ah, Madame Le Brun I take it?" Honorade asks with a wry smile. "I see you've decided to join us as well. Enjoying the excitement, I take it?"
emigre.node.137: "Yvette, darling! What are you doing here?" She asks in a low voice.
emigre.node.136: "I'm glad to see you've made it." Alex says in a low voice, keeping a firm hand on his saber, to stop it from rattling. Before you get the chance to respond, you see another figure approaching through the darkness.
emigre.node.135: You almost miss Madame Gazel in the darkness, as she is nearly camouflaged in the night by her black dress. You can see her servant René behind her silently unloading a bevy of possessions into a nearby row boat.
emigre.node.134: "Yvette, I've never been so glad to see you." She gasps. Before you get the chance to respond, you see another figure approaching through the gloom.
emigre.node.133: You spot Élisabeth hurriedly moving across the sand, with her daughter Julie following close behind. They're both positively laden with baggage.
emigre.node.132: You may have come here alone, but you've left with a woman like Élisabeth. Paris may burn, but together, you both have a whole world ahead of you.
emigre.node.131: As you climb into the boat, and the sailors shove out to the water, you feel a renewed sense of purpose.
emigre.node.130: You're not sure how long you spend staring out onto that now familiar skyline, but eventually you feel Élisabeth gently tug at your elbow. You turn and go.
emigre.node.129: Still, there is a beauty here that you've never seen anywhere else. You know that no matter where you make landfall, it will never be quite the same.
emigre.node.128: Staring out at the ship that will take you out to the rest of the world, you feel a renewed sense of purpose.
emigre.node.127: You may have labored long and hard to get here, but that time is over. The city has changed, and now you need to change as well.
emigre.node.126: They step away to leave you with your thoughts while you take one last look at Paris. The lights are dimmer than when you first arrived. What voices you can hear, are more full of worry.
emigre.node.125: Élisabeth helps you aboard, and you quickly find yourself settled in. Behind you, your servants are already seated, ready and waiting. Without another word, the sailors shove off into the water.
emigre.node.124: "What next, madame?" Camille asks, already dreaming of Rome.
emigre.node.123: "Why, in fact I am! Personally, I'd suggest that we go to Rome. It's warm, not far from the sea, and I'm sure that I can find many interesting clients to paint. "
emigre.node.122: "Oh! Bonsoir Madame Le Brun, are you joining us on our boat ride?"
emigre.node.121: Camille approaches you and whispers. "Uh, madame... I just finished packing your things onto the boat, and the sailors are telling us that we'll need to leave soon."
emigre.node.120: She wraps her arms around you, and quickly gives you a peck on the cheek. It's not enough to draw too much attention, but just enough to let you know of her intentions later.
emigre.node.119: She leaves, making no attempt to hide that she's hurt. You're not sure how you know it, but you know that this was the last time you'd ever see Élisabeth.
emigre.node.118: "Au revoir, Yvette. I think we have a boat to catch."
emigre.node.117: "Well, Julia and I are probably heading to Rome next. Maybe I'll be able to pick up some clients there."
emigre.node.116: "Ugh... I guess everything in Paris really is falling apart."
emigre.node.115: "What? What are you saying? I just thought-"
emigre.node.114: "Oh, we are going to make such glorious art together!"
emigre.node.113: "So, Julie and I are leaving. Jean may follow us, or he may not. We don't know yet."
emigre.node.112: "We're already running away. How would you like to do it, together?"
emigre.node.111: "My husband Jean is staying behind. He thinks he can keep the art dealership going, but I simply don't know anymore."
emigre.node.110: "I have other responsibilities." She gestures to her daughter, who has collapsed in an undignified heap on top of the bags.
emigre.node.109: "Absolutely. Even if I wanted to stay amidst, all of this upheaval..."
emigre.node.108: "Mon Dieu, the last few weeks have been absolutely maddening. Every day feels like it's going to bring some new calamity, and it often does. I don't know when anything is going to get better, and I can barely focs enough to work anymore."
emigre.node.107: "Yvette, I've never been so glad to see you." She gasps.
emigre.node.106: You spot Élisabeth hurriedly moving across the sand, with her daughter Julie following close behind. They're both positively laden with baggage.
emigre.node.105: Staring out at the ship that will take you out to the rest of the world, you feel a renewed sense of purpose.
emigre.node.104: You may have labored long and hard to get here, but that time is over. The city has changed, and now you need to change as well.
emigre.node.103: You may have come here alone, but you've left with a woman like Madame Gazel. Paris may burn, but together, you both have a whole world ahead of you.
emigre.node.102: As you climb into the boat, and the sailors shove out to the water, you feel a renewed sense of purpose.
emigre.node.101: You're not sure how long you spend staring out onto that now familiar skyline, but eventually you feel Madame Gazel gently tug at your elbow. You turn and go.
emigre.node.100: Still, there is a beauty here that you've never seen anywhere else. You know that no matter where you make landfall, it will never be quite the same.
emigre.node.99: "We're done when I say we're done." She growls playfully in your ear.
emigre.node.98:
In a swirl of dark and luxurious fabrics, Honorade walks away. 

It is the last time you will ever see her.
emigre.node.97: "I suppose that's it, then." She sighs. "Goodbye Yvette. May you find whatever it is that you're searching for."
emigre.node.95: "Sorry, I just assumed that we would... never mind."
emigre.node.94: She steps away to leave you with your thoughts while you take one last look at Paris. The lights are dimmer than when you first arrived. What voices you can hear, are more full of worry.
emigre.node.93: Following a step behind her, you help Madame Gazel into the boat before boarding yourself. Your servants are already there, ready and waiting. Without another word, the sailors shove off into the water.
emigre.node.92: Camille returns to the boat, and Madame Gazel turns to you "What next, darling?"
emigre.node.91: "Why, thank you." Madame Gazel replies with a smile. "Please wait with René, you adorable thing. Your mistress and I shall be along in a moment."
emigre.node.90: She quiets to a whisper, saying "... I just finished packing your things onto the boat, and the sailors are telling us that we'll need to leave soon."
emigre.node.89: "Uh... excusez-moi, madame- I mean madames!" Camille stammers, flushing bright red.
emigre.node.88: She pulls you in closer with her hand on your chin and kisses you fiercely. Wary of the other people present, you start to pull away, but she seizes your wrist with her free hand and holds you in place.
emigre.node.86: "You have no idea how much it pleases me to hear you say that."
emigre.node.84: She reaches out and tenderly grasps your chin between her fingers. "I'm so glad to see you here. I couldn't stand the thought of you being hurt by someone else."
emigre.node.83: "While I may find pleasure in this morbid aesthetic, I would prefer to perpetuate it in the land of the living." She continues with a wry smile.
emigre.node.82: "Earlier tonight, I had René take my carriage by your home to pick you up, but it appears that you'd already left for this charming little port."
emigre.node.81: "Revolution and liberty may be the only rightful choice for our people, but I doubt that such noble sentiments will do me any good, should someone decide to burn my home to the ground with me in it."
emigre.node.80: "His Majesty may be the rightful ruler of the land, but I doubt that such loyal sentiments will do me any good, should someone decide to burn my home to the ground with me in it."
emigre.node.79: "My sleep last night was rudely interrupted by someone hurling bricks through every single one of my windows. After that, I felt that it was a good time to find myself a way out of the city."
emigre.node.78: "So we're of the same mind, then. Paris isn't safe anymore, and all the money and the liberty in the world mean nothing if one has a dagger buried in their breast."
emigre.node.77: "Yvette, darling! What are you doing here?" She asks in a low voice.
emigre.node.76: That is... that is a lot of possessions.
emigre.node.75: You almost miss Madame Gazel in the darkness, as she is nearly camouflaged in the night by her black dress. You can see her servant René behind her silently unloading a bevy of possessions into a nearby row boat.
emigre.node.74: You may have come here alone, but you've left with a man as gallant as Alex. Paris may burn, but together, you both have a whole world ahead of you.
emigre.node.73: Staring out at the ship that will take you out to the rest of the world, you feel a renewed sense of purpose.
emigre.node.72: You may have labored long and hard to get here, but that time is over. The city has changed, and now you need to change as well.
emigre.node.71: As you climb into the boat, and the sailors shove out to the water, you feel a renewed sense of purpose.
emigre.node.70: You're not sure how long you spend staring out onto that now familiar skyline, but eventually you feel Alex gently tug at your hand. You turn and go.
emigre.node.69: Still, there is a beauty here that you've never seen anywhere else. You know that no matter where you make landfall, it will never be quite the same.
emigre.node.68: They both step away to leave you with your thoughts while you take one last look at Paris. The lights are dimmer than when you first arrived. What voices you can hear, are more full of worry.
emigre.node.67: With a strong but gentle hand, Alex helps you aboard the boat, followed quickly by your servants. Without another word, the sailors shove off into the water.
emigre.node.65: "It appears that I am. It seems like we could all use a change of scenery."
emigre.node.64: "Oh! Bonsoir Monsieur Dumas, are you joining us on our boat ride?"
emigre.node.63: Camille approaches you and whispers. "Uh, madame... I just finished packing your things onto the boat, and the sailors are telling us that we'll need to leave soon."
emigre.node.62: Corporal d'Auvergne marches away into the night, leaving you with Alex on the beach. "I guess that's that, then." Alex laughs, running his fingers through his hair.
emigre.node.61: "Yes, yes, of course I am! Now take this lovely woman and go, before I realize how incredibly stupid I'm being right now." The young Dragoon barks angrily.
emigre.node.60: "Out there, tens of thousands of people are in danger, and I can't rightly put my own happiness above theirs."
emigre.node.59: Genuinely moved, Alex pauses to salute his friend. "You're a true man of chivalry, d'Auvergne."
emigre.node.58: Camille approaches you and whispers. "Uh, madame... I just finished packing your things onto the boat, and the sailors are telling us that we'll need to leave soon."
emigre.node.57: Without another word, Alex turns and marches back towards the shore. Towards the city and the people he swore to protect.
emigre.node.56: He pauses to tenderly kiss your forehead, and stares into your eyes. It's as if he was memorizing every last detail.
emigre.node.55: "To the hangman with our duty! I'll make something up to tell our Lieutenant. The city's already descended so far into chaos, that he's likely to believe any tale I tell him about your sudden disappearance."
emigre.node.54: "d'Auvergne, we swore an oath. Our duty-"
emigre.node.53: "You'll either go with her right now, or step aside and I will!"
emigre.node.52: "A beautiful woman, charming and clever wants to whisk you away from this thankless life of blood and gunpowder... and you're even considering staying?"
emigre.node.50: Alex suddenly straightens up and puts his hands out defensively. "d'Auvergne, you don't understand..."
emigre.node.49: "It may take some time for us to reunite again, but I already look forward to that day. Please stay safe, my love."
emigre.node.46: "Corporal Dumas, what the devil are you doing here?"
emigre.node.45: "As long as there's honor to be had and glory to be won, I'll be fine."
emigre.node.44: "That sounds like a fine adventure to me!" He laughs, tension visibly unburdening from him.
emigre.node.42: He sighs and looks back towards the city. Towards a place he swore to protect.
emigre.node.41: "But I can't do that, yet. My duty is here."
emigre.node.40: "Fear not, Yvette." He chuckles. "It'll take more than a few stray musket balls to be the end of me."
emigre.node.39: "Oh, I want that, more than anything." He replies, putting a hand around your waist and bringin you close. "I want to disappear with you, and start something new."
emigre.node.38: "I'm sorry, but I can't stay long. My unit is moving out to secure the Pont Neuf in a few hours."
emigre.node.37: "I'm glad to see you've made it." Alex says in a low voice, keeping a firm hand on his saber, to stop it from rattling.
emigre.node.36: "You're also been really nice to me. Nicer than anyone else I've ever worked for!"
emigre.node.34: "Some of those might be easier to reach than others." Hansel replies with a chuckle. "In the end, it's all up to Madame Yvette here."
emigre.node.33: "So we can go anywhere? Like Rome? Or the Americas? or the Orient?" Camille asks, starting to bubble up with excitement.
emigre.node.32: "I'm glad to see you've made it." Alex says in a low voice, keeping a firm hand on his saber, to stop it from rattling. Before you get the chance to respond, you see another figure approaching through the gloom.
emigre.node.31: You peer into the dark at your fellow travelers, searching desperately for some sort of familiar face. Eventually, one appears.
emigre.node.30: As you climb into the boat, and the sailors shove out to the water, you feel a renewed sense of purpose.
emigre.node.29: Just because a city burns, doesn't mean your own ambitions have yet been extinguished.
emigre.node.28: Staring out at the ship that will take you out to the rest of the world, you feel a renewed sense of purpose.
emigre.node.27: You're not sure how long you spend staring out onto that now familiar skyline, but eventually you feel Camille gently tug at your hand. You turn and go.
emigre.node.26: You may have labored long and hard to get here, but that time is over. The city has changed, and now you need to change as well.
emigre.node.25: Still, there is a beauty here that you've never seen anywhere else. You know that no matter where you make landfall, it will never be quite the same.
emigre.node.24: They step away to leave you with your thoughts while you take one last look at Paris. The lights are dimmer than when you first arrived. What voices you can hear, are more full of worry.
emigre.node.23: With a light and quiet step, you climb aboard the boat, followed quickly by your servants. Without another word, the sailors shove off into the water.
emigre.node.21: "I don't know where we're going, but I hope it's somewhere warm. That would be nice."
emigre.node.20: "There's a whole lot of world out there to see. It would be a waste to spend your whole life in one place."
emigre.node.19: "Don't worry. It's not so bad..." Hansel says, as he strides up to join your group. "After fighting in the Americas, I practically stayed."
emigre.node.18: "My mother, brothers, and sisters left for the country-side weeks ago. Too much fighting near their home. I stayed in Paris with you because I was the only one who still had work."
emigre.node.17: "I'm a little worried. You see, I've never left Paris before."
emigre.node.16: "Uh, madame... I just finished packing your things onto the boat, and the sailors are telling us that we'll need to leave soon."
emigre.node.15: Alex died less than two months ago, trying to keep other people safe. He cared so much about others, and even now, it feels like this was his doing. That he's still trying to make sure that you're alright.
emigre.node.14: You peer into the dark at your fellow travelers, and spy no familiar faces.
emigre.node.13: You peer into the dark at your fellow travelers, searching desperately for some sort of familiar face. Eventually, one appears.
emigre.node.12: You peer into the dark at your fellow travelers, searching desperately for some sort of familiar face. Eventually, one appears.
emigre.node.11: You peer into the dark at your fellow travelers, searching desperately for some sort of familiar face. Eventually, one appears.
emigre.node.10: You peer into the dark at your fellow travelers, searching desperately for some sort of familiar face. Eventually, one appears.
emigre.node.9: You peer into the dark at your fellow travelers, searching desperately for some sort of familiar face. Eventually, one appears.
emigre.node.8: You peer into the dark at your fellow travelers, searching desperately for some sort of familiar face. Eventually, one appears.
emigre.node.7:
You were never a woman of great means. You'd merely found a way to live like one.

Not that there's anything wrong with that.
emigre.node.6: A few rowboats are pulled up on the sand, accompanied by small clusters of sailors and fellow travelers loading their cases.
emigre.node.5: You arrive at the address along the river. There's no official dockmaster here, and you have to squint to spot a ship waiting in the river. All of its lamps have been extinguished, and its crew labors in silence, doing their best to blend in with the quiet of the night.
emigre.node.4: Between, yourself, Camille and Hansel, it's not that hard to carry everything. Other than your wardrobe, you actually possessed very little in the way of valuables.
emigre.node.3: As you skulk across the city, you remain in cautious silence. Even though you can't see them, you can feel the weight of eyes upon you. Eyes watching you from inside houses. Eyes of people too afraid to leave their own homes in the daylight, much less at night.
emigre.node.2: Twisting and turning through the streets, you approach every corner cautiously. Often, you find barricades blocking your way, forcing you to backtrack multiple times.
emigre.node.1: A heavy bag is slung over your shoulder, and Camille hurries behind you, carrying everything else. Other than your fine wardrobe, you actually possessed very little in the way of valuables.
emigre.node.0: You leave your decrepit house for the last time to head for the docks. It seems like the violent discontent that's wracked the streets for the last few weeks has chosen to abate, for a moment.
emigre.link.248: "I need a moment. Let me take one last look at the city, before we leave."
emigre.link.247: "Let's shove off. The sooner we can get to Rome, the better."
emigre.link.229: "Actually, I feel that the time has come for me to travel by myself for a while."
emigre.link.228: "I'm sorry Élisabeth, but I wish to leave with Alex."
emigre.link.227: "Élisabeth is right. She and I are leaving together for Rome."

emigre.link.206: "Why not though? Leave with me, and just let it all go. We can escape together."

antoinesInvitationReward.name: Antoine's Invitation
antoinesInvitationReward.node.6: The letter goes on to describe a location where you could meet him.
antoinesInvitationReward.node.5: You check his directions against your map. If you head out now, it might be possible to meet up with Antoine today.
antoinesInvitationReward.node.4: ('Direct Action' is now available to visit in the Paris map)
antoinesInvitationReward.node.3: 'Fear not. I'm certain that you will enjoy this as much as the royalists will hate it. Gloire, paix et rage patriotique, - Antoine'
antoinesInvitationReward.node.2: 'Chere Yvette, I've grown dissatisfied with the ceaseless inaction of my peers and have decided to do something myself. I would like you to join me, should you find yourself inclined to the cause of liberty'
antoinesInvitationReward.node.1: You break the seal with a deft slice from your letter opener. You can immediately tell that the handwriting is Antoine's. He writes quickly enough that you can find small spatters of ink at the top of his compressed, precise letters.
antoinesInvitationReward.node.0: While getting ready for the day, you notice that Camille has left a letter on your nightstand. The wax seal shines red like fresh blood.
royalVigilance.name: Royal Vigilance
royalVigilance.node.8:
(The Crown has gained some power)
(The Revolution has lost some power)
royalVigilance.node.7:
There's been a variety of people who've dared to whisper that the king was distracted, vassilating, and irresolute, but this latest display seems to have put a halt to such claims.

At least, for the moment.
royalVigilance.node.6: This comical lapse has only aided the Revolution's rhetoric that the Third Estate is taking the concerns of the people far more seriously than the Crown and the Second Estate.
royalVigilance.node.5: And so, in Paris, life goes on.
royalVigilance.node.4:
(The Crown has lost some power)
(The Revolution has gained some power)
royalVigilance.node.3: However, despite the drudgery and tiresome revisiting of the same issues, over and over again, His Majesty has remained sharp, alert, and incisive.
royalVigilance.node.2: Which is rather unfortunate, because that meant that every member of the assembled estates noticed when His Majesty fell asleep on his throne during one of the debates.
royalVigilance.node.1: The daily debates over the details of extremely particular issues are dragging on for a long time. However, there is still a level of anticipation in the air. For most of the assembled representatives, this is their first chance to actually see the thirty-three year old king's ability to rule, in person.
royalVigilance.node.0:
As one might imagine, His Majesty King Louis XVI is a subject of much attention during the Estates General. Which is by design. He's on a throne, which is on a platform, at the head of the entire chamber.

Much of royal power seems to come from making sure that you can't be ignored.
toBenefitThePoor.name: To Benefit the Poor
toBenefitThePoor.node.5: And so, in Paris, life goes on.
toBenefitThePoor.node.3: Unfortunately, despite the auction being well attended by those seeking to see and be seen, it seems that it wasn't attended by many people actually intending to spend money for a good cause. This failure of personal charity has made Monsieur Riquet look quite the fool, and made the Bourgeoisie seem ineffective in the face of a true crisis.
toBenefitThePoor.node.2: The auction went exceedingly well, and was enough to supply a good amount of Paris' poorest citizens with enough bread to last the week. Hardly a remedy for a national crisis, but it showed that the members of the Bourgeoisie not only care about their fellow commoners, but they have the ability to actually do something worthwhile.
toBenefitThePoor.node.1: This noble endeavor attracted much attention, and has been covered by many of the most prominent newspapers. In fact, it was such an exclusive event that they even sent Pierre a letter preemptively forbidding him from attending.
toBenefitThePoor.node.0: With the threat of famine continuing to grow, a prominent entepeneur in the Bourgeoisie, one Monsieur Riquet, hosted a charity auction where he sold nearly his entire art collection to help feed the poor.
spiritualPossession.name: Spiritual Possession
spiritualPossession.node.5: And so, in Paris, life goes on.
spiritualPossession.node.3: Unfortunately, it seems that his punishment will be almost entirely spiritual in nature. After being forced to return the lost funds, the bishop was simply shuffled to a position in a different province, without any additional censure. This flagrant apathy towards corruption has damaged the people's faith in the Church.
spiritualPossession.node.2: Shockingly, the bishop's superiors acted in the strongest terms. Not only has the Pope ordered the bishop to be immediately defrocked, the now former priest has been seized and sent to Rome to await trial. The common people have reacted well to this harsh treatment of corruption, and seem to show renewed faith in the Church.
spiritualPossession.node.1: A bishop in Lyon was recently caught embezzling a significant amount of funds from the Church, and there are rumors that he was attempting to sell a holy relic to a private collector. This latest embarrassment has forced his superiors to act.
spiritualPossession.node.0: It's a well-known secret that certain priests manage their parish as if it were their own personal estate. The Catholic Church tends to overlook such worldly indiscretions, but there are limits.
aManOfControversy.name: A Man of Controversy
aManOfControversy.node.8: Regardless, Mirabeau has made the Revolution seem extremely competent.
aManOfControversy.node.7:
At the height of this disagreement, Mirabeau loudly proclaimed that the priest Talleyrand “would sell his own soul for money and he would be right, for he would be exchanging shit for gold." 

Whether or not this is true, it doesn't make the Revolution look good.
aManOfControversy.node.6:
(The Revolution has lost some power)
(The Church has moved away from the Revolution a little)
aManOfControversy.node.5: Unfortunately, that very wit got ahead of him, when became embroiled in a fight with a representative of the First Estate, one Talleyrand.
aManOfControversy.node.4: And so, in Paris, life goes on.
aManOfControversy.node.3:
(The Revolution has gained some power)
(The Crown has lost some power)
aManOfControversy.node.2: Against all odds, Mirabeau has managed to restrain himself amidst the heated discussions, and occassionally even served as the voice of reason. Rumors abound of the Queen even attempting to bribe Mirabeau as part of some scheme to undermine the Third Estate, but you're not sure if there's any substance to them.
aManOfControversy.node.1: Of course, the most suprising thing is that he was legally allowed to return to the country at all, or that nobody has killed him yet. Despite his work ethic, measured political stances, and his talents as an orator, the man's caustic wit tends to make him enemies at a pace greater than even your own.
aManOfControversy.node.0: Today, the talk of Paris is that Honoré Riqueti the <i>Comte de Mirabeau</>, is representing the Third Estate in the Estates General. Known more simply as 'Mirabeau', he's been a outspoken supporter of the Revolution for a long time.
thePeoplesDefenders.name: The People's Defenders
thePeoplesDefenders.node.6: And so, in Paris, life goes on.
thePeoplesDefenders.node.3: While the dragoons easily captured the bandits, news has reached the public that this group of criminals was composed almost entirely of former soldiers, who fought in the American War of Independence. The public has reacted poorly to this revelation, and many wonder why they should place their faith in people so quick to turn against them.
thePeoplesDefenders.node.2: The dragoons dispersed the bandits quickly, and without incident. This easy victory has strengthened the people's faith in the Military.
thePeoplesDefenders.node.1: A few days ago, the Military dispatched the Queen’s Royal Dragoons to bring these brigands to heel.
thePeoplesDefenders.node.0: Bandits have always been a problem in France, but the growing famine has only encouraged more desperate people to prey upon roving travelers. Things reached a head recently, when one bold group of highwaymen began committing robberies just outside of Paris itself.
ourPeculiarSystem.name: Our Peculiar System
ourPeculiarSystem.description: The architect, Christophe is locked in a conversation about noble priveleges, that he doesn't want to be in. Perhaps you can rescue him?
ourPeculiarSystem.node.36: The older nobleman storms off, shaking his fist at you both and muttering some impotent oath of vengeance to himself. The nearby crowd whispers worriedly amongst themselves at his departure.
ourPeculiarSystem.node.35: (You have gained a decent amount of peril)
ourPeculiarSystem.node.34: "This isn't over, you quarrelsome woman. Nor is it for you, you Austrian cur!"
ourPeculiarSystem.node.33: (You have gained a decent amount of credibility)
ourPeculiarSystem.node.32: "Your silence answers my question more thoroughly than any words you could speak! Madame Decaux and I have a pressing engagement. Please feel free to join us when you'd like to join the rest of Europe in the modern day."
ourPeculiarSystem.node.30: "Have you personally served in France's army or navy?"
ourPeculiarSystem.node.29: "Well, not me personally, but a cousin of mine..."
ourPeculiarSystem.node.28: "Ah, but did you?" Christophe says, searching the nobleman's jacket for any ribbons or honors, and finding it distinctly barren. "Did you personally fight for France, in any of its many, extremely expensive wars? Wars paid for by taxes."
ourPeculiarSystem.node.27: "Well, to start, we've been at the forefront of the King's armies, fighting for France for over a millenia!"
ourPeculiarSystem.node.24: The older nobleman storms off to badger someone else, and Christophe waits until he's entirely gone before turning to you.
ourPeculiarSystem.node.23: "After all, a man will never understand something, if his livelihood depends on not understanding it. No matter how you try, he'll just blame you for not explaining it right."
ourPeculiarSystem.node.22: "Well, if nothing else, I appreciate what you were trying to do." Christophe says with a shrug. "For what little it's worth, I don't think anything could change that blowhard's mind."
ourPeculiarSystem.node.21:
(You have lost a decent amount of credibility)
(You have gained some peril)
ourPeculiarSystem.node.20: You chat with Christophe for a bit, and laugh behind your hands together at your now departed conversational partner, before parting ways.
ourPeculiarSystem.node.18: "Normally, I'd relish the opportunity to verbally trounce someone like that, but you've probably just saved me from myself, Yvette. So, you have my thanks!"
ourPeculiarSystem.node.16: The older nobleman disappears to badger someone else, and Christophe waits until he's entirely gone before turning to you.
ourPeculiarSystem.node.15: You talk with the nobleman a while longer, but the conversation doesn't seem to stretch beyond your ability to flatter him and his ability to take those words at face value. Eventually, you leave to see if you can find a conversation that's more substantial.
ourPeculiarSystem.node.13: As the architect disappears from sight, the nobleman tuts disapprovingly. "Ignore such grand pronouncements, madame. He's just another arrogant foreigner, covetous of what we have. At least you understand your place in things."
ourPeculiarSystem.node.12: Christophe leaves, before you can offer any sort of defense.
ourPeculiarSystem.node.10: "Ah, this is some clumsy ruse intended to push me away. I don't have to endure such disrespect!"
ourPeculiarSystem.node.9: "Ah, splendid! It's nice to have someone who knows how important my time is!" He says, suddenly coming to the conclusion that it is he who was the one being inconvenienced all along.
ourPeculiarSystem.node.8: "'Simply different', without an explanation is less of an answer than silence." Christophe says with a shake of his head. "It's the sort of thing people say to make themselves feel better about being taken advantage of."
ourPeculiarSystem.node.7: "What? You ingrates really think we should be so unfairly burdened, after all we've done for the people of France?"
ourPeculiarSystem.node.6: "You wish to take care of this for me?"
ourPeculiarSystem.node.5: "That's because of our unique situation! You foreigners simply don't understand. For example-"
ourPeculiarSystem.node.3: "None, Monsieur. No other kingdom in all of Europe still allows their nobility such a privelege. They haven't, for a very long time. Perhaps there's a reason for that?"
ourPeculiarSystem.node.2: "Nonsense, you'll see soon enough!" The nobleman chuckles, intercepting Christophe as he's about to leave. "Such arrangements are the bedrock of a just monarchy. Think! How many kingdoms in Europe are balanced in such a way?"
ourPeculiarSystem.node.1: "Really, I must go." Christophe insists. "All I was saying earlier is that if the nobility of France have most of the money, but functionally pay little to no taxes... it's plain to see how such a thing could never last, non? Eventually, something is going to break."
ourPeculiarSystem.node.0: You come across the architect Christophe, who's currently talking with some nobleman about taxation. You're not really certain how he was drawn into this particular conversation, but judging from Christophe's barely concealed frustration, you get the feeling it was by no intent of her own.
ourPeculiarSystem.link.7: "Christophe, you should listen to the honorable Monsieur, here. Things are simply different in France."
ourPeculiarSystem.link.6: "I think he wants to be in this conversation about as much as I want to be paying your share of taxes."
ourPeculiarSystem.link.5: "Monsieur, why don't you leave me alone with Christophe? I'm sure I can convince him."
primedAndReady.name: Primed and Ready
primedAndReady.description: Michael Pelletier seems to found himself yet another romantic rival, and requires your assistance in using their temper against them.
primedAndReady.node.47: Ah, yes. How mysterious. Simply impossible to understand.
primedAndReady.node.46: He then leaves without so much as an 'adieu'. Worse yet, he leaves in the opposite direction of Michael Pelletier. Curses. Perhaps there's something else that you can do at this party.
primedAndReady.node.45: "I know that impudent Pelletier is trying to provoke me, but not today! I'm more than willing to play the waiting game." He continues, gritting his teeth.
primedAndReady.node.44: "I've made my desires more than clear, as well as my willingness to defend her honor, with steel if necessary. Still, she always dismisses it as 'an unusual joke' and changes the subject. I just don't understand it!"
primedAndReady.node.42: (You have gained a decent amount of peril)
primedAndReady.node.41: Well, enraging him wasn't exactly difficult.
primedAndReady.node.40: Together, the two of you toast to his future success. Hopefully, the next time you see him, he won't have any extra holes in him.
primedAndReady.node.38: He slips you some a small pouch of coins, as thanks for your help. It's not much, but your real goal is the payoff that could happen later.
primedAndReady.node.36: "The wheels of my plan are well and truly in motion!" He whispers excitedly to you. "His challenge itself isn't illegal, but attempting to act on it would certainly be enough to get him arrested. Soon he'll be out of the way, and Hortense will be free to choose whatever paramour she desires..."
primedAndReady.node.35: Some time later, while you're doing your best to look inconspicuous as you lay siege to a small table of canapés, you're approached by Michael. He looks quite pleased, despite the growing welt on the side of his face.
primedAndReady.node.34: He storms off, and it's not long after that you hear the slap of a glove and the scandalized gasps of some onlookers.
primedAndReady.node.33: "Let's see if Pelletier's willing to back up his impudence with steel."
primedAndReady.node.32: "There's only so many times a man can approach a woman he's not yet involved with, and utter 'I would kill for you' before a woman starts to wonder 'why all the killing?', non?" He laughs.
primedAndReady.node.31: "If that foreign layabout wants to play at intrigues, then I shall be more than willing to oblige him."
primedAndReady.node.30:
(You have lost quite a bit of credibility)
(You have gained some peril)
primedAndReady.node.29: With that, Hansel falls in behind you, just as you hear the slap of a leather glove on skin and the scandalized gasps of some onlookers.
primedAndReady.node.28: “Shame is for people who already have money and titles." Hansel shrugs. "I do my job well because I like you, and I like getting paid. I don't need any other incentives to break a man, least of all honor."
primedAndReady.node.27: "Respectfully, madame, there is nothing 'under control' about either of those men."
primedAndReady.node.26: The two of you take this moment to nod together in silent agreement.
primedAndReady.node.25: "Hmmph, this all feels like a lot of pretense, just to stab someone you hate."
primedAndReady.node.24: With that, he storms away from you both, already retrieving a leather glove from the inside of his coat.
primedAndReady.node.23: "Ugh! I simply knew this would happen!" The man spits. "Excusez moi, I have something pressing to attend to."
primedAndReady.node.22: "On my honor, guter Herr. It was infuriating to hear, and I barely know you. Madame Decaux insisted that we tell you, before any further damage to your reputation could be done."
primedAndReady.node.21: "That can't be true." He mutters unsurely. "Even that foreign layabout isn't so free with his word..."
primedAndReady.node.20: "Yesterday, we heard Monsieur Pelletier impugning your good name. Not just normal boasts and insults. He specifically called you a coward. Like a dog that only barks when its master has it safely on a leash."
primedAndReady.node.19: "Non, non, non! That cannot be true. This is just some clumsy plan to provoke my temper!"
primedAndReady.node.18: "I see. He has chosen to make this personal. Well, it would be my pleasure."
primedAndReady.node.17: "I'll keep this simple, and to the point." Your bodyguard says as he steps forward from his position behind you.
primedAndReady.node.15: "I would still that tongue, if I were you." He says, sweat already blossoming upon his brow and a vein freshly bulging in his forehead.
primedAndReady.node.14: "Pelletier has done that?" He asks, his attempt at a neutral expression betrayed by the newly emerged beads of sweat upon his brow.
primedAndReady.node.12: Michael leaves, which also fees you to approach the subject of your plot.
primedAndReady.node.11: He whispers his plan to you and it's extremely simple. Goad this choleric individual into challenging Michael to a duel, then appear later to witness the scene as the man is arrested for his murderous intents.
primedAndReady.node.10: Honestly, Michael's offer is rather paltry. However, you also know that if you follow up on this story as it develops, the gossip generated by it could be amazing.
primedAndReady.node.9: To the hangman with all these people absolutely insisting that you risk your reputation to solve the problems they created.
primedAndReady.node.7: You leave immediately, as such powder kegs tend to drastically shorten the life span of anyone foolish enough to be near them.
primedAndReady.node.6: "More than reasonable, Madame! How does a simple twenty livres sound, in exchange for his blind rage?"
primedAndReady.node.5: "Can you help? I can't be seen provoking him, or the plan will fail."
primedAndReady.node.4: "Still, his bellicose bombast has inspired me. I need to goad him into challenging me to a duel. This should be easy because he dueled quite frequently in the army. It may be legal in that profession, but in our world, it's quite the crime."
primedAndReady.node.3: Apparently, it is, because he continues. "I've managed to make myself a new romantic rival. The subject of our mutual affections is one Hortense du Montet. Hortense has been quite indecisive in declaring her intentions, but I think it's because my rival terrifies her."
primedAndReady.node.2: Why is it that so many people are always asking you for a favor? Just once, you'd like for something nice to happen. Is a pleasant surprise too much to ask?
primedAndReady.node.1: "Madame Decaux, I've come to request a favor of you."
primedAndReady.node.0: While you search for the latest goings on, you're approached by Michael Pelletier, the young chemistry student. Strangely enough, you've never seen him actually do anything even remotely close to his alleged studies.
primedAndReady.link.25: "'On my honor, guter Herr'? You're truly willing to stake that on a lie?"
primedAndReady.link.24: "Hansel, it's a necessary tradition. It keeps things under control."
primedAndReady.link.23: "Indeed. Like two roosters crowing in a barnyard, before the talons come out."
primedAndReady.link.14: "Hansel, can you explain the situation? This isn't my specialty."
primedAndReady.link.13: "The conflict with you and Monsieur Pelletier. Have you considered asking Hortense to settle it?"
primedAndReady.link.12: "I'm just here to see a coward up close, for the first time. At least, if the rumors are to be believed."
primedAndReady.link.11: "No, but you should know that Monsieur Pelletier has already made his move with Hortense."
primedAndReady.link.5: "I think you would do better to handle your own intrigues."
primedAndReady.link.4: "I could be persuaded to goad him, but I'll require payment."
aMatterOfSteel.name: A Matter of Steel
aMatterOfSteel.node.52: Shockingly, this question isn't aimed at you.
aMatterOfSteel.node.51: It's then that you spot the Guet Royal. More importantly, you spot them see this man threatening the two of you while he holds a pair of sabers. You nudge Michael, and he quickly steps back.
aMatterOfSteel.node.50: Michael steps in between the two of you in attempt to calm the situation, but it seems that is not one of his talents, and only serves to agitate his rival further.
aMatterOfSteel.node.49: (You have gained quite a of peril)
aMatterOfSteel.node.48: You decide to explore the rest of the party before anyone manages to connect you to any of this.
aMatterOfSteel.node.47: (You have gained a piece of Outrageous Military Gossip)
aMatterOfSteel.node.46: As amusing as other people's disappointments are, this messy intrigue was really about obtaining fantastic gossip, a task you handily succeeded at. Everyone likes to read about the imprisonment of someone powerful.
aMatterOfSteel.node.45: Michael exhales slowly, looking off into the distance, before bowing his head. "Je vous en prie, madame."
aMatterOfSteel.node.44: "You have my most sincere thanks." Hortense repeats.
aMatterOfSteel.node.43: Michael's expectant silence at these thanks is as subtle as a firework loosed into a nunnery.
aMatterOfSteel.node.42: "It's true, I'm finally out from under the jealous eye of that murderous boor. I'll sleep much sounder, going forward, and I owe you my thanks."
aMatterOfSteel.node.41: "I suppose, with his absence, you would finally be free to express the desires of your heart."
aMatterOfSteel.node.40: Without even a flourish, Hansel returns the weapons to their owner. "I can see that everything is in order, or at least it will be soon."
aMatterOfSteel.node.39: "Sir, surely you understand that we're taking your debt of honor very seriously." Hansel says, giving you a twitch of a smile. Suddenly, you hear the growing sounds of tramping boots and general discontent .
aMatterOfSteel.node.37: He continues to examine the blades... and keeps examining them...
aMatterOfSteel.node.36: Hansel unsheathes the swords, much to the consternation of the nearby guests. Heedless of their dismay, he takes some experimental test swings and examines the blades.
aMatterOfSteel.node.35: "That's seems only reasonable. I think you'll find everything in order." Michael's rival says as he hands over the weapons, begrudgingly.
aMatterOfSteel.node.34: "A revelation as alarming as it is unsurprising."
aMatterOfSteel.node.33: You decide to explore the rest of the party before anyone manages to connect you to any of this.
aMatterOfSteel.node.32: They leave before you can attempt to delay them any further, marching in the direction of that abandoned chuchyard. Surely, Michael will find a way out of this on his own... surely.
aMatterOfSteel.node.31: "Well, this isn't good." Michael mumbles to himself, proving his vast talent for understatement.
aMatterOfSteel.node.30: "Of course, Madame." Hansel steps forward, and motions for the sabers.
aMatterOfSteel.node.29: "Ah, Hortense! Yes, I'm afraid to say that his jealousy overwhelmed his reason, and he planned on cutting me down, right here. C'est incroyable, non?"
aMatterOfSteel.node.27: It's then, now that the danger has passed, that Michael returns.
aMatterOfSteel.node.26:
The guests whisper to each other as the man is arrested, and marched out of the party. 

Are they scandalized? Yes. Surprised? Not really.
aMatterOfSteel.node.25: Before the attempted duelist can even reply, the Sergeant plucks the sabers from his hands. "Clearly we need to have a discussion down at the watch post. You will follow us, monsieur."
aMatterOfSteel.node.24: It's then that your group is approached by a troop of the Guet Royal, in all of their swaggering and dubious glory. "What's this? You again?"
aMatterOfSteel.node.23: Such a futile exercise is exactly what you need to waste his time while you wait for the Guet Royal to finally arrive. Michael uses this opportunity to slip away.
aMatterOfSteel.node.22: "Perhaps we should take the time to find you one? If we're going through with this, we should do it properly."
aMatterOfSteel.node.21: You appear to have earned the ire of a man who is universally known for his short temper. He's also armed, right now.
aMatterOfSteel.node.20: You hike up your skirts, so as to hasten your retreat before any of this manages to become your problem. Surely, Michael will find a way out of this on his own... surely.
aMatterOfSteel.node.18: "Don't pester the woman, Pelletier. Most people are shy of blood." His rival chides. "I however, am not."
aMatterOfSteel.node.16: A statement that would surely arouse some sort of sympathy, were he not here to kill a man.
aMatterOfSteel.node.15: "You, Monsieur Pelletier are coming with me. My honor shall not be denied."
aMatterOfSteel.node.14:
(You have lost a little credibility)
(You have gained a large amount of peril)
aMatterOfSteel.node.13: You appear to have earned the ire of a man who is universally known for his short temper. He's also armed, right now.
aMatterOfSteel.node.12: "Non, I see the obvious gambit you're playing against me. You conspire against me, thinking me a fool."
aMatterOfSteel.node.11: "Well, I'm simply without one. For some reason, fate has conspired for me to be without a companion close enough for such a duty... or for any companions at all, really."
aMatterOfSteel.node.10: "Yes, please take as long as you like." Michael says as he steps back.
aMatterOfSteel.node.9: "You're leaving me with this? Now, of all times?" Michael hisses to you from the corner of his mouth.
aMatterOfSteel.node.8: "You dare lecture me on the validity of my methods, or the mysteries of her heart?"
aMatterOfSteel.node.6: "I find that matters of honor are best settled immediately."
aMatterOfSteel.node.5: "Oh! You mean now? In the middle of this party?" Michael asks, looking around, and seeing that the officers of the Guet Royale have yet to make their appearance.
aMatterOfSteel.node.4: "Ah, you've not only arrived, but you've done so on time? Truly, the Lord's miracles never cease." Michael's rival says, while carrying what is clearly a matched set of dueling sabers. "There's an abandoned churchyard, not far from here. I believe that'd be the ideal place. So, follow me."
aMatterOfSteel.node.3: "The strangest part was how easy it was to convince them that this was going to happen. All I had to do was mention his name. Once they arrive on the scene, he'll be dealt with, and the lovely Hortense will be free to shower me with her affections!"
aMatterOfSteel.node.2: "I've taken the precaution of tipping off someone in the archers about this attempt on my life, and they're already on their way."
aMatterOfSteel.node.1: "Ah, it's finally happening!" Michael says, with an enthusiasm rarely used by a subject of attempted murder.
aMatterOfSteel.node.0: While guests at the party are trying to pretend that nothing is amiss, the tension in the air is palpable. It seems that word has already gotten around that Michael Pelletier's duel against his rival is very soon.
aMatterOfSteel.link.8: "Hansel, can you thoroughly inspect everything, to make sure that it's all fair?"
aMatterOfSteel.link.7: "Pardonne-moi, It appears that I should be anywhere else, right now."
aMatterOfSteel.link.6: "And what makes you think that murder is going to make Hortense love you?"
aMatterOfSteel.link.5: "You plan to duel without a second? Surely, you need to find one first..."
